Bit touristy. I last visited Boudanath 40 years ago when it was surrounded by farmland and not just cafes and gift shops

Walking around the stupa. What a great Buddhist stupa. Due to repairs being done to the upper levels, they are not accessible at the moment but the lower walks around the outside are still possible and enjoyable

you need to get there. Even so the stupa has been damaged during the earthquake, it feels good to see workers busy working on rebuilding the top and some other parts of the stupa.When you go there you can still see devotees walking around the base of the stupa praying. The atmosphere has not changed and it is wonderful.
Soak up the atmosphere. Worth a half day visit to photo site and people. A very Tibetan feel to the site with lots going on. Hang round some and watch.

must visit. One of the bst place to visit, The best time ti visit this stupa is late afternoon.Try to Visit on the evening of the full moon,when the plaza surrounding the stupa is lit up by thousand of butter lamps.
Nice place. A place to visit when you are in Kathmandu. Try one of the roof restaurants and have a overview with a Everest beer.

Definitely worth a visit. This stupa is a huge building that will be magnificent again once it is renovated. Whilst it was badly damaged in he earthquake men (and women) are hard at work to effect repairs. Currently the central part of the stupa is heavily scaffolded and work is ongoing to make it safe. Having said that the stuff is still well worth a visit in the interim, there's lots to see and numerous shops to visit around the stupa perimeter.
You have to go. I have always seen the image of the Boudhanath growing up so when I hit Nepal it was the first place I visited. Bit of a climb but well worth it !
Boudanath. Really interesting culture. I did as part of a tour and i felt it was a great to see Kathmandu. Strongly recommend

Very calming and quaint. The stupa is definitely still under construction and it definitely does not look as glamorous as past photos of it. But I enjoyed my short visit to the stupa. We walked 2 rounds around the stupa (locals believe that if you're a Buddhist and you're visiting the stupa for the first time, make a wish the first time you enter and the wish'll come true), and I loved taking in the quietness of it all. There's an entrance fee if / when entering from the main gate, but because we had some local friends who brought us there they brought us through a back-gate instead. It was definitely a big difference from the hustle bustle of dust-filled streets outside! The stupa grounds aren't very big, but is filled with quaint little shops and eateries/cafes. The architecture if also vastly differently. I would have loved spending more time here, so I suggest taking 2-3 hours to fully take it all in.
Earthquake damage not yet repaired. Work to repair an earthquake damage still in progress. Everything is done by hand; no mechanization.

Wonderful....Loved it.. Exceeded expectations, it's real, there are no hussler/ sellers, the atmosphere is filled with committed locals circumnavigating at sunset. Visit Rokpa too for coffee/ shop/ to support while you are so close...

Buddha was Born in Nepal. Buddha was born in Nepal So it is very famous in Nepal and it is a heritage site in Nepal. when i visited in Kathmandu in Buddha stupa it was so beautiful and so many market surround in circle special i like Nepali thanka and Nepali handicraft which is man made by Nepali hand so nice. when i was visited there i was so regretful from god whatever we are we must have to trust and believe on God by their own religion so i like so much of peace of Nepal. thanks i will visit again when i get chance again.

The oldest Stupa in Asia. This is a world heritage site declared by UNESCO. Huge Buddhist Stupa in the midst of a square surrounded by curio shops and eateries. There is construction work in progress right now repairing the damages that occurred with the last earthquake that destroyed large portions. A must see for tourists.
Interesting temple with good views. Nice temple with good views on the city of Kathmandu. Good for a stroll around of an hour or so, you can walk from the city center. Takes about 30/45 minutes

Great site but under repair. This site is under repair from the damage of the earthquake but still worth the teip to see it and the entry fee which I think was 500 Ruprees. Theres a monastery at the same location with amazing art work and photos are allowed. Shame about the damage but well under repair. Remember to go around clockwise but is more a polite request being a religious site. Many cafes upstairs surrounding the Stupa for a bite to eat and lost of little shops and street vendors.
Painful reminder of earthquake . This site is currently under construction but still work a visit. Go to one of the monasteries nearby... With an offering you can get blessed by Buddhist monk!
Interesting. Always a good place to people watch. Sad to see damage after earthquake but good to see they are in the process of rebuilding it.
Serenity. Here is where you'll find a glimpse of what you seek when you seek for peace. As this is one of the temple of Lord Buddha you'll definitely find peace here.
Under reconstruction. This Stupa is currently under reconstruction. It was affected by the earthquake that hit Nepal last year. It is still nice to see the area.

Holy place for Tibetan Buddhists, but surrounded by shops.. atmospheric place, but very commercial and without the towering structure on top of the stupa (collapsed in the 2015 earthquake, and under scaffolding). The round square around the stupa is still a nice place to stroll and if you are lucky monks are chanting in the nearby temple. The base of the structure with its prayer wheels is in tact and one sees many Tibetans going past, turning the wheels and praying. The shops are of highly varying quality and range from trinkets to things of real beauty. It's an interesting place and one can have drinks or lunch at one of the many restaurants (some on the roof, with good views). But it's crowded and commercialised.

Kathmandu's spiritual Core: walking the Kora. Instead of walking the week long trek around Mount Kailash, you can join locals around the Boudhanath Stupa. Become part of a joined intention to gain merit by circumambulating the stupa, allowing you time and space to dedicate your efforts for the benefit of your loved ones and all sentient beings...The area is quiet and peaceful, late in the day hundreds of lamps will be lit...
place of speritual. great place for peace and happiness, i was spending three in there and praying for peace in world. thanks glp to organized wonderful trip.

Alive with people and religious fervour. Among the main monuments of Kathmandu this is the one I appreciated most, probably due to the particular setting, as you enter this closed multilateral compound with the circular stupa in the center (seen from above it is to resemble a mandala), and you walk around it (clockwise, remember) as if turning a prayer wheel, together with the faithful and visitors. Shops and cafeterias, restaurants and guesthouses dot the buildings surrounding the square. Do not forget to turn the big (and heavy) prayer wheel in the temple inside the square. It is a good place to buy tangkas and mandalas, as shops are generally one and the same with the artisans laboratories. The whole place has a marked Tibetan character, as the stupa is built right on the ancient trade route coming down from the Tibetan border. I visited during the Buddha’s birthday festival, and the place was joyously crowded with faithful. It was a pity that the 2015 earthquake has stricken hard the top of the stupa, so that the pinnacle and square drum (with the Buddha eyes) were under restoration and not visible. It was the place in Kathmandu, among the ones I saw, most alive with religious activity.

Bouddha, "the eye of peace". I visited to several places in Nepal. Nepla is naturally and culturally very rich country. We visit to boudhanath stupa with our our city guide . The place was very nice, we love to see the peace eyes of Buddha (the light of Asia we were there at the birthday of Buddha ) the boudhanath stupa is also known as the largest stupa in Asia.very good place to discover the Tibetan culture as well. "Recommend "
construction work in progress. It is not possible to make the cora completely on the upper levels. But still many antique shops around

You can spend the day. The Shree Boudhanath Area Devlopment Area is home to the Boubnanath Stupa. A Rs.250 ($2.33) admission fee is charged. It is my understanding that the fees are intended to help with restoration.There is much to do.The stupa is surrounded by shops and restaurants includkng a Thanka school. Often monks/priest can be seen walking in the area.There are more shops to explore outside the development area.
Peace in the making. Boudhnath stupa was damaged in the earthquake, but repairs are almost complete. It remains a peaceful haven
Underwhelming religious site. Take a guide to save the hassle of parking. Enjoy a meal at one of the roof top restaurants. Say hello to the two midget monks inside the large prayer wheel structure

Must must must!!!!. Few words I can say about this historic place are best,best,best. You should visit must if you are inside the valley. Much more clean,helpful people,historic elements, good eating places around, live view .... Too much relaxation.

Still worthy. Major earthquake repairs happening by a team of volunteers...the beautiful Seeing Eyes are gone and the compete some is being reconstructed.This is still worth going to as the Buddha devotees are still perambulating around the Pagoda..heaps of shops and cafes.

Really interesting place. The area was really cool, and we were entranced by the local people. Even though there were a lot of shops in the area, you could see that it still had great meaning for the locals. Also, we saw some fascinating painting shops in the area, and we even had the chance to learn a lot of Buddhism and its beliefs from some of the locals in the area. This was probably our favorite place in Kathmandu.

Spiritually breathtaking!. Beautiful sights at the Boudhanath and it's amazing to see the hive of activity surrounding the stupa. Walking along the roof tops for a fantastic sight of the surrounding shops.

A great place to people watch. This place is very crowded with devout Buddhist coming to worship. It is a wonderful place to sit and watch the people. Also, surrounding the stupa are tons of shops selling all kinds of tourist trinkets.

Still a site despite earthquake damage. We still had to visit even though the main part of the Stupa broke during the earthquake. Interesting to see how they're rebuilding it. Still lovely to see all the prayer wheels and religious activities, including the great temple on site too. Nice rooftop restaurants overlooking the whole area and touristy shops to keep you entertained too.
Under reconstruction . The stupa is under reconstruction therefore you miss the all-seeing-eyes :( However the entire square got a certain atmosphere and it's definitely worth a visit.

Interesting but you only need half an hour. Sadly I think this was damaged in the earthquakes. It is interesting but a bit over rated.... I wouldn't go there to just see that I would opt to do it only as part of a city tour...

Under reconstruction . As the largest Stupa in Asia this is still worth a visit, although covered in scaffolding you can still see just how immense this stupa is. The surrounding shops are busy and add to the atmosphere. Looking at progress I would expect the Stupa to be fully repaired by the end of 2016.

Can be avoided till renovation is complete unless there is a religious significance for visitor . Under renovation after severe earthquake damage. This is as on 23rd May, 2016. About 8 kms and around 500 NRS taxi fare from Thamel. Can book a return fare and come back by same cab for a better price
Great tour great shopping good eats. It's all in this area Excellent displays of hand crafted art and Buddhist culture A must see for travelers

Stupa . Spend the afternoon learning about the history of this beautiful place! You won't be disappointed!
Enjoy some lunch on the many rooftop restaurants

Traditional and cultural place. This aslo known as the holly place of Buddhist.It is also known as the heart of kathmandu.This should visited by all foreign people who are come in the aim of visiting nepal.Many prayer come to pry lord bouddha
Rebuilding. Good ambiance given the noise of the surrounding area. Interesting to watch them rebuild after the earthquake. Try a rooftop bar or restaurant overlooking the Stupa.

Such a sacred place - go early for the locals prayer time. What an amazing experience. We saw the locals prayer time, 4 different temples, and the most special part - I received a blessing from a monk that looked to be 90+ years old. He reached out and pulled my forehead to his - I felt him touch my soul.
Busy Place. Lots of people busy with their their religious practices. Mixture of Buddhist and Hindu worshippers. Spent about an hour and felt that was enough.
Ramesh Gupta. Nice place to visit. Peace in mind when you get there. Since lord Buddha always preached non violence I would like to see the people of Nepal follow his path rightfully.

In the busy city, it is a peaceful and tranquil escape. The square is so peaceful with no hassle or beggars. all shopkeepers are friendly and let you walk by without forcing you in their shop and the restaurants are very well maintained. there are many monks and townsfolk walking (clockwise) around the temple praying and chanting as well as prayer candles being lit, giving the whole square a lovely scent in the air.It is free but some people may try to charge you entry... just go round and find another entrance.
Under construction. Nothing to see - under renovation- can be skipped until Renovation over- spend somewhere else- may take few months
Amazing Buddhist Stupa. Visited Boudhanath two days in a row. Got some great pictures and even had tea with a head monk while watching people circumambulate the stupa. Quite a special place.

Go and circumambulate!. Totally worth going and if you can go early in the morning. You will see all the people coming To circumambulate around the stupa. Don't forget to stop in the various monasteries around the stupa. If you are interested in traditional Tibetan medicine there is a doctor on the square and lots of art as well as other things. Make sure to go down side streets!!!

Already being rebuilt after the quake. This Stupa was badly damaged after the 2015 quake. They have done a great job posting before & after images so you can see the progress. Lots of fascinating temples also surround this Stupa. Go up to a roof top restaurant and enjoy an epic view of the Stupa with the Himalayas as a backdrop!

Feel the burn. Make the climb.. Over 200 steps to the top, this temple has more to offer than you can ever imagine when someone describes it as "The Monkey Temple". If you are a photographer, prepare for a visual explosion. No matter where you turn your lens, it's beautiful. The statues, the temples, the colors, the people, and of course, the monkeys. Make sure you descend a different way than you climbed up. On the opposite side of the temple, there are more sites and attractions. Of course there are souvenir sellers, beggars and thieves in the form of tiny, hairy primates... but that's all part of the adventure. This place is very holy and wholly memorable.
Good for evening visit. Its best to visit in the evening after the people light the candle. The ambience is perfect for night photography

restoration going on. We visited this place end March and when we entered we saw only the lower part of the Boudhanth, the upper part was taken off because of the damage done by the earthquake in 2015. No problem with that, although a bit a disappointing view. Unfortunately there was no indication or explanation to guide visitors, so we could only walk around the Boudhanath.

The reconstruction and renovation of the Stupa has recently started after it was badly damaged by the earthquake of Apri. The Stupa sees a crowd of Buddhist monks and followers chanting slogans while circumambulating it during early morning and evening every day.

Worth a visit . Really worth a visit, on a clear morning views of Kathmandu would be very good.
The stupa itself is impressive in size and quality
tibet in nepal. The largest tibetan community outside of tibet. Peace and serenity permeate the air. You cant miss this.

beauty under construction. this is really a beautiful and holy place to visit. me and my friends visited this place in april 2016, and i was still under reconstruction in view of the damage tat caused by the earthquake that happened in 2015. we were unable to enjoy the beauty of it perfectly in view of that, yet..its still a beatyful place to visit. there are still buddist temple around it which we can ask bleesing from and they are equally beautiful and small small shops around this areas.during our visit to this place,it was an aniverssary 1 year after the terrible earthquake, and we witness some beautiful heated foreigners that was helping with the rebuilding of the stupa.

Beautiful sacred Buddhist stupa. With the Nepali government repairing the steeple due to a crack in it from the 2015 earthquake, it's a little difficult to see the full beauty of the place, but still well worth the visit, especially around 5pm in the evening when the locals come to pray. Lots of lovely local shops and galleries around the area too. The area needs the tourist dollar.
fun . it is great and nice beautiful . I am really enjoy I have some friends who love this place we suggest to visit there.
Being rebuilt. Very interesting site but has sufered badly from the earlier earthquakes. Rebuilding was well underway.

they hit you at the gate if you look foreign. find a different way to walk in than the main gate, they hit you up for a ticket if you don't look local. I don't mind so much, but it's arbitrary, and unlike other attractions, this one isn't worth paying for. Cool to see, but essentially it's ringed with Thamel.
Nice and good . Good and nice memory about baudhanathstupa centre location largest setups shaping centre aroused like Tibetan
Stupa. I am a true lover of temples and architectures and this definitely is the icing to the cake! It is absolutely breath taking and worth seeing!

Under repair. The Stupa has been badly damaged by the earthquake. Luckily I see some commitment to rebuild it unlike the Kathmandu Dubar Square. Unless you're interested in the tourist souvenir shops or coffee houses that surround the area, it's not worth your time.
Tourist . Nice place to visit. You can walk around the temple and there are many places to sit on top of a roof and enjoy a meal and the view of the temple.

Circumambulation of 108 rounds. It was a rare experience as the Boudhanath stupa is almost crowded daily with buddhists & tourists especially in the early mornings and evenings when the weather is cool. I did circumambulation of 108 rounds on 1st & 2nd May 2016 and would come back to visit the stupa complex again next year in Oct'17. The Boudhanath stupa is still under repair but was told by locals the repair work will be done by end Nov'16. Managed to raise Lungta ( colorful prayer flags which represent peace, compassion, strength & wisdom ) around the scaffoldings on the 2nd level of the stupa.Would love to come back and view the beautiful scenery of the completed stupa again next year.
Earthquake damage. At the time I visited this place, the upper dome was damaged due to earthquake. I see no point in paying the amount they charge for the ticket to see nothing more than walls.
Peter . Still magical as ever even after the earthquakes . A place to spend time rather than just doing a drive by to collect the photograph
Good. One of the largest stupa call boudha stupa that stupa have very old histry i dant no all but i like this palace

Still Earthquake Damage to the Stupa. The stupa itself sustained damage during the earthquake a year ago and is covered in scaffolding. The surrounding complex is filled with artisan shops selling everything from singing bowls, beads and Buddhist artwork. We toured the art school and visited the temples to hear the monks singing their mantras. Very colorful square.

Stupa appears to be very old but under repair.. The Stupa is under repair, situated on a busy road. To go in you have to buy a ticket. Although there is nothing much to see , Some part of this was damaged in last years Earthquake. A place to know the history of Buddhism.

Still worth a visit. I love this place. There is a small entrance charge to the area. There is significant earthquake damage, the tall bit with the eyes has come down, Tibetan flags have replaced all the prayer flags for now, and men are working hard to reconstruct it. The shopkeepers need our custom more than ever. They are friendly, nowhere near as pushy as India.

Beautiful - but sad to see in its current state. When we visited in May 2016, the Boudha Stupa was covered in scaffolding and was in the process of being rebuilt after the 2015 earthquake. You could sense what an impressive building it is, but it was sad to see it in its current state of ruin. There are many good terrace restaurants surrounding the plaza that offer excellent views of the Stupa and are a great place to get some lunch.

Beautiful Stupa but not yet in shape after the earthquake. Beautiful stupa but the top part was missing such it was a bit sad to see all the destroyed bits. Still the atmosphere is nice and we enjoyed this short stay there..

Good place for a walk!. When I was there it was under construction after the earthquake, but we were walking aroung and buing some gifts from local shops! Also there a lot of cafe on the rooftops with a nice view on stupa!

Under renovation but still an eventful place. Was being renovated the last time I visited. Nice place and love the cafes here for organic coffee and do try the ethnic food "laughing" if you can handle spices...
Nice. Nice place to visit. Nepal is a beautifull country in such place this boudhanath stupa was good i like this place.

Peaceful . Surrounded by busy tourist shops, surprisingly peaceful as you walk clockwise amongst monks, the religious and tourists. Sadly a lot id earthquake damage but is being rebuilt. Visit at night if possible to see the many candles. No hassle whatsoever as solo female

Not impressed. Nothing much to see due to earthquake damage and restoration.
Charging 250.00rh was a bit steep but paid happily to help restore the monument
Very sad to see poverty everywhere

Being restored. Bodnath is still under construction after the earthquake, but still worth a visit. The square around the huge Stupa is very scenic and atmospheric. That's worth a visit by itself. We hope the restorations will be completed soon.

Boudhanath. After seeing this magnificent Stupa 3 years ago when we visited to just recently it was so very sad to see the damage that was done by the earthquakes. Such a huge monument a must see to actual soak in how big it real is. Restoration has began and it will be back to its former glory sooner than later.
Excellent. very nice place & sacred destination. This is the largest stupa in Nepal and the holiest Tibetan Buddhist temple.
Dreams Come True. As a child I always wanted to visit this place. It was nothing short of stunning seeing all of the people making their trek around. The colors are vibrant!
Beautiful site even when damaged. First visited before the earthquake but even now it still has a peaceful majesty. It will be restored so a visit now is unique.

Doesn't feel the history. I don't blame the earthquake damages. The top part is gone, and massive rebuild is being done. The worst is the cheesy new paint(not related to earthquake) jobs on the building and most of those stucco "sculptures". Nothing seem authentic and historical. There are monks among tourist, all dressed in shiny, well ironed and new costume, many of them talking on mobiles. Everything feels staged.If you are not interested in shopping, one round of the stupa can be done in less than 20 min-including photography, selfies. Luckily entry fee is relatively low at R250.

Great view of Kathmandu city from the top. This temple is unique. It has Hindu and Buddhist nuances in one place. You have to go through climbing stairs to reach the temple. Inside the temple, you'll find attractive shops and restaurants, along with those people coming for praying rituals. Nice view of Kathmandu city from above.

Still under construction. I will have to visit again next year as this stupa is currently still under construction. Currently it doesn't look magnificent due to construction work and the were significant amount of dust around that area. The shops were nice to browse but many are selling overprice stuff.
Boudhanath . Nice place to visit. It is damaged due to the earthquake making it less exciting than before. Luckily there are plenty of small shops and cafes surrounding it. Good place to relax

Before the earthquake this was absolutely stunning. I hope that it is still standing today as it was one of my favorite parts of my trip to Nepal and where I got to feel the spirituality of the people! Make sure to visit the temple next door so you can see the stupa from the second and third floors

Surroundings better than main stupa. The main stupa really is just big, otherwise aesthetically doesn't offer anything special. But take the time to fully explore the temples and prayer rooms surrounding it, and you'll see some really nice stuff.
Rebuild Phase. A big attraction but unfortunately being rebuilt and is quite ugly at the moment. Give it time to fix itself up and then I'm sure it'll be back to its former glory.

Interestng cultural place in Kathmandu. This place is a very interesting cultural place. Many peoples (in general - local) goes here for to pray. Around you can see a lot of monkeys which feeling yourself as the owners of this place.Also the way to this place not so easy.
Walk Clockwise!. Good to see very active reparation of the earthquake damaged stupa. Fascinating edifice, with prayer circles in a room.
Ok temple. I was disappointed as the temple is under construction because of the earthquake and I couldn't see much of it. I still enjoyed the little shops all around.

Serene place damaged in earth quake. Very serene place
Highly damaged in earthquake but the renovation work is going on.Beautiful campus with lots of shops and cafe.

A must see. A must see if Kathmandu, this is little Tibet. The most important Boudhist temple in Kathmandu. One of 4 most important ones in the world. Go in the evening where there are less tourists and more " real" Bhudists people and monks going around the Stupa. Make sure you go clock wise.

Under reconstruction. This is the biggest Buddhist stupa in Asia and the Dalai Lama is assisting with the financing of the reconstruction of the top part, as well as many local people. Definitely worth a visit.

Refreshing. its a great historic monument...refreshing place during morning time and there are lots of coffee station around it where everyone can enjoy better morning coffee with beautiful scene of stupa and peaceful zone...

Earthquake damaged. Sadly the top is now missing following the earthquake but they are doing what they can to repair it.
Lots of prayer wheels to spin. Lots of tourist shops, a few touts - worth visiting. Entry is 250 Rupees.

A sacred place to visit. Due to damage from the earthquake a year ago there is repair work going on. However, for me it did not take away the feeling of peace this place holds. I loved walking around the Stupa spinning the prayer wheels, spending time in prayer and meditation. It was free to enter, and if you are one who likes to give money to monks in prayer etc I recommend taking several small sized rupee notes.
A must visit at Kathmandu. If believe in Buddhism, this is its Makkah. Other vise, it is a marvelous tourist spot in Kathmandu.

Under repair . It's hard to give a fair rating while the damage from the earthquake is still being addressed. Certainly it's a fascinating spot and well worth visiting, especially if you take a well earned rest at one of the upper level cafes. If you get a chance, look for historical photos from the mid 20th century. It's unbelievable to see how much it has developed since then!
Stature. lots of visitors from Sri Lankan devotees, and India, Burma, bangladesh also i have seen this place always bc

Amazing Historic Monument!!. Amazing!! This historic Stupa is so big and give you peace in your mind and soul. Nepal is such a lovely country with very very honest and lovely people. Please help Nepal by visiting Nepal.

Very Moving and Humbling Experience. Don't skip this place if you come to Kathmandu. Walking around the stupa and listening to monks chant was very peaceful and calming. Glad to be able to see this place before the earthquake.

A highlight of Kathmandu - currently making repairs to the structure. Still one of the highlights of a visit to Kathmandu, this holy place is an incredible structure surrounded by a round courtyard of shops, restaurants, tea houses, etc. It was encouraging to see the dedicated repair work underway and it didn't diminish the impact of seeing the site. Plan to spend an hour or two slowly walking clockwise around the site. Plenty of shopping, and nice to head up to a rooftop cafe on a nice day for some tea and people watching.
Give support although under restoration. Sad to see it being affected by the earthquake and still under restoration. But I went to support the businesses around it.

Stunning even under repairs. Nice square, a town within the town, good to see repairs occurring, had a good laugh at the "no drone allowed" sign. Beautiful buildings and small monasteries all around stupa.
Beautiful!. Such a beautiful place, good vibration and energy. If you are looking for at place where you can open your mind this is one of the places.

Was destroyed by the quake. It would have been an AMAZING structure I am sure. Unfortunately it wasn't there when I visited and there is no one to be blamed. I could only imagine the pain they go through to rebuild such a monument.

Boudhanath. A place to observe silence. Shop beads and have great food. There are many shops around the stupa, singing bowl shop and many beads shop. Its amazing to see people walking around the stupa.
Large Stupa. Great attraction. Many local shops surrounding it along with other local attractions. It was being repaired due to the earthquake when we were there.

In construction as at May 2016. With all due respect to Nepal for their suffering from the earthquake in 2015, the fact is this temple is in construction and inaccessible as at May 2016 and hence you wont see much except the buildings outside the stupa (souvenir shops, some prayer bells and donation boxes). Having said that, ticket fee is still applicable which is a bit strange to me. You are welcomed to donate but dont expect a fieste to the eyesIf you want to go anyway, its 1.5km eastward from the Pashupatinath. Avoid ticket: The main entrance has a big wood gateway you must walk through. The ticket office is right inside. However, just 50 M to the east (after the Yak restaurant) there are two smaller alleys lined by shops, leading into the temple plaza. Just walk in those alleys instead.Have heard that its nice in late afternoon or evening of a full moon when the temple is lit up

Work in progress !. Bouddha is one of my most favourite places to visit when in Nepal. I love the atmosphere, the candles, prayer wheels and everything about it. This year it is under extensive renovations and I can't wait to see it when it is finished. An average rating only because of the work taking place at present. You still have to pay 250Rs to get in which I don't object to and pleased that they have not taken advantage and raised the entrance fee.It is worth going in the late afternoon, evening time do that you can see all the candles and have a meal in one of the rooftop view restaurants and look down and watch the world go by.A nice peaceful way to pass the afternoon and I would recommend a visit.
Authentic Site. However Kathmandu is heavily destroyed by the earthquaqe this site remained relatively nice shape. Awesome.

Being restored. Another area you will need to pay to visit, and money goes towards restoration after the quake of 2015, which is currently happening. Its in a huge courtyard like area, with many shops etc also around it.

A world heritage site worth the visit. No trip to Kathmandu is complete until you visit Boudhanath. I like to go in the late afternoon, so I can join the people, the nuns and monks in their daily round of prayer and contemplation. The Stupa was badly damaged by the 24th April 2015 Earthquake. Unlike some of the other World Heritage sites in Kathmandu, where little reconstruction has commenced, the Tibetan community and Tibetan Monasteries around Boudha, have not waited for the usual Government inactivity and apathy and have taken control of the situation and started extensive repairs. It was heartbreaking to see the damage, but very heartening to see real progress being made to get this important Buddhist shrine back to a state befitting its international status. I was also very impressed that the Committee/community have not taken advantage of the Earthquake by increasing prices for tourists, so this site had more visitors than some of the other World Heritage sites. This makes Boudha a good value visit (Rs 250) unlike Durbar Sq or Pahsupatinath where tourists are charged Rs1000. The area around Boudha is well served with roof top restaurants, so I love to go and sit on one of these terraces and have dinner and see the Stupa lit up in the early evening, by hundreds of butter lamps. Until the repairs are completed, we are a little way off seeing this beautiful sight, but Boudhanath is getting there and upgrading all the facilities at the same time.
Chaotic and peaceful at the same time. It's unfortunate the top of the stupa collapsed during the earthquake. It's a great place to observe both Nepali and Tibetan Buddhist life.
a memory . I been in baudhanath I like this palace stupa was nice and historical nice tibeten saping center around stupaso must visited

Earthquake repairs underway. I saw Boudhanath 12 years ago, and it was spectacular in it's full form! As of today, the top has been removed to be fixed following last year's earthquake. It's still a nice place to visit, there are many shops restaurants and other temples in the area.
Highlight in Kathmandu. A must for all visitors of Kathmandu.Most impressive not only forBuddhists.I hope re-construction after the earthquake will befinished soon.

Hidden damage. I visited Bodnath just after the earthquake last year. It was one of the few sites open in Kathmandu. Sadly, it appears that the crack we could see near the top was more serious than we thought because they have taken the top off the stupa and are rebuilding it. It's a fascinating place and worth a visit even now as the surrounding buildings are interesting - as well as providing retail opportunities.

Destroyed but still interesting. It costs 250 rupees to enter the square, but I think you may be able to walk in by the back entrance without paying. Or even just walk past the main booth pretending not to notice. I don't think they'd stop you. They are asking you to pay for nothing at the moment, as it was destroyed by the earthquake. The square is beautiful for a walk around though. The site before must have been beautiful, but unfortunately it is just a white dome now, they are re-building the top now. So no prayer flags.

Meditate on this. I've been to Nepal at least twice a year since 2010 and each time I've made a point of going to Boudhanath for an afternoon at some point in my travels. The 2015 earthquakes left the main Stupa and several of the smaller ones in a terrible state and some efforts to rebuilding were begun in late 2015 and early 2016. The Buddhist faithful still come in throngs and the square is still quite crowded - especially on auspicious days. I'd have to say that it's still worth the time and effort to go.Getting there is not all that hard, depending on where you're coming from. And, of you're like most visitors you're likely staying in and or around Thamel. You can certainly walk - I have on manny occasions and you can meander though streets until you make your way there - something I highly recommend - do bring a camera. Easiest thing, of you're not up to the walk is to take a taxi. Now, recent events have forced the prices of taxis up, what with fuel shortages etc. That particular crisis is over, but I suspect that the price of taxis is still a little high. It used to cost about 500 Rs (about 5$). That's somewhat negotiable - as it always has been. With recent events it should cost you no more than 800 Rs - my advice - negotiate - start at 500 Rs - and them dicker. Once you get there it can be a bit of an experience getting in - there are several gates, most often people arrive at the main gate. There's a fee for entering; the money goes to restoration and maintenance of the site. Foreign visitors pay more - get used to that - you can afford it anyhow. The square is lined with shops selling all of the same, somewhat tired, tourist goods - caveat emptor - as always. There are numerous restaurants that line the square, most offer rooftop views. Take one or more in as a way to get a better view of the stupa. Take your time. Be observant. Be polite. Enjoy the experience.

Incredible experience!. Really one of the best places to see in KTM; Lots of sadhus wandering around to take photos with, experience one of the world's biggest stupas and the hustle and bustle of people going about their daily routines. There are a few restaurants in the square but nothing notable. Nice ambiance and photo ops, hundreds of pigeons, tourists from every country around the world, all in all a kaleidoscope of experiences and colours.
Excellent. This is an amazing place to visit. This is the biggest stupa in the world and it is so good when you go there in the evening time.

Sadly ruined. Sort of far from the end of the city and I think 250 rupees to get in. Unfortunately besides the white base of the stupa the rest is destroyed. It is being reconstructed. In regards to the once beautiful stupa there is nothing to see unfortunately. Around it there are lots of interesting looking tourist shops but that is about it. I made a journey from Thamel to here and was very saddened and disappointed.

Massive structure. . We visited a year after the earthquake and the top part of the structure is unfinished. It was still worth visiting as the monastery is functioning and tourists are welcome. The surrounding shops are worth a glance and the tanker art school was great to visit.
VISIT BOUDHANATH!. Boudhanath is a stupa, largely popular for Buddhist and Hindus devotees. This stupa is listed as one of the World Heritage Site by UNESCO. People are relaxed here.

Cultural Boudha. I visited 3 temples in Kat (ana also iconic Durbur Square) and this was probably my favourite. You walk around it in a clockwise direction and the whole place is surrounded by interestings shops that sell all kinds of fascinating items. We walked around it twice with ease without banging into everyone on a hot sunny April day.

Calm Buddha. This is an incredible place. Not crowdy most of the time and days of the year as it is traditionally run by Tibetan Buddhists. The restaurants around the Stupa but inside the main area have good scenic view of the Stupa and the mountains near the valley. There are many places around the main Stupa. Unfortunately the top of the main Stupa was damaged by 25th April 2015 Earthquake. The reconstruction work is ongoing. It is open for tourists and prayers.
worth a visit. am not much into arts...its a sprawling circle basically n the streets adjacent look nice..was way hot

So many things to see and do around Boudha Stupa. The spire of the Boudha Stupa may be under repair but there is so much to see and do around the Stupa. All the shops are open, there are great cafes and restaurants and you can watch the world go by from a coffee shop or anywhere around the stupa kora (walk). And you may be lucky as I was to see a magnificent prayer ceremony (puja) at the base of the stupa where you can see ancient traditions such as the Newari priests performing a prayer ceremony (Tara puja) for world peace. The whole area is a fascinating world in itself and shows the resilience of the local Nepali people how life continues on each day a year after the quakes. One of the very special places in Kathmandu to visit and can easily take a full day when you also visit the surrounding monasteries.

What a great place for Buddhist.great work of ancestors.. Bouddhanath is a place where we can see Buddhist designs .it's really beautiful for historical art designs. It's also known as the "mahabaudhha"it means great Buddha.

Being rebuilt but still impressive. The Boudhanath was badly damaged by last year's earthquake but is still worth visiting to support its redevelopment. Plenty of little cafes and restaurants around the square with excellent views.
Ancient Stupa and childhood memories. This used to be on the way to our school and no matter how many times we were there, it always appeared grand, mysterious and beautiful.

Being rebuilt. The earthquake in April 2015 destroyed this Stupa, but the people work hard to rebuild it. Take the time to walk around and enjoy the view, visit the shops, temples and markets. The people are welcoming and make this part of Nepal a delightful place to visit.

Calming & enlightened. The whole area around the Stupa is busy but very peaceful. It was sad to see the damage caused by the earthquake of 2015 but it was encouraging to see the reconstruction of the Stupa taking place. Definitely worth the visit.

Earthquake damage. The stupa has been significantly damaged by the earthquake in 2015. As a result only the dome is intact and work is being done on the top. This affected our visit a little as there are a lot of workmen around, it is not possible to walk closer to the stupa and there were no prayer flags etc. Worth a short visit maybe but I was a little underwhelmed.

Damaged yet worth the visit. Like many attractions this place was also damaged by the earthquake and so the top part of the stupa was not there. Nevertheless, the place stupa is so big and and was surrounded by a Buddhist temple,which had big golden idols inside, and lots of shops. Circling around the stupa and rotating the prayer wheels gave me some inner joy. It had one big prayer wheel inside and another one in the temple outside.Went via travel agency.
A favorite place. Walking around the stupha is so nice, explore the lanes around the back and visit the Chechen monastery and sit and have tea in the monastery guest house garden,

Great souvenir shops . The top of the temple were destroyed in the earthquake in 2015. But I still think it is worth a while to visit. Lots of Buddhist come here to pray morning and late afternoon. Very interesting to watch. There are also great souvenir shops around the temple.

Stunning…yet sad…. This iconic sight was damaged in the earthquake of April 2015. It was sad to see the destruction but we got to witness the repairs taking place and that made us happy to be there and support this beautiful country and its World Heritage Sites.
Bigger than I thought!!. Fabulous place to come experience culture, eat great dal bhat and shop. Wish I had more time to spend here. A must for those coming to Nepal
So sad. This visit was incredibly sad and devastating. The earthquake has had a terrible pact on the stupa and half of it is now gone. As a result the stupa is quite an unfortunate sight to behold.

Blessed on my Final Day. . On my last day in Nepal, following a two week stay, I took a city tour of Kathmandu. It truly is the city of temples, most of which are Hindu. But this Buddhist Stupa, the second largest in the world, was the centerpiece of my day. A set of shops, restaurants and a large monastery surround the Stupa. Our tour group had a brief lunch there and then I and a young Irish couple went to visit the monastery. As was often the case when I visited such places, I was overwhelmed by the artwork. But this time, as I stared at the brightly colored statues, paintings, and prayer flags, I was approached by a young monk who offered me incense, encouraged me to pray, and then delivered me to the Lama for a blessing. And in a real sense, this experience summarized my whole trip to Nepal. I felt welcomed, appreciated, and blessed by all my encounters with people in this wonderful country. Is this really a review of the Boudhanath? Perhaps not. But some experiences cannot be well conveyed by pictures or written descriptions. And in reflecting on this stop in my tour, I want to return to Nepal more than ever.
Mostly a shopping venue. The stupa here was heavily damaged in the earthquake and repairs are under way. Now the major attraction are the shops surrounding the stupa.

Circumambulating for 3 times make you feel great!. Whenever I stay close to the Boudhanath stupa, I can't stop visiting there & circumambulating for 3 times as it makes me feel awesome! Now, it is under renovation as it was partially damaged. Believe it will be all done in few months.

Boudhanath (Stupa) Famous Landmark. Covered with the prayer flags this Temple is a must see. It is round and sits inside a loop of small shops. The top of the building is flat and you are able to see the walkway that runs in front of the shops as well as an area that is behind a wall inside where you look down over people doing prayers and monks walking around doing their chores. If you go be sure to go on top of the Temple to see the private actions behind the wall. Very interesting.

Spiritual and commercial . We came here early in the morning, in time to see the locals all make their way clockwise around the Stuppa. It was a very powerful experience and I would definitely recommend coming here when the locals come to pray. Don't be shy about spinning the prayer wheels yourself, it's fun to join in! Just be sure you respect the locals and give them space to pray and worship. There are a few nooks and crannies you can actually walk inside, where you will find prayer wheels as big as a person. Sadly, a year after the earthquake, the stuppa itself has not been rebuilt and all that's left if the dome. Construction is underway but is going very slowly. Instead, make your way to the many monasteries surrounding the area. Take off your shoes and make a small donation as you walk in. Some monks speak English and are happy to answer any questions you have about Buddhism and the prayer space, which are covered in the most glorious tapestries I have ever seen. Pictures are allowed, but not during prayer time. Around the stuppa itself there are hundreds of little shops selling anything from prayer beads to mandala art. It almost contradicts the very nature of the Holy space, but it all seems to mesh together very well. Definitely worth a visit even though the stuppa is broken.

Damaged, don't pay to get in.. Sneak in with the locals. We walked in circles, then went home. Considering the location of this temple far from Thamel, I don't recommend it. We definitely won't pay to get in.
Best sunset spot in Kathmandu. Spend from 2pm till after sunset sipping tea in rooftop restaurants, exploring shrines, and looking at trinkets. Very magical place.

Visit ..Yes.. but, take your time.. I read many of the other reviews. Don't rush this wonderful place. Find a place to sit. Take is easy. Get the feel of the place. It's NOT a quiet garden. There are many people.The Stupa: Yes, it's under construction. That's fine. Go anyway. It's lucky the temple and surrounding buildings even exist given the seriousness of the earthquake. The Buddhist worshipers are not waiting for a complete reconstruction. The bricks are damaged; the spirit of this place is not.The fee: Don't pay the 1,000 ($10 USD) fee to get in. That's silly. There are couple of alleys to get in. Thousands of people are walking in without paying. This is a public square. By avoiding the fee, you are not depriving the common Nepalese of money. There are many shops, little cafe's, people selling hot tea in the morning, people selling everything. So, use your $10 USD inside and the common people will get the money instead of some inefficient gov't agency or the guard's pocket.

Amazing. A must see for anyone visiting Nepal. Get to the stupa in the early afternoon to explore and take in the area and the culture on display, then grab a table at one of the rooftop restaurants for an afternoon meal. On a clear day you will be looking over the stupa over to the Himalaya.

Stunning yet, quaint. This is a very spiritual and beautiful place. From the huge Stupa encircled by prayer wheels and prayer flags, it is a fascinating place to visit. We had a guide who bought tickets and then guided us with very interesting commentary. I chose to enter a Buddhist shrine where monks were chanting and completing daily prayers...it was quite mesmerising. Shops also circle the Stupa where you can barter for souvenirs of the visit. I loved it.
Do not be put off by the damage!. Do not be put off by the damage it sustained, the atmosphere is wonderful, go in the evening when everyone gathers to spin the prayer wheels. Magical!

Buddhist heritage at its finest. This is a must see in Kathmandu. It is an absolutely stunning place to visit. Such rich culture and history to be told. There are multiple local guides on hand who are very nice. Try and barter the price down a bit and they will likely take you to a shop near the end of the tour to show you some things but don't feel like you have to buy anything. Having said all that they were very informative and even the shop had cultural significance as it was a Thangka school. The owner gave me a tour and told me how the paintings were made and this was for no extra costs. They did ask if I wanted to buy any and I firmly but politely declined after which they did not push me further. Overall I learnt a lot about the area and had a lovely time. It is one of 3 main temples in Kathmandu so it is on the list of things to see. The shops in the area do seem a bit more pricey compared to other parts of the city so don't buy at first sight.
Tourist trap. Cool to see but they are reconstructing since the earthquake. Def. a tourist place but worth it for 15 minutes to walk around and have some milk tea.
Sightseeing after earthquake. Still recovery after eartquake, so i just sight seeing and try the bhutan and tibetan dish, buy some souvenir..
Under Repair, No view. This place is under repairs and no entry into the temple, a waste of entrance fee as you are unable to view inside

Still a must see despite construction. Yes, I get it. Everyone has a complaint about the damage due to the earthquake, but it was a big earthquake and it's a large important structure. Look at the pictures of the place from before the earthquake and imagine it as it was years ago and appreciate it along with the surroundings when you get there. This country is in desperate need of funds from tourism after the earthquake. So, don't complain when they ask you for $10 vs the locals being free or paying $2, because if you're reading the reviews about the Stupa on Tripadvisor, then chances are you make roughly 5x or more than what the locals do. Appreciate what you have in this life :)

Worth a visit. It is such a shame there is so much damage, however there is a lot of reconstruction work going on here unlike some of the other sites. You can still see the beauty of the building and there are lots of local people volunteering in the restoration process.
Good memory. We been baudha stupa good heritage palace nice view feel like tibeten invirment so i must recumend also good saping near stupa you found what ever you need like tibiten item

So much damage. I'm only giving it three stars as I have seen it as it was. Without the "spire" it lacks something. Hopefully the repairs after the earthquake damage will soon be complete and restore it to its former glory. Restaurants around give a good view but are overpriced.

Somewhat Disappointed. I stayed at the Hyatt Hotel and was 20 minutes walk from the hotel. To enter the Stupa, foreigners need to pay Rs1000 or $10.00 to enter. Local enter free. The Stupa was damaged by last year's earthquake. Currently the Stupa is being repair. The Stupa is situated near the local markets and monastery. A must place for photographers to take photos of the local people.Please be warned that a lot of beggars and handicapped people asking for money.
Buddhism . You cannot missed it, it is the heart of Buddhism in Katmandu, you can see how they live everyday, their prayers and belives.
sacred site. Happy to see energetic post earthquake reconstruction going strong at this sacred site. Really epitomizes the unique Himalayan cultures/religions of this area
A heady experience. The burning grasses, butter lamps, drumming, mantras, prayer wheels and prostrating pilgrims create an exotic atmosphere, especially during early morning.
Peaceful. The streets around the stupah are peaceful, the whole area is a nice break from the noise and business of the city outside.

So much damage after the earthquake. The stupa is being totally refurbished as the top and many other parts were demolished in the earthquake of April 2015. This is being done mainly by volunteers . The energy is still there although a bit disturbed... I still love the place !

Still under repair. Great spot surrounded by markets and restaurants. A 200 rupee entrance fee per person is required. There are still major repairs to the Stupa happening but still a great place to visit. I recommend a visit to the Thanka studio to see how these magnificent artworks are created.

Nice to see but heavily damaged and reconstructed at the moment. I’m afraid this place lost a lot of its charm after the earthquake, although its reconstructed now it worth a visit, with the entrance fee you support the work and still it’s nice to walk around a few times and sit down and view other doing the rounds.

a big shopping mall, so disappointing. One of the most important temples in Kathmandu turned into a big shopping mall. Very disappointing. In addition, the stupa is being renovated after the earthquake, and "the eyes" are not visible.
Always a fun place to visit. A lot to see and do.. Handicraft of all kinds. People from all over the world. You can walk around on different levels of the stupa.

Only if you must. The place is still undergoing repairs since the earthquake but is open to visitors regardless. The price is a little steep but nothing too bad. It sucks if you're not SAARC but again, not too bad. The property is usually crowded and filled with shops selling all kinds of things you might find all through the tourist areas of Nepal so don't be in a hurry to buy anything. Try the tiny restaurant "Flavour's" for a break from the crowds.

The most interesting visit in KTM . Let it be no surprise that I haven't been fond of kathmandu, but the Boudhanath was a little nice experience. The monkey temple as they call it is located in a hill and overlooks the polluted city. Entrance of 200 rupees per person even though the sign says "we appreciate if you buy a ticket to support bla bla bla" but they force you to buy the ticket.

Good place to visit to know the history of Buddha culture.. Good place to visit to know the history of Buddha culture. We can buy lot of Nepal hand made / products, however you need to bargain to have your best

Stunning tempel. Stunning budhism tempel with an excellent view over Kathmandu valley. If you come to Nepal do not miss out to visit this place. When I went it has been a bit crowded but it still felt comfortable. Great architecture and spiritual approach.

Sadly rennovation is still underway. A beautiful place to visit and enough pictures to depict what it used to be like- extensive renovation is being carried out post earthquake- varied shops/restaurants surround this place.

most beautiful place. this beautiful stupa is just amasing to see. Even its was damage after earthquake, the place is so quiet and still so beautiful. The best moment is to go at the evenning when all people and lots of monks going for make a round around he stupa. With the butter lamp is quite mervellous.
A must see while in Kathmandu. This beautiful stupa was damaged by the earthquake, but still worth visiting. I was able to watch local people making bricks by hand in order to repair the stupa.

so nice and spiritual place. around this stuppa many handycraft shop. for mandala singing bowl .. not so close by walking from Tamel or Praknajol street, for going there you should take taxi or bus( cheap) but take care to the price.. no more than 500 rps go and back.

In the Middle of it All. The stupa is a tourist trap, no doubt about it. But still, it gives one peace to visit this place. The top of the stupa is still being reconstructed (it feel during the earthquake), but folks can still come and visit the temple to find some peace. Lots of shops, restaurants, etc. surround this holy site.
Peaceful and good. Part of the stupa was under reconstruction after the earth quake. We enjoyed rolling the bells. Very calming and made 2 circles. It was crowded when we visited.

Medieval attraction. Looking a little dishevelled as a result of the earthquake, however, restoration work is in progress to return this beautiful structure to its former beauty. Whilst the stupa itself was damaged, the surrounding buildings appear to have suffered little. I was last here in 1990 and the area has not changed....with the occasional Tibetan and also Nepalis circumambulating, clockwise, spinning the prayer wheels and praying as they walk around the base of the stupa. Like steeping back in time.

Beautiful (even with the damage). While the top of this stupa is being rebuilt from the earthquake it is still beautiful. Locals still go there to pray. We ate dinner at the top of a building, it was impressive to see the size from there. It's worth a visit.
Very beautiful . Worth a visit and enjoying a drink in one of the roof restaurant to admire the place. I recommended really. When we were there many locals where there to pray.
Place for inner peace. When you see the stupa, you will feel so peace and cool in you. the place the surroundings and environments attracts you.
Hub of spirituality. If you're visiting Kathmandu - this is a must. Fantastic peaceful vibe. Huge sense of spirituality. Shopping opportunity. Feel blessed when you leave

Watching the volunteers sort and organize sacred soil to be used in reconstruction…. The effort given by the local volunteers was insightful. Watcing the volunteers carefully sift and bag the sacred soil spoke volumes about the rich culture and heritage of the people of Nepa..

Damaged in 2015 Earthquake . The top of the Boudhanath fell off as a result of the earthquake in 2015, but it's still pretty impressive!It's currently being reconstructed and I'm sure will be returned to its former glories!Watch out for hawkers here though, very busy tourist place and they're everywhere!

Beautiful temple. We visited after the earthquake so unfortunately the top golden part was completely destroyed. The area has many restaurants and shops so it is still worth visiting while they are restoring the damage.

Exceptional; don't miss. If you're visiting Kathmandu, this is a priority. Built sometime after 600 AD, it's currently under construction as a result of recent earthquake damage. Surrounded by shops and restaurants, it's a perfect morning or afternoon trip.
Very peaceful surrounded by nice restaurants. There is a great vibe around this area, it's relaxing in a very busy city. There are many roof top restaurants around the Stupa that offer great views.

Awesome but for the construction. Boudhanath is pretty awesome but the construction is all over. It's being rebuilt and will probably be just as beautiful as it once was in no time but until then maybe try another place? There is an awesomely giant prayer wheel that I would highly advise checking out if your in the area.

Magical. So sad to see this place damaged but it is being renovated to its former glory and still the atmosphere of the nepalis going round and around is just electric. I went here around 4pm and the light was great and there lots of people, without being too much.I walked here from Kopan Monastery so approached from the north, I did see on the way out a ticket booth, not sure if I was supposed to pay but I didn't.Don't miss this place

One of the best places in Kathmandu. The busy street at the main entrance is almost like the exact opposite of what happens inside Boudha. For us it was definitely one of our highlights in Kathmandu. A quiet place, with a friendly, calm atmosphere, it shouldn't be missed. There are many nice shops and small restaurants around the stupa, so one can easily spend a whole day there. Make sure to also visit at least some of the surrounding temples. The monks there are extremely friendly, if you show some sincere interest. If you are interested in the spiritual aspect of the place, make sure to be there early in the morning or around 5-6, when you can also join in the mass cora around the stupa. There are also a number of performers usually. Boudhanath is around 30min walking from Pashupatinath, along some small, not touristy, typical-daily-life kind of streets. The two make for a nice day trip. A practical note: around the entrance of Boudha, there are some women with children that will try to trick you to go and buy milk formula for the children. Admittedly, we did get partly tricked the first time around but then they led us into a shop and we realised the woman and person behind the counter are probably working together since the price they asked for the formula was extremely high. Save yourselves some time and don't buy into their talk, despite the fact that the children do look like they need more nutrition....
Cool place. Cute little markets all around the edges, good place to get that holiday snapshot for Facebook profile.

Calm and mystical environment. Once you have entered the gate and leave the noise and pollution of the main road behind all of a sudden you find yourself in a different place. Although full of pilgrims, visitors and tourists, it feels like a calm and mystical environment. The fragrant smoke of burning incense, the monotonous chanting of mantras on the air, hundreds of believers walking around the stupa turning prayer wheels, bells, dogs, pigeons, butter lamps, everything around helps to make you feel peaceful. The top part of the stupa was completely damaged by the earthquake, but reconstruction is underway. Entrance fee for foreigners is 250 Nepali Rupees, but the funds are used for the reconstruction. There are many tea houses and restaurants, often at the rooftops with panoramic views.

Nice place for everyone. The stupa of bodnath is a interesting place, but currently a little bit damage by the earthquake. At the place you can see and watch many people, how there live there religion. The entrance costs a little bit,but it is OK. It is a must have seen place in Kathmandu!

Damaged cause of the quakes !. The stupa is damaged from the top and is under renovation. It needs another year for completion but the walk around it and the market there is decent. So if you got nothing better than this is a good choice.

Boudhanath is a must-visit. Boudhanath was on my to-see list, but I really didn't know what to expect. The entrance fee goes toward reconstruction (it was badly damaged in the 2015 earthquake). Once inside, there's an almost mystical feel of lightness. Versions of the mantra "Om mane padme hum" are played over speakers, and the air is redolent of incense. Join the crowds walking counter-clockwise around the stupa, spinning the prayer wheels. There are lots of shops selling Buddhist and Tibetan goods, and several nice places to eat. Very peaceful, and surprisingly moving.
FABULOUS. My favourite place in Nepal. Peaceful and spiritual. Great place to walk with the locals and/or sit have a tea and enjoy the sights.

Under repair. My favourite monument is under repair right now, following the earthquakes last year. However this has not diminished its interest. Far from it. I spent a few happy hours sitting on a rooftop terrace looking down at the monks supervising the workmen, busily restoring the Stupa to its former glory. For a few months the top was under wraps, but now it is being cleaned, ready to install back at the top of the dome.
Great visit. Definitely worth seeing when visiting Khatmandu........this was part of a day package and extremely cheap

Under construction, but still impressive.. Damaged from the 2015 earthquake, this site is still under construction to repair damages incurred. It is still worth a trip to walk clockwise around the stupa, joining the throngs of monks who are doing the same daily. The ambience is awesome and there are plenty of shops and restaurants to soak up, as well. Really cool.

Peaceful and great spot for people watching. This is a lovely spot to stroll around and stop and have a tea. You walk around clockwise and you can observe many locals spinning the prayer wheels. You can also enter the temple and receive a special blessing with a simple string bracelet. Well worth an afternoon visit.

The Boudhanath stupa. Katmandu, Nepal. A superb towering Stupa surrounded by fluttering multicolored prayer flags, with an unbelievable serenity and peace which will entrance you and stay with you for many years,(despite the tragedy of repeated earth quakes and deaths.) You will treasure this visit after a taste of the serenity which comes with an understanding of the faith that created it.

Great ambiance. Although the temple is damaged badly by the earthquakes, it is still a lovely place to go because of the vibe and all the wonderfull people you can see there, praying around the temple.
Magic atmosphere,especially from 3 or 4 pm.. One of the most sacred Bouddhist site in the world,majectis and peaceful.It is a must for seeing and understanding life in Nepal.

Witnessing history. The stupa is still under reconstruction after the 2015 earthquake. There is so much beauty in the architecture. It felt serene to simply watch people spinning prayer wheels, monks feeding pigeons, dogs with Tika on their forehead chasing each other. It really feels like another world. To be able to see people working on the stupa also felt like we are witnessing a moment of history.

Peaceful though crowdy. The boudhanath stupa is one of the site you ought to see when you are in kathmandu valley.The nearby restaurants and handicraft culture adds more beauty in it. Visit and have a great time here :)
Sad !!!!. The Stupa was damaged badly in the Earthquake. But, now it is under renovation. Usually I go to Nepal twice every year but didn't manage after the earthquake only until March 2016.

Boudha Stupa under Construction. If you know this beautiful place from before earthquake it probably makes you sad in the very first moment to see it like this. But after a few minutes you will be catched from the positive energy of old tibetians and young nepalis carrying stone after stone up on the monument to let buddhas eyes shine again! It is special to see it after earthquake and with your visit you are supporting the reconstruction work.
Beautiful Stupa. Made several circuits of this earthquake damaged holy place in the morning cold. Entire area was swarming with monks and devotees. Extremely uplifting experience. Om Padme Hum.
Trekkers view. Following on from the 2015 earthquakes they are still rebuilding this masterpiece.There's still plenty of things to do or sights to see whilst in this area.

Destroyed by earthquake. Unfortunately the place has been destroyed by the earthquake so it's a construction site for now. Before going there, make sure that the construction has been done otherwise it is not worth going there.

even now after the renovation in place due to the earthquake - it's special. last years earthquake had damaged the holy Stupa and now the renovation is going on. but even without the eyes looking in the four direction and the impressive top one still can feel the special energy of this place
clockwise round boudhanath. lively and interesting place.stupa is being restored after earthquake damage with the help of willing volunteers passing bricks hand to hand.

Under construction, but still worth a visit.. This was my second trip to Nepal, with the first being before the devastating earthquakes. Despite the ongoing re-construction, Boudhnath is as beautiful as ever, and still very much worth a visit!

No spire but still vibrant. Despite the removal of the spire - so no prayer flags adorning the Stupa - itis still a vibrant place to visit. Repair work following the damage caused by the earthaquakes is going ahead with building supplies on the Stupa which is not ideal but it wil not be for long. Monks, nuns and pilgrims still perform kora and puja so it's still a vibrant lively place to visit and observe yet remains a peaceful place for reflection.

In the land of the lotus. A great place for a quick walk around the stupa. Surrounded by shops and restaurants, more touristy then quite religious walk. However, a lot of people around walking with prayer wheel and chanting Buddhist mantras.

Nice atmosphere in Budhanath stupa. It is good to take guide for kathmandu city tour. my guide told me this is very old stupa. any way as i taken to visit from the guide and tour operator i found this is very worthy. very interesting and peaceful place.

Boudhanath Stupa. Boudhanath Stupa (or Bodnath Stupa) is the largest stupa in Nepal and the holiest Tibetan Buddhist temple outside Tibet. It is the center of Tibetan culture in Kathmandu and rich in Buddhist symbolism. The stupa is located in the town of Boudha, on the eastern outskirts of Kathmandu. It is difficult to assign a period to it, as some believe that it was built during the resin of either Shiva Dev or Amshu Verma in 7th century A.D. Bauddhanath attracts the Buddhist pilgrims from all over the world.

Beautiful feel. Just upon entering this holy area you feel at peace. Even thought the 2015 earthquakes destroyed the famous stupa of this temple it is still such and amazing site that has to be visited to be experienced
Amazing stupa. Such a great place. The stupa was under construction when we went but we did the walk around it and visited some of the shops. Such an amazing place!!!

Deep State. I did not visit Boudhanath as a visitor/traveler or a tourist. Was there as a person looking for silence and it was totally worth it. Lines and lines of clay lamps and a beautiful vibe. Loved it.
Under renovation. Visited this place as part of our sightseeing and it was under renovation. Even after long time of earthquake it seems that the government is still sleeping.
Under repair. The stupa was badly damaged in the earthquake, but reconstruction is well under way. Worth a visit to see the whole area
Nice Stupa but still being rebuilt. It was surely a beautiful one before earthquake but now the upper part is being rebuilt. Worth a visit seen a wedding while there :-)

Chanting voices just near crowded city. Just, in middle of crowded city, anyone can find Boudhanath Stupa more pleasant and more beautiful. After earthquake, it is being rebuilt. But, not even one regular person has stopped visiting since. Om pane padme music all over the lanes, beautiful handicrafts shops and lot of people around the world will make your day at Boudhanath stupa, a good one.
amazing. i love this plaace ..this is one of the great and oldest temple of asia .mostly buddhist and hindu love this place for worship and another people love this place for visiting .
Interesting. Don't know if it's still there since the earthquake. Fascinating. Worth visiting. In the heart of kathmandu.

kathmandu large stupa. bodhnath stupa is a signature spot of Kathmandu . The eyes painted on the stupa makes it look more beautiful. It is a must visit site . Many small stupas are made near the large Stupa . whole kathmandu is visible from the top.
Himalayan Buddhist Religious sight. Buddhist arts and cultural heritage as well as popular pilgrimage site.Buddhists monks seems very well practise.

WOW place in Nepal. I had the greatest experiences of my life in Nepal. The long steep stairs uphill the temples and once you reach up there, you are astonished to see the historic sights and shops decorated with all arts and crafts. You also can see almost all Kathmandu valley and monkeys along the path is little of nuisance but overall this is great site for all visitors and locals.

Undergoing renovations, but still a nice attraction. The stupa itself was badly damaged in the earthquake. But intensive renovations and repairs are underway on the stupa, privately funded. . . . Whereas most shrines in the city are in ruins due to lack of funding. All of the shops and restaurants surrounding the stupa are functioning and still one of the cities main attractions. .
Interesting stupa. Boudhanath Stupa is still pretty even though it sustained damage via the earthquake. The area itself is very crowded as is all of Kathmandu.
Being here a kind of Happiness. Its been one of my favorite place in Kathmandu. Very close to another holly hindu temple we walked about 15 min.

Lovely Temple in the middle of a busy area. We visited here spending some time in the shops around the temple. There were lots of people praying and walking around the temple. A lot of the main structure had been damaged by the Earthquakes but still worth a visit.

Whistle stop introduction to budhism.. First place I visited In Nepal the roads to get there were crowded once we paid to get In it was quite quiet I visited a few of the areas were the monks were praying they were happy for me to visit anywhere and turn the prayer wheels I was allowed to visit any of the areas tho you have to remove your shoes. Photography was allowed anywhere I went. There was some building work going on reconstruction from the earthquake.

Down but not out. Despite some damage as a result of the 2015 earthquake, this is still a must-see attraction in Nepal. Watching the rebuilding taking place and the intricate bamboo scaffolding is amazing in itself. There are some lovely stalls/shops surrounding as well.

It is what it is. Have visited recently, unless you really like this sort of thing I wouldn't recommend, bottom line this is a large round temple which you walk around, and that's it at a cost of 250NPR. The tenple is currently under repair following the earthquake, so with hoards of scaffolding everywhere, it isn't as photogenic as it would usually be.There are shops and restaurants all around the perimeter, and are all fine, there isn't the same intense pressure selling you get in say Thamel for example, you are free to look without hassle.A very cultural place to visit, but not a place really to revisit, as once you have seen it you have seen it.

Very serene escape from the dirty, busy city. Don't forget to walk clockwise around the stupa. A must visit is the monastery. The interior is gorgeous with many Buddhist gold statues and large drums. Remember to take off your shoes. The monks are very nice and open the doors for you if you ask. Entry is free. The paintings inside and on the roof are more colorful than the paintings in Chinese temples I've seen in Beijing. The swirly designs and dragons are similar and familiar, but the colors and flowers and outlines are noticeably different, which is interesting. The stupa was unfortunately still under construction from damage from the earthquake. In the two months I've lived here, I have seen considerable strides in repair of the dome and top. If you're Buddhist (or not) it's nice to spin the prayer wheels around the stupa and in the monastery. The giant one in the monastery is very cool. The stores are reasonably priced for a tourist area. It'll be nice when the structure is fixed, since it's unfortunate that it's very dusty and dirty right now. Most of KTM is dirty all the time, but inside this "bubble" it was always clean, free of garbage.

Nepalese History Baudhanath. Baudhanath is one of the history place in Kathmandu culturally Buddhist but we all respect every religion. Big earthquake damage lot of history place one of them is Baudhanath stupa, so government support and private sector too. We would like to request people from different around the world to come Nepal and visit our nature thank you.

Boudha visit. The temple was destructed in most part by the earthquake last year - so unfortunately there isn't much left of it to see. But the area surrounding it isn't too bad for a little bit of sightseeing or shopping.

They are building it up again. The stupa got quite a lot of earthquake damage. But people are doing their best to get it fixed. The atmosphere is great. You get the best view by having lunch at a nearby rooftop restaurant.

Amazing energy. I returned to Bhoudanath after quite a while. There is Currently (march 2016) repair work going on to the main stupa due to damage caused from the earthquake of April 2015 but the place still retains its original energy. There are lots of rooftop restaurants in the area but my favourite is the Road house near to the entrance.

Under Restoration But Still A Gem........ Unfortunately the Boudhanath was under restoration from the earthquake but still a beautiful sight to see. The plaza has several restaurants and shops around and the restoration looks like its progressing at a good pace. Beautiful and Amazing are the words that describe the sight and all the people in Nepal.....

Great holy place . This place was destroyed during the earthquake in 2015 but the energy and the aroma is still here. When I see this stops I almost forget everything, all my pain it just takes all my worries. This century old stupa is worth visiting.

Worth a stop. Even though the stupa was damaged due to the earthquake and they were in the middle of repairing it, visiting this site was will worth it. My husband and I strolled around it as we watch the locals come spin the prayer wheels. There was a lot to take in but it still felt so peaceful. There were benches all around the temple that were so inviting to just sit and enjoy some peaceful moments to meditate or people watch. Lots of little souvenir shops. Really charming. There's an entrance fee for foreigners, expect to pay a higher price now because the fee go towards rebuilding. We were happy to pay and the tickets were stamped on handmade woven paper. We plan to frame them because they are such a beautiful reminder of our stay.
hard to go but worth it. its near pasupatinath , people must visit here . people are nice and food in that area are tasty . worth visit .
Under maintenance!. The stupa is currently under renovation and nothing fancy experienced there. I think have to wait for sometime.
