Amazingly beautiful!!. Having lunch across the street and watching all the volunteers moving one brick at a time to help rebuild this Stupa was amazing! So many people working for one common good was such a great site!
It's just a matter of time before this amazing Stupa is brought back to its glory days!!

A beautiful spiritual experience!. Boudhanath Stupa is a must see if you visit Nepal. We were very lucky to visit this beautiful Stupa on the day of a full moon so there were many visitors there with us. Although this is a Buddhist Stupa, both Buddhist and Hindu followers go to Boudha to spin the prayer wheels, light a butter lamp, visit the monastery or perhaps take part in a celebration to a God or Goddess. Most walk around the Stupa 3 times. The first for the Deities, the second for the people and the third for themselves. Don't miss the history and culture of this incredible Stupa.
Lose yourself arround and get the tibetan flavour!. The stupe is really nice but take the opportunity to walk arround and see the monasteries, rituals, mandalas etc.
Mesmerising. The temple is a must see destination, filled with beautiful buddhist flags, wheels and monks. You will run into many street vendors here.
Go at sunset for the prayers. Post earthquake repairs are still underway but this is a great place to visit especially at sunset when hundreds of monks walk around the stupa.

Under Repair. The Stupa is under repair and appeared to have minimal damage compared with the temples in Durbar Square. There are many temples and shops surrounding the Stupa and gifts can be purchased for very reasonable prices.
beautiful place, where you can feel the budist culture in KTM. beautiful place, where you can feel the budist culture in KTM. nice restaurants around and nice shops, with jewelry, arts and incense.

A very spiritually enlightening place to visit . I loved it here. There was plenty to see and learn about the Buddhist philosophy and was swarming with tourists and locals alike. There are also many shops and restaurants surrounding the stupa

Buddha eye destroyed but still beautiful place to be. Such a lovely place to be - the buildings surrounding the stupa are beautiful and you can still see the magnificence of the place. I loved just sitting up at the rooftop restaurant and see al the volunteers helping to rebuild the stupa while others were still praying and performing their religious rituals.

Much earthquake damage. I didn't get to see this place before the earthquake but I hear it was impressive. We did get a chance to see a lot of restoration underway. There Stupa is surrounded by shops and restaurants catering to tourists.

Must see while in Kathmandu. The stupa and surrounding neighborhood are worth the short trip from the center of Kathmandu. The area draws Tibetan Buddhist pilgrims and refugees and the area around the stupa provide a window into the life and worship of Tibetan Buddhists. Be sure to wander the back streets, stop and have a meal on one of the rooftop restaurants where you can watch pilgrims circumambulate the stupa. Note that the iconic steeple is off the top of the stupa, undergoing repairs after the 2015 earthquake.

busy monks, broken stupa. this was one of the last places we visited in Kathmandu, so i may have been overdosed with stupas by this point in time. however, due to the damage from the 2015 earthquake there isn't much visible to a tourist. it's great that the stupa is undergoing renovation but from a visual perspective there isn't much to see. there are a lot of monks around, given it's their residence, so good photo opportunities, if you are into that. also if you want the exact photo from Lonely Planet 2015 cover, it's here. otherwise, if you didn't have time to visit this place, purely from a visual perspective, you could skip it.

Mesmerising. Best visited early morning or just as sun goes down. In the morning there is lots of activity as the Tibetan locals go about their business before the tourists arrive - there is a local monastery and all the small child monks are often seen around the temple. As the sun goes down the Tibetans, in their national costumes, come out again to walk clockwise around the Stupa, turning prayer wheels as they go. Join them and get swept along in this very calming and traditional ritual. I love this place.

Serene and Peaceful. This is in them middle of Kathmandu City. Though the exteriors are crowded and busy, as soon as you enter the gates of the Stupa, you are transported to a different world. Calm and serene, with good vibes.It has plenty of things to do - shop, eat, cafe inside and a also buddhist temples along with thanka painting.
A must see. It is once of the main attraction, But very sad to see that it is badly damaged in earth quake. Restoration work is still going on

Fascinating glimpse into Buddhist culture - under renovation. Surrounded by what seems like hundreds of shops selling all sorts of souvenirs, this stupa is massive, but being rebuilt after serious damage from the recent earthquake. Still and interesting hour or two. The Golden Eye Restaurant provided a good view of the stupa while we had our lunch.
Must see. Despite the rebuilding that is going on since the earthquake, the stupa is well worth a visit and the surrounding roof cafes offer the best views.

Boudhnath. Was here while i was roaming around KTM solo. One of the famous and attractive stupa ever in KTM where you can actually spend some of your good time. Lots of beggars right there. Please be careful when you go there with the local beggars. Can reach here by public transport. Enjoy

Spectacular and a hive of activity. Awesome spot to observe Kathmandu life. Lots of great shops and restaurants. During certain times, there are Koras (a type of pilgrimage), where the crowds and monks are everywhere. Don't forget to walk clockwise.

Cannot miss this. This was one of the places we visited when we hired a driver and guide for the day. Absolutely loved the place even though repair works is going on. Be careful coming into the stupa, I found this place to have the largest number of beggars (who were not so friendly) street kids and people trying to rip you off hanging around the entry and exit point of the stupa, more than anywhere else in KTM. Tourists are their targets.
Pity that there are major damages. Great Buddhist attraction. The progress of restoration of damages from the April 2015 earthquake is slow. Still worth a visit
Nepal 2016. Magic place with amazing spiritual sensations, you can't miss it for the peace and the relaxing times

Nepal. Nepal is the country of real peace. Full of tourists, yearly visitors are about 30 000 from all over the world. our experience at Stupa was really exciting and cultural, we enjoyed the peaceful life of Nepal
Worth a Visit. Nice atmosphere around the Stupa. Reasonable entrance fee for foreigners, Worth a visit despite the damage done by Earthquake

Very spiritual. The top part of the stupa was damaged in the earthquake, so it's kind of sad, but you can see the rebuilding going on which is interesting. It also has a good feeling about it - the square is filled with Tibetan people and many monks, and there's a good kind of peaceful energy.
superb speactacle. This really is a must see on your trip to Kathmandu. Inspiring site and very moving. the constant wind helps the flags create a real impression.
The falling down top of tower. Hope the top of Stupa build as soon as possible. People can recovery from the pain from the earthquake,
Stupa. Rebuilding of the top of Stupa which was destroyed during the earthquake. Many shops and temples surrounding the Stupa. Have a break on one of the cafe at the top to get a good view.
its was amazing. boudhanath such a nice place for tourist...after earthquake its damage but now the are making...good

Boudhnath Stupa. Boudhnath Stupa is an important place of pilgrimage and meditation for Tibetan Buddhists and local Nepalis and as well as a popular tourist site. It was built in 14th Century. 2015 earthquake has hit this stupa hard which is currently closed for reconstruction however you can view it from outside. Nearby roof top restaurants give a very good view of the stupa. A small entry fee is charged at the entrance. SAARC country residents get discount in entry fee.

Its a type if its own kind. All I can elaborate that it was an excellent moment for me to bring my sprituality. Great place and majesic view in the evening. Devotee chanting and praying... Bit crowed though as it is within the cityYoub

My Favorite Place in Kathmandu!. I first time I entered saw part of the Boudhanath Stupa between down a long narrow street my breath stopped. Something spoke to be from my most inner most depths of my soul. As I approached I heard the soft voices of all the pilgrims walking around the stupa in a clockwise direction - Om mani padme hum - they became louder and louder and i realized I was listening to all the low voices. I felt I was in a very holy place. I moved from Thamel to a guesthouse nearby here and this became my home base in Nepal - my home away from home in Nepal. But I felt at home here. It's a feeling that's hard to describe but when you come here you will feel it. I watched the Tibetans come pray here twice a day and joined in with them. I attended the pujas in the numerous Buddhist monasteries nearby and in the area. I fed the pigeons and the homeless stray dogs with the displaced Tibetans here. I gave donations to the poor. I befriended some of the young pretty women pretending to be milk mothers trying to scam money from the foreigners. I took the street orphans to lunches. I watched the pilgrims do prostrations over and over all the way around Boudhanath - even inthe pouring rain. I befriended my 1st Buddhist monks here too who took me "under their wing" and taught me about mind training, and their practices and rituals and single minded concentration and other things too. It is here that I learned that Buddhism is divided into 3 parts: Buddhist Philosophy, Buddhist Science and Buddhist Religion. I also learned about the healing power of sound. Come to Boudhanath and stay and lose yourself...and then find yourself.

Broken, but still impressive. Even though the stupa broke during the earthquake, it still has a majestic aura, which is enhanced through the way you first see the stupa, when you enter through narrow gateways from the busy streets outside and then the place opens up, and bam, there it is. All around the stupa, tourist shops and cafés flourish, but that doesn't seem to destroy the religious serenity of the place.

Boudhanath is presently under restoration after the earthquake. Since the main Stupa is under restoration, it is covered with scaffolding and hence does not photograph well. Do not shop there though as the shops are ridiculously expensive when compared to other parts of Kathmandu/Nepal.

So so . When I was there, they were still reconstructing after the Earth quake. I prefer Swayambhunath to Boudhanath. Swayam is more relaxing, I can easily find a quiet spot to meditate there. Boudha on the other hand, is too touristy, I didn't find the energy there as high as Swayam. Having said that, there are more shops and restaurants here. There are 3 Tibetan holistic healing clinics within the area, a Thangka painting school, nearby. I would have given 5 star if I'm not comparing it.

Very affected by the earthquake but still worth seeing. The whole top (brick section) of the Stupa was reduced to rubble by the earthquake, so it now looks very different from how it did before. But it's still fascinating to see the size of the Stupa and to hear about what it means (worth hiring a guide to tell you all about it). They are also very busy restoring the Stupa, so hopefully it will be back to usual soon. The Stupa is surrounded by rooftop restaurants and shops, and it is really worth having lunch or a snack on one of the roofs to enjoy the view before/after walking around the Stupa and spinning the prayer wheels. Be aware that at the moment, you can only walk around the periphery of the Stupa, rather than on any of the levels. 250NRS entrance fee to the area for foreigners. And a very busy traffic area with limited parking.

Peaceful yet touristic. Boudhanath Stupa (or Bodnath Stupa) is the largest stupa in Nepal and the holiest Tibetan Buddhist temple outside Tibet. It is the center of Tibetan culture in Kathmandu and rich in Buddhist symbolism. it is a perfect place for chants and incense and where you can relax, have a coffee or food and enjoy the beauty of the Tibetan culture. Perfect place for taking photos, having lunch or dinner and just roaming around.

All around the stupa are shops of different varieties. There are also people selling real money in small denominations, which we later found out are bought by pilgrims to be given to monks. Boudhanath(Stupa). I visited in December 2015. It is damaged by the earthquake.The area around the stupa used to be just green land. Now it is a Tibetan community area there. There are houses all around the stupa, and they are mainly restaurants, hotels, guest houses. Quite commercial, I would say.

Spirituality. Just look at this place from a different angle and the magic is still there. The roofs are just the place to be and from there you check the rebuilding of the stupa budha. Holy site, undergoing earthquake repair. This is a very significant Buddhist site and a very special place. The stupa is surrounded by historical buildings and Buddhist related shops. The locals are not aggressive and anyone with an interest in Buddhism would get a lot out of a visit.

Damaged by earthquake, but great for shopping, eating and watching a sunset!. The stupa was quite close to our hotel and hence, we visited it almost twice or thrice a day. The main draw of this place is the shopping area around it. There is an entry fee for SAARC citizens (less) as well as non-SAARC citizens (more). The stupa's top part (structure above the white dome) has completely collapsed in the earthquake. As such, there is not much to see of the stupa, except the white dome and the prayer wheels around it.The whole stupa area is set up in the form of a circle - the stupa in the centre and shops, restaurants, small bldgs, alleyways around it. There are plenty of souvenur shops selling pashminas, yak wool items, paintings, art, handicraft items, knick-knacks, etc. There are plenty of cafes and restaurants (mainly on the first and second levels on the tiny bldgs) here and this is the main tourist draw of the stupa now. Also explore the alleways leading out of the stupa circle, for some Tibetan style traditional wear, kimonos, local items and tiny local restaurants. We visited this on a Sunday afternoon and there was a live band playing from 3pm till sundown. It added another charm to this area, where we had an early dinner watching the sunset from a terrace restaurant in the stupa area.

Under Renovation. During our visit we could see the work under progress to undo what earthquake had done. We could not enter the Stupa at that time. Being the centre of the attraction expect commercialization and tourist around the place

A lot more commercialized than I expected, but still beautiful. Beautiful stupa that sustained substantial earthquake damage at the time of my visit. I hope they are able to rebuild it to it's former glory. Nontheless, it was well worth the visit to see such a spiritual place with many pilgrims. The area is smaller and more commercialized and touristy than I expected. Definitely find some time to get a meal or tea at one of the rooftop restaurants/cafes to have a great view of the scene below.
Damaged by earthquake. The pictures looked amazing but unfortunately I didn't get to see the Stupa in it's full glory as it has been significantly damaged in the earthquake

The Hub of Kathmandu. Going to Boudhanath gives one an opportunity to be in the mists of those actually practicing Buddhism as they make Koras around the Stupa, usually the traditional 3 rounds, at any time during daylight or towards dusk. All walks of life, tourists, kids with their families, and steer kids, adults, elders. Beggars. Shoppers. Since the Earthquake, someone decided it would be an added attraction to put up digital lights and signs to announce to those who may not be aware that they were at a spiritual site, not only the name, but the fact it is a "World Heritage Site" in big bold banners, which takes away from the spiritual nature and makes it more commercial. That and the sound, music? Hard to classify it. This should not keep tourists from attending, as Nepalies are suffering enough, between affects of earthquake and the illegal embargo on fuel, causing petro prices to soar, and market prices so high, that the average working family can not make due. You will see it all if you are brave enough to look.

Massive stupa. I hv been here a couple of times. Sad that it was affected by the earthquake. The magnificent stupa is a UNESCO World Heritage and undergoing restoration. There are nice little eateries tuck at the corners and rooftop for amazing view.
Famous Landmark. One of the famous landmarks of Kathmandu, take a taxi from Thamel around 300-400 rupees. Worth a visit :)

large stupa. large stupa located in a northeast of the city; some souvenir shops around the stupa.
In recent earthquake it suffered comparatively less damage than other historical structures in Kathmandu.

Great landmark in Kathmandu. One of the greatest landmark in Kathmandu. The view of The stupa and around was really thumbs up.
Highly recommended for travellers and for pilgrims

A classic place. You kind of have to stop here since its one of the most iconic places in the city. The spire of the stupa is being reconstructed but that doesn't take away from the experience. Best time to arrive is late afternoon, sit and enjoy a cup of tea as the sun goes down over the hills.

Beautiful. I've been here multiple times and it's always a great experience. So sad to see the damage from the earthquake. Make sure to visit and support any efforts you can to rebuild this beautiful country.

Biggest stupa. One of the biggest stupa of its kind in the world that situated in the north east of kathmandu. The beautiful places is surrounded by traditional houses n lots people living here are people migrate from Tibet. Interesting things here at evening is regular group of people worship and plenty traditional handcraft gifts are sold around the stupa. Worth visiting the Boudha nath stupa.

Major Earthquake Damage. I am sure prior to the earthquake, this was a beautiful Stupa. Now, the top is badly damage. It is such a shame but they are rebuilding it but I am sure it will take awhile.Entrance is 250 rupees. And it took us less than an hour to walk the circumference of the Stupa. During the time we went, there was a group of Tibetan monks doing prayer service. It was interesting.

Still a Stupa of great beauty. Beautiful Buddhist/Hindu stupa in the heart of Kathmandu. Despite great damage from the earthquake it remains a magnificent place to visit to see the renovations in progress and the great resilience shown during the recovery phase following the earthquake. Worth visiting the exhibit and the monastery while there

Peaceful vibes. The experience here can be a bit noisy and jarring at times but the real ambiance of this place is calming. Sitting in one of the chairs around the stupa circle facing towards the winter sun and just being there, physically and mentally-it is the best feeling ever. Although the main shrine was damaged due to the earthquake this April, the devotees circling the stiupa will never make one feel the absence of it. Totally in love with the vibes of this place!
Daily focal point. We visited this everyday before starting out for the day. It is a great way to experience some daily life of Nepal. There are so many different people gathered here.

Amazing Energy. This is a must visit site when in nepal. Amazing energy and good vibes from this place. Although the earthquake has damaged the stupa, the engery can be felt. Very peaceful and relaxing, worth the visit.

Fascinating Stupa. It is really sad this stupa affected by the earthquake and currently the gvmt is doing the reconstruction on top of the stupa. Overall it is a huge complex and good for Buddhist pilgrims trip..

Largest Spherical Stupa in Nepal. The UNESCO, World Heritage Site Boudhanath Stupa is known to be Khasti in Nepal Bhasa or Bouddha by speakers of Nepali.The Stupa's massive giant mandala makes it one of the largest spherical stupa of Nepal. Along with Swoyambhu Nath, it is one of the most popular touristic site of Kathmandu area. Inside there is a relics of Kysap Buddha. Nearby Boudha Nath there are lots of monasteries belongs with different four sects of Buddhism. It is also the holiest Tibetan Buddhist Temple outside the Tibet.

It's much more peaceful than just outside. Boudhanath is a huge stupa in a quiet section off a main Katmandu street and it's much more peaceful than just outside. The stupa was damaged in the earthquake and is currently undergoing restoration - you can't walk on it like before and the decoration on the stupa has not yet been replaced. The shops are open and there are people circumambulating the stupa but it's comparatively quiet - versus my visit two years ago - if you discount the masses of pigeons. When I was there, the protective windows for the paintings in the stupa entry were being cleaned and the paintings were open for close observation. No knowing how long until that will happen again.
Buddhist Gems. we had explore the bouddhanath stupa after the devastating earthquake in nepal, amazing place to explore Buddhist monastery in Nepal.
peacefull place. peaceful place for explore. lots of temples and monastery. people are friendly. i did a few hours meditation in the monastery.
It's a nice place to visit in winter. There are shops with great things and kind people. I loved the pigeons there. Like a big crowd over there. But the temple is also beautiful.
A must see. There are many shops and things to see around this area. The stupa was damaged after the earthquake but I belive it has been repaired.

silent and peacefull area, not possible to enter. that's nice area around the Stupa, but you cannot entry inside after earthquike that's still repairing. Lots of shops around, prices are higher. Some restaurants on the top of buildings with a good view. Nice just to visit for a walk and enjoy silent and atmosphere of a closed district.
Damaged in the earthquke. The Stupa was damaged in the earthquake last April , but like the rest of the town there is repair going on . Still a good sightseeing spot

Magiskt. I will say this is the best and most intressting place in Katmadu.
Så calm and so lot of shilling sounds and feelings all over.
Interesting. Cultural experience, nice to see, lots of shops around, a nice walk around. Enjoy your visit here :)

Peaceful and historic.. This ancient Bhuddist stupa is currently being rebuilt after the Nepal earthquakes. It is a must see site for all. The monasteries are interesting. We lit lamps upstairs for personal wishes. Incense and prayer flags available here

Enjoyed best at night. This is a religious site and very lovely later at night without the crowds. There are so many shops around this place it is easy to get distracted for the real reason of this very auspicious site. It is currently under construction due the recent earthquake in may. Just the top of the Stupa was effected. Still lovely to circumambulate around the Stupa.

Must visit this Stupa. Boudhanath is a place where you can experience not only Tibetans doing their circumambulations, turning their prayer wheels and reciting mantras, but many more people.In the neighboring streets you can visit many temples, buy souvenirs in a lot of small shops and enjoy your stay. Just mingle with all the visitors and inhabitants. Due to problems elsewhere in Nepal, there's a shortage of cooking-gas, fuel and kerosine in the whole of Nepal, so it's difficult for people to survive. Therefore especially in this period: go and visit this beautiful place, people deserve it!

Best place to visit in Kathmandu Nepal. This is Buddhist temple but I really like it. It is very nice place for visit tourist . It was near by airport center city nandffxnzjdnensnddjdnensnsndndmdnfnnsns

Boudhanath November 2015. We did the visit after two long international flights before even going to our hotel. perhaps we were too tired to fully appreciate the experience, but it was the only bit of a 16 day tour that left us feeling a bit underwhelmed. The lid (excuse the term) was knocked off in the earthquake and this doesn't help.In spite of this, if you visit Nepal, you need to experience it.

Earthquake damage. This was one of the temples that we were recommended to visit and unfortunately we were quite disappointed. This temple has been damaged during the earthquake and access to it is limited. There are nice souvenir shops surrounding and it is cheaper than some of the other sites. However if you have limited time I would recommend the monkey temple or Pashupatinath instead.

Beautiful even while being restored . Even though the tower has been destroyed, this site is still very much worth visiting. The surrounding markets are buzzing but there is still a tranquility around the site. It gives you a real idea of the local vibe. Try to get up onto a roof of one of the surrounding buildings to get a complete view of the site.
Morning walk. It's nice to see that the repairs have begun. This is one of my favorite places to walk at sunrise in Kathmandu.

Must visit. Boudha stupa is a must visit place for a pilgrimage as well as for the love of the architect and history behind.You will be surprised to see many locals and tourist at any time of the day with chantings and dharma music playing on every corner of the place.Too many handicraft shops and one could just sit and pray or meditate.
Very large. This is the largest (or at least one of the largest) Stupas in Kathmandu. The size alone makes it impressive. However, once one takes in the spectacle, there is not that much more.
MUST go. This is for sure one of the most emblematic temples that you can see in Nepal. For me was an incredible experience and I was impressed on the beauty of the place!

Sadly traumatised by the earthquake. This beautiful building is being rebuilt with love and attention after the earthquake in Nepal. It will soon be an amazing site to behold. Even now, it is still quite something to see and appreciate.
Good visual of the damage the earthquake caused. You can get in for free if you go to one of the restaurants that fronts on the main street and the inner circle :)

A mesmerising place. A visit to the Boudha Stupa is a must for any visit to Kathmandu. Enjoy an afternoon sat in one of the restaurant balconies surrounding the restaurant watching the Nepalese culture unfold below.

unfortunately suffered some damage due to the earthquake. the stupa and the houses around this are a different world from the rest of Kathmandu. the narrow lanes leading out of the circular centre, the 3-5 storied houses/buildings around the stupa and the narrow streets leading out from inbetween the buildings.Bustling with life yet tranquil with great shopping around this.

Amazing structure, now spoilt after the earthquake but worth seeing. The square where the Stupa sits is very busy but try too find a restaurant high up on on the side walkway and enjoy overlooking the Stupa for a while. You cannot go inside but it is impressive, despite the ornamental roof now being removed.

Impressive, even after the dual earthquakes earlier this year.. This is one of THE places to see in Khatmandu. The surrounding area is packed with restaurants and shops. It has a European feel to it. Definitely something to see.

Earthquake made this less amazing unfortunately.. I liked Swayambhunath better. Both as a site and for the people and stores around it. This was much more commercial. This was not a highlight of my trip,

My visit in October. The area is still worthwhile visitng and a better stupa should not take too long to be rebuilt (suffered partial damage in hurricane), construction is ongoing and you have the opportunity to see what is was and how it will be.
Must see place. The ambiance is amazing. Nice place to shop and experience the culture. There some good places to eat too.

Peaceful place for contemplation of the sacred, no matter what is your religion. I suggest you include this visit in your Nepal tour guide.
Besides the temple and its sacred perspective, there´s a lot of stores around this Stupa selling handicraft articles, crystals, clothes, semi-precious jewels, etc with attractive prices.
Huge. Very special atmosphere, nice to do the kora. Very nice also in the evening, with all the lights. Namaste

You have to visit it, is the soul of Kathmandu.. Still if the earthquake distroyed the main stupa of the temple, the soul of budhist people is Still there, and maybe stronger than before.
People met there foremost at the sunrise and the sunset. Sacred music, mantras, nice cafe's and small shops are every where around the stupa... do not forget, you have to walk "clockwise".
Peaceful.... the most peaceful location at Kathmandu representing all the authentic culture of Buddhism.. Nirvana of Nepal,

Beautiful structure. Have similarities and differences with the stupa that you may fins in India, Thailand or Sri Lanka. Shops around the stupa gives a different value may be an under value to the location. Don't go shopping in there. They sell souvenirs if you are interested but obviously for over price. Few Temples and buildings around the stupa has attractive architecture. Inside of some of the art shops you may find artists doing live paintings which is great to see. You have to pay only if you buy these paintings. and the place is full of pilgrims around the world for special times.

Amazing structure. My 2nd visit before and after the earthquake. I consider myself very lucky as i already see the this Boudhanath its original before the earthquake. Its a place must visit. It has a great story and it is incredibly inspring. It was build my a poor mother and was completed by her 4 sons. As they were praying all the buddhas and bodhisattvas absorbed into the stupa. Its so powerful that that ever you wish for is believed to be full filled. There are more stories. For those seeking liberation, one of the spot to go within you.

Boudhanath. A wonderful area and the center if spiritualism with many very famous Gumbas (Napali for monastery) Almost across the street from this area known for very good restaurantes and shopping (actually where the Buddhist monks come to buy their religious items) is the Hotel Tibet International. The hotel is operated by the Tibetan Lama family, who own the largest Tibetan rug factory in Nepal or Tibet, and they have a beautiful showroom in the hotel stocked with a huge variety of very high quality rugs made from Tibetan wool. Worth a trip there.
Shame. It was being rebuilt as the top part above the dome was destroyed in the earthquake. Still worth seeing and the temple to the side

Many restaurants at Boudhanath. At Boudhanath, there are many restaurants such as Nepalese, Chinese,Korean and Italian. So, you can enjoy meals there. But around the Stupa, I think that the prices are a little bit expensive.
I recommend to go to Stupa after evening, so you will have mysterious feeling by the lights of many candles and the sound of Buddhist sutra.
It is on the list of things to see. If you are into Stupas this is for you. Not fully open as a result of earthquake damage. You can walk around it and say you were there.

History.. All heritage sites require an entrance fee- be prepared.
The Stupa has been partially damaged by the 7.8 Richter earthquake in April 2015. It is still being restored but worth a visit anyway.

Good walk up!. We decided to have a look at the Stupa on our travels in Nepal in Pokhara, it was unfortunately being renovated or maintained and you weren't allowed on the temple which was a little disappointing. But that aside it was a good walk up and a great view of the Pokhara city.

Damaged but still amazing. The top of the stupa is currently missing but somehow that doesn't seem to matter, the neighbouring temples as just as interesting (though one just outside he stout area is quite badly damaged) and are the with the great view if he stupa is the only one in the whole of Kathmandu where I've actually felt peaceful enough to meditate, and the monks are happy to let you. There's also some lovely shops that aren't as touristy as Thamel and some really nice cafes. Worth a visit despite the damage.

Vibrant & Beautiful!. An absolutely delightful place to visit. There is a sense of tranquility despite the milling crowd and countless commercial establishments that thrive in this area. Reaching there by car and finding suitable parking on your own may be trickier than achieving escape velocity but time flies one you are in the precincts.
Visit to Boudhanath. Would definitely recommend a visit to this tranquil place, meditating here is a great experience and we need to visit Boudhanath Stupa to enjoy the experience.

Every sunrise at Boudhanath Stupa in Kathmandu brings along with it the sound of ringing bells and Mantras, the smell of. This is one of the best places to people watch in Kathmandu. My recommendation is to grab a delicious breakfast at one of the cafes around the stupa and watch while Tibetan monks and mix with tourists as they walk around the stupa slowly turning the prayer wheels and lighting the butter candles.For the best vantage point, you can climb the stairs and walk around the highest level of the stupa. You can sit and relax while you absorb the experience-- and look at the Himalayas.

A "must see" in Kathmandu! :). In the middle of a circular ground surrounded by three-or-four-story buildings mostly housing souvenir shops and coffee shops (some may have like guesthouses on the upper floors as well), this stupa with like four "step-like" levels (each level is smaller than the one below) above the ground leading to a big round structure above on top of which are four sets of Buddha's eyes under a cone-shaped hat is one of the "must see" places in this city with really only a small number of major sightseeing places (the others being Swayambhunath Stupa on a hilltop, the main Durbar Square, Garden of Dreams and Pashupatinath Temple which is for Hindus only).Also among the surrounding buildings are two temples with a big red dharma wheel (can be turned slowly by the rail around it); the first temple with a big Buddha in it also have a picture of Dalai Lama (right under the Buddha statue) and tall painting portraits of who I figured were the king and queen of Nepal, and the great thing about the second temple is its rooftop with railings around so you can safely view from there the Stupa below with these beautiful colorful cloth pieces on long strings coming down in all directions from above the "Buddha's hat" and also the surrounding colorful buildings.I rented a tour car with a driver just for myself to go to three destinations with this one first followed by Buddhanilkantha and Swayambhunath, costing 3,000 Nepalese rupees (about US$30), and it was about a half-hour drive east from my hotel in Thamel to get here (the tour was arranged at the hotel) followed by another half-hour's drive north to Buddhanilkantha and then about 45 minutes to Swayambhunath before returning to Thamel. Swayambhunath actually is walkable from Thamel (will just take about half an hour) but this one is too far to the east and Buddhanilkantha (which actually is a Hindu temple despite the name) is too far to the north, so I would say a combo tour like I did is definitely a good way to get to these distant places from the tourist area.

Largest Stupa in Nepal. Boudhanath is the largest stupa in Nepal. It is located in the suburbs of Kathmandu - about 20 minutes from Thamel. We visited during a full moon, which is meant to be very special to the Monks, and there were many people giving praise to their gods. The stupa has seen obvious damage from the earthquake and there is reconstruction taking place. The area around the Stupa is very influenced by western culture, with many restaurants serving western style food and drinks.

If You're in Kathmandu, You Can't Leave Without Going Here. The Boudhanath Stupa is one of the largest Buddhist stupas in the world, and an UNESCO World Heritage Site. There's a small fee to get in, but I don't think you can say you've been to Kathmandu without having seen it.A full walk around, up and on it should be a fairly quick trip, even if you're taking lots of pictures. It's customary to walk around it in a clockwise direction. Don't make the mistake of being "that tourist" who walks against the flow of people. There's a reason that they are all moving in the same direction. ;)If you feel that you want to make the most of your entrance fee, the stupa is surrounded by building housing shops and restaurants - some surprisingly good restaurants. If the weather is nice, grab a balcony table and enjoy a meal while overlooking the stupa.A large section was cracked and damaged in the April 2015 earthquake, but sources seem to indicate that it's been completely repaired, so you can see it in its full glory.
Relaxed in silence. Whenever i visit boudhanath, feels relaxed with the silence nd cool environment with the mongolian chants out there. A great herirage site with good enviroment

Slightly damaged but still beautiful!. The Stupa was slightly damaged by the earthquake but is still stunning. The top golden part is no longer there but they are currently conducting renovations to return it to it's former glory. Unfortunately the steps up to the top are closed due to damage but you can still walk around the bottom, Go in the early morning or late evening when there are minimal tourists to see the locals performing their daily rituals - they walk clockwise around the stupa, spinning the prayer wheels and chanting the mantra. We were there in the morning when the shop keepers were just opening (about 9.30am), the locals were chatting and the dogs were sunning themselves. There are a few Buddhist monasteries to visit there as well but be aware that they close from 10-2pm. The Stupa is surrounded by tourist shops where you can buy any trinket you like!

Illy. Boudha has a completely different feel than other parts of KTM.It has all the trendy, Buddhism seeking , ex pats who are well catered for by the numerous cafes, bars and restaurants that surround the Stupa. Lots of lovely places to find an Illy coffee and a good meal at a reasonable price

Spiritual. Never Ending Peace and Love. (Nepal). A Wonderful place of Prayer and Peace.....suggest enquire about free meditation at Osho Divine Zone room. (2nd floor of Golden Eye Restaurant).Earthquake damage minimal around Stupa and repairs to spire well underway.

Damaged, but still beautiful. I've visited Bouddhanath several times before, and I was shocked to see (post-2015 earthquakes) the whole top of the stupa gone. Shocked, and wounded-feeling. Entering the square, though, and seeing everyone else going about their (religious) business, put things into perspective. It's the destination, not the appearance of a destination, that matters. It's still peaceful, calming, and simply wonderful for people-watching, calming down, and enjoying the life of a Tibetan cultural area, in Nepal. Always worth visiting.

Amazing place...bring repaired right now. This is the famous stupa that you see in all the pictures. The top part with the Buddha eyes was destroyed in the earthquake but they are repairing it so it should be back up soon. The walking area around it is full of very interesting shops.

Amazing & best momos too:) . Great site, beautiful. Highly recommended to all. And the rooftop cafe has the best momos.Be careful of scammers - women asking for food for their babies! Yet they aren't their children!

Great religious place. Visited in July right after the earthquake. Complex was closed due to repair works and cracks but still many people milling around outside. Get a guide to explain the intricate carvings. I was told its visited by monks from all over the world. Overall, a meaningful and great attraction. Just don't buy anything from the stalls beside.
An interesting place in Kathmandu. I was there for sightseeing. It is a great Holly place for Buddhism. The area was clean, has good neighborhood, good restaurants. I enjoyed momo.

Worth the time. We went here several months after the earthquake, and they were still in the process of restoring it. My kids and I thought it was very interesting. We enjoyed all the shops surrounding it as well.

Buddha was born in Nepal.. Lovely Stupa, historic and in the heart from Kathmandu.
Very close to ***Kathmandu Self Catering***
Must go place.

Very interesting site although some damage by earthquake. The site is interesting for sitting and watching people going by on their three circumferences of the Stupa - an amazing variety of locals intent on performing their daily rituals
Nice Stupa!. Very nice place with all the Shops around. The earthquake destroyed something but the people are restaurating the building to be nice again soon!

Tick it off your list. Great day activity. Unfortunately the earthquake earlier this year has ruined the Stupa, but they are in the process of rebuilding. Lots of cute little stores surrounding the Stupa selling a variety of things (bracelets, scarves, paintings etc). There are also many rooftop restaurants and cafes which provide a great view of the entire site.

Currently Under Construction. A magical place, but because of earthquake damage the main stupa has been taken down. Still great to walk around and visit the shops, but not in its true form at this time.
Atmospheric but central tower being rebuilt. The golden eyes and umbrella are being reconstructed after the 2015 earthquake. The rest of the monument and area is open and as interesting as ever.
Boudha. It is a good place to visit. Mainly the stupa is huge, I think one of the largest Dom in the earth. In the evening when the candles are lighted up its look great. The place is neat and clean.

Buddha Stupa in middle town. This is in center town. Very badly damaged by recent earthquake. Hence not able to visit inside. Just seen around the stupa. Lot of souvenir shops around the stupa. Very simple place , nothing much to see here.

It was nice... It was nice and clean.
I only saw the leftovers from the earthquake, but still nice to visit
People were very friendly

So awesome - dusk is the best!. Its so beautiful at dusk, when people are lighting candles and presenting them as offerings. Then you can go eat at the many restaurants around the Stupa. Its great, even after the earthquake!

Rebuilding now. This Tibetan community was one of my favorite areas in Kathmandu. They are slowly rebuilding the pinnacle after the earthquake, a demanding process that is happening literally brick by brick as community members and volunteers haul the stone up to the top of the stupa. Shopping is wonderful in this area but go early in the morning when the Buddhists are circumnavigating the stupa and chanting. Spiritual and vibrant.
Worth a visit!. We enjoyed some local beer and momo at a local cafe over looking the stupa at sunset. Amazing view and highly recommend going in the evening if you want to avoid the crowds.

Well worth the visit. The stupa is an amazing place. Unfortunately, the stupa tower was destroyed by the April 2015 quake. But the site retains its feel of a place of faith. It is worth doing the walk around the dome (clockwise!). The buildings around hold stores and artist workshops as well as a monastery (LhaKhang). The whole experience is worth the effort!

A highlight of Kathmandu - repaired since the earthquake... This grand temple is definitely one of the highlights of Kathmandu. Surrounded by prayer wheels, shops and restaurants, it is a tourist stop. Really enjoyed the people watching here.

The Symbol of Peace. Although the top was demolished in great April's earthquake, the white base is enlightening the Peace & Prosperous for remaining victim life. the charms & beauty is still to watch & the chorus the prayer "Om Mani Padme Hu"with all Devotee of Lord Budhdha, you will feel you are in Heaven.
Amazing, dnot miss it!. One of the est places we visited in Kathmandu! Much bigger than it looks in pictures, buys some prayer bead bracelets from the vendors all around.
Before, During and After 2015 Earthquake. I have experienced this holy place several times this year and I was there during the Earthquake. Unfortunatelly Stupa is currently being rebuild
One of the most fascinating places to visit in Kathmandu!. I always love visiting Boudhanat. Come early in the morning and enjoy the soothing sound of prayers.

The best thing in Kathmandu! Peaceful, unique, sacred and will definitely coming back. Boudhanath was one of the best place i ever visited ! Everything are basically amazing, the Stupa (although when i came the top was destroyed), the various people from various countries and places came just to do the Kora (Circling the stupa 3 times), the monks that did their practice im mearby monastery, the pigeon, the dogs, sellers, almost everything are amazing. It is like coming back to the past, escaping from modernism and accepting the life in the present moment. From the architecture you can feel that, the use od bricks and the use of stone for road. The buildings were created so that it can make a harmony with the famous boudhanath stupa. I liked to sit down on the chair facing the stupa in the night just to enjoy the silent night with full moon after did my kora. It is definitely on of my favorite place, i aill definitely coming back to boudhanath and enjoy the present moment.By the way the tips is, don't eat near the boudhanath as the price is higher because it is the tourist area, eat at the local place.And don't forget, the stores and restaurants are usually closed around 8.00 so be quick. Cheers

Great site despite the quake. this historic temple is in a great location with fun shops and cafes - fun to visit both day and night and we felt safe there after dark. Go ahead and spin those prayer wheels with the Monks!

Definitely worth seeing. This Stupa is located in a square with many shops surrounding it and is good for shopping. There is a beautiful Buddhist temple opposite the Stupa which is definitely worth visiting and sitting in, to get peace of mind. The stupa was affected by the earthquake, but you can still make a full walk around it to spin the prayer wheels.
Under reconstruction. Under reconstruction. The top did not collapse during the earthquake, but it's been taken down anyway for reconstructuion. Still very atmospheric place.
Lovely Culture expereine. We had a lovely lunch at the roof top cafe over looking the the Boudhanath. Was a great trip to see it-

Still epic despite losing its top. Still worth the visit despite its top having sadly come off after the earthquake - it is currently under restoration. A lively part of town with monks, tourists, beggars, street sellers, artists, all going about their business in the one place. A great spot to also see some amazing Mandala paintings, buy a pashmina and have a coffee - definitely a cultural highlight of Kathmandu.
One of the happening place in Kathmandu.. I visited Boudhnath Stupa 14 Days before Earthquake. Such great round ambience. so many shops and cafes to relax and see the views of Boudhnath.

The Buddhist center in Kathmandu. Boudnath is the Buddhist center of the world in Kathmandu. Although the Boudnath stupa suffered a lot in April 25 earthquake, the place is still full of spirit and specific atmosphere. Sink into it to feel the deep devotion of the visiting pilgrims and amusement of casual visitors.

Interesting evoacative site - even when damaged by earthquake. Boudhanath was extensively damaged by the April 2015 earthquake but it is still well worth a visit. It is very quiet with no tour groups so it was possible to enjoy the temples and monasterys in the area without the crowds
The most beautiful place in Kathmandu!. This is for me the most peaceful place in Kathmandu, but at the Moment the Stupa is under construction because of Earthquake!
kathmandu. Very religious site damaged by earthquake Don't miss this on your visit to Kathmandu Please visit Nepal they need your help as tourists
Great Place but Damaged. The stupa is very nice but was heavily damaged by the earthquake. The repairs are ongoing and should be done soon

strong belief. Since I spent several days in hotel near Stupa before earthquake, I visited it then many times and had a occasion to read in faces of people circling around. With exceptions, they was lost in thoughts, which gave me the feeling as if the Stupa were a center of deep spiritual emanation.

Beautiful giant stupa. We visited this during our Nepal trip in December 2010. Boudhanath which is a UNESCO World Heritage Site is a beautiful giant stupa in Kathmandu and is located about 11 km from the center and northeastern outskirts of Kathmandu. The stupa's massive mandala makes it one of the largest spherical stupas in Nepal.The Buddhist stupa of Boudhanath dominates the skyline and is one of the largest in the world and is surrounded by over 50 Tibetan Gompas (Monasteries). Must visit when in Kathmandu.

Lovely setting . Great setting in its own square. Very tidy and clean. You have to pay to get in but your away from the crowds. Peaceful and when we went not overcrowded. Great choice of restaurants and shops.

Earthquake damaged the stupa!. We visited Nepal in October, 2015 and visited few monuments around Kathmandu valley and Bouddhanath was one of them. We loved the peaceful around this place, kind people, religious monks, amazing stupa etc. It's a must visit place while you are in Nepal.
Earthquake damaged but still worth seeing. The April, 2015 earthquake has certainly damaged the stupa but it will be repaired again. It is still worth visiting.

A must!. I moved to Kathmandu about 4 months ago and the first attraction I visited was Boudha Stupa. I was overwhelmed by the colors, culture, and liveliness! It was/is unfortunately still under repairs, but the ambiance is still booming. If you are an observer, (like myself!) there is no better place than Bouda. There are cute shops and restaurants to explore, too! We used to go to yoga there every Monday evening. I love the area at dusk, beautiful! A must if you visit Kathmandu!

The largest Stupa in Nepal,. Sadly had been damaged due to the earthquakes earlier this year, but still an impressive site to visit as they work to restore it. Loads of touristy shops and restaurants surrounding the stupa, definitely worth a look.

Tibetan culture in Kathmandu . No trip to Kathmandu is complete without a visit to the Boudhanath Stupa. The shops and restaurants that surround the Stupa are very nice. It is an opportunity to see Tibetan Buddhist culture in Nepal

Religious serenity hidden from the noisy city streets. As you come off the bustling street to this attraction, you are suddenly consumed by the dignified silence that the visitors (religious and others) and attached merchandisers convey. A clockwise journey around the stupa presents a very old structure that has been severely damaged by the earthquake but this does not detract from its significance and presence. Despite being an important Buddhist location, it is surrounded by the usual curios and souvenir shops however the owners maintained a level of respect as the visitors took in the atmosphere.

Tranquility in buzzing Kathmandu. For me this is the best place you can be when you're trying to escape the craziness of the Kathmandu trafic. It's peaceful and quiet and you feel connected with the Buddhist culture. Every year I make time to go back just to sit around all day and watch the lama's and devotees doing their rituals...
very moving to go here. it was hard to see it in ruins but still special to go and turn a prayer wheel. The top was damaged but the rest was till in tacked.

Lovely views and peaceful surroundings. In the midst of crazy busy streets and the hustle and bustle of Kathmandu is this beautiful Stupa. Surrounded by loads of traditional shops and cafes, this is easily a place that you can spend a half day just watching the world go by. Locals and religious visitors frequent this stupa so be sure to have your camera ready.

Beautiful Temple in the heart of Kathmandu. Definitely worth a trip, you can walk around. We were there a few days before the earthquake, it was a dark and stormy afternoon, the wind kicked up and it was very dramatic. There are also many cool shops and places to eat around the outside of the temple.

Damaged, But Nice Area.. The top part of the stupa is now gone and they instead put a makeshift set of some poles and flags. Although the area around this thing is great as there are tons of monasteries you can check out and the street that goes around the stupa is very nice.
Great day!. Beautiful surroundings with restaurants and tea shops close by the Stupa. The location was easy to reach by local bus as well as taxi!
Religious buddhist temple. Oh I love this place and this place fills me with positive vibes , lots of Buddhist monuments .. And lots of good restaurants .

Currently getting renovated. A World Heritage Project. But the Stupa has been damaged by the recent earth quake and is getting renovated. Not worth the trip unless you want to do some shopping for souvenirs around the place or you are a religious Buddhist

Great place to visit. Visited this site as part of a city tour. Work is ongoing to deconstruct and rebuild the top section of this ancient Stupa post the earthquake. It was great to see this work being done piece by piece & we had lunch at a lovely restaurant overlooking the site. Very historic site and a nice to place to relax over lunch. Highly recommend a visit to this site. AAA+

Amazingly atmospheric and very important culturally and religiously to the people of Nepal. Dusk is the time to visit Boudhanath Stupa. We also visited in daylight hours, but the twilight was fun and magical. The fading blue sky and the coloured fairy lights made me expect to see a ferris wheel around the bend. Instead, the golden stupa took centre stage and its kohl-rimmed eyes watched us from every angle. As is tradition, the mass of people swarmed clockwise around the stupa, getting ‘on’ and ‘off’ this carousel to browse for souvenirs or grab some dinner in the endless sea of shops on its perimeter. The seriously devoted were ochre and saffron clad, clearly focused, not distracted in the same way tourists were – they shuffled and chanted, turning prayer wheels as they passed, oblivious to the couple taking a selfie on the white upper story of the edifice.

Under construction but still worth to visit. The top of the stupa is completely missing. The stupa is under construction. Therefore, no one is allowed to go inside of the wall. However, there are many shops and bhuddist temples surrounding the stupa. We got blessed by the Tibetan monk.
Damaged. ... but being repaired. The walk around this stupa is still interesting though.The surrounding shops and centres are still open.

Beautiful!. We went to see Boudhanath (Stupa) during our day trip in Kathmandu and this is not to be missed. Even though the top is a bit ruined from the earth quake, it is beautiful and very well kept. It was peaceful to walk around spinning prayer wheels and getting lost with the crowd. Must see historical site. If anyone is interested in shopping local items, this is a good area for that as well.
Nice Experience. This is a must see for the cultural significance. The earthquake of May 2015 toppled much of the stupa, but it is gratifying to see the work to repair it.

Missing the top. When we visited, they were under the reconstruction of the top. So, the Stupa was without the top. Missing top was totally different from the picture I saw in my guidebook. However, missing top does not make any difference for this sacred place. Very nice and magnificent!

Evenings are always nostalgic. Many good place to sit down and enjoy your coffee with beautiful sunset passing over majestic Stupa.. Have your camera ready for some great photos of stupa and surrounding!!!

A must see historical site. Although badly damaged in the April 25, 2015 earthquake, Bouddhanath Stupa is a must see. Your 250 rupee entrance fee goes toward the restoration of the main temple. (250 rupees is about $2.50USD). When we were there access to the main temple was foridden because of the repairs taking place. However, there's lots of shops to visit, an authentic thanka painting school, and cafés. A clockwise stroll around the stupa turning the prayer wheels is an enjoyable and relaxing experience.

A must visit in Nepal. Even though the stupa is badly damage during the earthquake, this is still worth visiting. It is just as grand but without the top. I reckon at the rate that it is being rebuilt, it will take again least another 10 years. Go to a rooftop cafe and enjoy the view. No regrets coming!
Charm and calm personified. The earhquake has destroyed the top of the Stupa, but this place has retained its earthy charm. No trip to Kathmandu is complete without an obligatory visit to the Stupa.
buddisth stupa. good place to walk around in boudha where you get good coffee... the amience is amazing and you feel you are in different world altogether.

Must do. Although the stupa has been majorly damaged by the April 2015 earthquake, this is still a must visit site in my opinion as it is one of the most important religious sites in the world. When we were there, we witnessed the people rebuilding stupa and the many people who took a pilgrimage to this important temple. Take a lunch at one of the albeit overpriced terrace restaurants and just watch the world go by.
Wonderful and peaceful.. A huge a very old stupa, a holy place in the city centre. Loads of bazaars are around, lovely to just sit down for a while and see the crowd.

Wonderful!. Absolutely beautiful way to spend a day whilst in Kathmandu! We walked around this Stupa for atleast 3 hours and loved everything about it. The shops surrounding the Stupa are lovely & filled with wonderful little trinkets for you to buy and support the local people. There are also lots of little cafes and bars to choose from, where you can have a bite to eat & look over the Stupa in all of it's glory! Would definitely recommend to all!

Nice place. I really found this place nice and beautiful. The hugh monasty is amazing with lots of people who worship Buddha god. It has nice ambience but little far from thamel on the way to kathmandu airport. Must visit once.
Nice place & surroundings. We visit this place before earth quack.. It is one of the main tourist attraction of Kathmandu. Nice place & surroundings with many shops.
interesting - but under construction. the site was under construction for repairs after the earthquake, but still a great spot for locals and visitors to enjoy.
Damaged huge stupa. Now it is damaged but still nice to see tibetian culture around. Nice monastery and shops as you walk there
Amazing old stupa!. It was a magnificent place with, but unfortunately the earthquake that hits this stupa and destroyed the top.

Under repair!. Visited late October and the top bit you see in the photos is not there and the other bits are surrounded by plies of bricks for renovation work after the earthquake. Understandably it is also a rather dirty white at present. Would be a 5 star review I expect when repairs complete. Still a nice atmosphere there
Good energy . Boudha stupa is a place where I can do some handicraft shopping ,antique , good place to eat on the terrace . Most important is you will feel more in holly place with good energy .

wow. I had been here in 2006, and I wasn't ready for what I saw this time. The earthquake damage is overwhelming. The dome and everything above it were obliterated. Really sad. Because of the unesco world heritage designation, there are strict protocols as to how they can rebuild, what materials they must use,etc. Still a great area to visit, but be warned, the stupa is a mess.
very old. historic. stores Nepali and area Tibetan. very old. historic. stores Nepali and area Tibetan. rebuilding now. worth a visit once in your life.

My favorite place in Kathmandu. Still an atmospheric island of peace and quiet. Well worth the visit , even after earthquake.As with all worthy public places in Kathmandu, the government charges fee to enter. YOU CAN ENTER FOR FREE by entering through one of many small alley that lead in. You can make direct donation to restoration of stupa inside.TO GET THERE FROM THAMEL you can take a 15rs minibus from Ratna Park
Iconic landmark. After a while you start getting blasé because of the sheer number of stupas in this country. However it's worth visiting this or and wandering around the outside.
Boudhanath Stupa and surrounds. A great experience - found the site very interesting , especially the Art School. Hopefully the Stupa will be back to its glorious best within the next year.

Early morning at the stupa. We went there early morning, before all shops open and we enjoyed the tranquil setting. People come there to pray in a incessant flow and it is amazing to see thier devotion. We stayed for breakfast at Stupa View and then went shopping for incences and curio. Beautiful morning
After earthquake still beautiful. Very nice stupa. The entrance fee is hopefully spend on rebuilding itThe paintings and arty survived the earthquake very well

An Oasis of Peace in the City. This is a must see in Kathmandu. I could have spent all day here. When you walk thru the gates you feel as if you have entered a tiny oasis in the busy city. Historic, peaceful and breathtaking.
largest Buddhist site in Nepal. circuit it before you stop to shop the top is being rebuilt due to earthquake damage plenty of shopping around, visit monasteries

Beautiful place to visit. Though badly damaged in the April 2015 earthquake, Boudhanath is a great place to visit. Rebuilding is underway and the monastery and temple nearby continue to operate. Surrounding the Boudhanath is a ring of small shops which provide a buffer from the bustle of the streets outside and where you can take in the scenery, the history, a bite to eat, or much souvenir shopping. Definitely worth the visit despite the extent of damage from this year's earthquake.
Peaceful. No matter how many times you visit this placr u will find something new everytime. I lov to go to baudha in the morning. .. its peaceful and calming !!
Worth the trip. Unfortunately the site has been damaged in the earthquake, however it is definately still worth the trip to visit it and the surround square.

Amazing temple. One of my favorite places in Kathmandu. The temple is beautiful and the "ring" around it is a quiet spot in a very hectic and loud part of the city. Another temple nearby is more available to tourists while the earthquake repairs are ongoing. This is a fantastic photo op location.

Surreal. I visited this place last year, way before the devastating earthquake. Walking around the stupa was such a calming and surreal experience. Monks draped in their monastic robes were chanting in unison, as music played in the background. Colourful prayer flags fluttered in the air, as devotees spinned the prayer wheels. Little Nepali children running around chasing after the pigeons, and locals and tourists alike receiving blessings. Truly peaceful and serene, just being there in the moment.
Wonderful. I visited this place in capital city of Nepal last month. This is a nice place to visit when if u want to see some stupas when you are in kathmandu. Can be accessed by public transport.

Very special place. Boudhanath is a very special place. The stupa was once the largest Tibetan Buddhist Stupa in the world. The stupa was affected by the April earthquake in Nepal. Rebuilding and renovation projects are currently underway.
Massive Stupa. Still quite destroyed by the earthquake but worth the walk around. An interesting mix of devotees and tourists. Hopefully they can restore in over time.
Peace. I always feel peace to visit this place as i get satisfaction from my heart. I get different kind of feeling when i get to this place. It's really amazing and spiritual.

recomended. Recomend those who visit kathmandu to go there. But beware of the monkeys even if they are funny animals (would almost love to keep one as a pet), set of some time to get full value for the time (lime so many other places )

Excellent views. This site offers excellent views. It is called the monkey temple for a reason...because the monkeys have clearly taken over. It's in poor condition due to earthquake damage, but the views make the trek up all the stairs worth while.
Nepal Nepal Love Nepal. It is really imaging in kathmandu city views and when you in kathmandu you must to go Boudhanath temple it is really nice .
MONKEY TEMPLE. Definitely worth the trip. The Earthbound Expeditions tour guide was very knowledgeable about the history and significance of the shrines and local area.

Damaged but still worth a visit. The earthquake damage relates mainly to the upper part of the stupa. Repairs are underway, albeit slowly, and it will be 2016 at the very earliest before the main works commence.
It's still an awe inspiring place and an important location that every one should visit.
An amazing structure with lots of history to learn about.. Worth a visit to see the culture surrounding this area. There are many shops surrounding the area to check out.

Very emotive.... The temple is half destroyed by the recent earthquake and it is amazing to see how people preserve the holy ambient of the stupa by performing the famous circle around and doing the candle light rituals at the sunset. An extremely emotive experience....

One of the most special places on earth, for many reasons.... Why Boudha is so special? For one, the stupa is a monument to humanity, and symbolizes a deep faith in our very existence on this planet, and for another, the community there is beautiful. A blend of Tibetans and Nepalis mixed up with foreigners from all over the world... what could be better?

Damaged but still magnificent and needs your help. This mighty stupa once stood tall as one of the most impressive sights in Kathmandu. Sadly damage during the April 2015 earthquake has meant it's now undergoing repair work so has lost a lot of its original features. The entire top section including the famous Buddha eyes has had to be removed.However this shouldn't put you off going, in fact all the more reason to go. They need visitors to help with the costs of the repair, so go and support it. Then next time you come to visit Kathmandu it'll be back to it's former glory.
verry peaceful experience. To get into a state of peace and contentment. lovely people. Looking around for the meaning of everything. great place to visit.

Ancient temple. This structure survived the earthquake with minor damage. It was like walking up a narrow alley to spring out in the open to see this ancient structure. It is surrounded by a wide walk way ( no vehicles). The Stupa in the center and outside the walkway are shops, residences, galleries, temples etc. We went to a four story temple and climbed the stairs to its roof for a panoramic view of the Stupa and surroundings.

Peace. You will love it and feeel at peace all thru when you are inside.
You will forget the whole world and live in a complete set of different ambiance
An impressive place to visit. Though severly damaged by the 2015-earthquake, it's still an impressive place to visit. Great spot to experience the warm and open minded Buddhism.

Peaceful place. this is in north east of Kathmandu. very peaceful largest sputa in Nepal. many shops and restaurants to enjoy time. if you are looking to buy some souvenirs this is one the best place in town.

The place to be in Kathmandu. Everyone, who is visiting Kathmandu will go there. Not only the Buddhist athmosphere, also the Tibetan and local people are there, surrounded by many shops and cafes. Take your time there and stay a while.
Pleasant.. We visited here today as part of a day trip and enjoyed lunch close by before wandering around and watching the workmen begin to rebuild the tower on top of the stupa.

The most peaceful spiritual place ever. I couldn't stop sitting and watching the Tibetans praying all day long. Magical place with amazing atmosphere. Around the Stupa you will find some famous tanka schools worth visiting.
Spiritual. Beutiful place to eat on the roof top and hang out specially during sunset. candle lights all over with the smell of incense.

Go there and get dissolve! . The first time it was a coincidence,The second time it was serendipity,The third time onwards it was a call,And later it became a regular call, a reason. If you want to understand the meaning of tibetian belief system, go there with an open heart.Don't gauge it as a materialistic destination, listen to the chanting, understand the hidden meanings, feel and feel and feel, observe and yes ginger lemon honey tea, is a must!This is what this place has done to me, I calls my soul and am not ashamed to rate it so high.
Beautiful, not as peaceful as you might imagine/hope.. Peaceful stupa, though a little chaotic by mid afternoon, nice restaurants surrounding it but a little outside of the main parts of Kathmandu.

Great near sunset. If you can brave the narrow pavement and busy road it is great to visit the Stupa near sunset and enjoy the view a few levels up. On a good night you'll see the mountains turn pink.

under construction. i think it's nice, but wait to fix it after the earth quick effect
I get inside to see nothing but shops, was really disappointed.
anyways there are nice cafes to have some drinks

religious/difference.. coming from a christian perspective,it was very different for me to spin the bells and also told by the guide to climb up on the stupa and circle the building as a sign of respect and also to gain good luck.i did that,to enter had buy ticket.lots food shops and restaurants in there.i sent about an hour ,had tea and pastry in tea shop.
Amazing and Serene Place. This is must-visit place in Kathmandu. You can find very nice restaurants around the stupa. You can feel an aura of peace in this place.
Enchanting. There's an energy that can't be put in to words. It's a place where you could just sit for hours. Beautiful.

Took My Breath Away. When I walked into Boudhanath it literally took my breath away, my companions thought I was having a heart attack. It was here that I chose my life's mantra, "Life is not measured by the number of breaths you take, but by the number of moments that take your breath away". The monks were chanting, juniper was burning, the faithful were walking and spinning the prayer wheels. My trip to Kathmandu, Boudhanath and the Sherpa community changed my life. If you are traveling to Kathmandu, Don't Miss Boudhanath Stupa.
City Tour. We did visit city tour We are enjoy lot. We did visit Nagarkot sun set also. This is fantastic trip for my family members

damaged by the earthquake. The stupa was slightly damaged by the earthquake in April but repairs were being carried out when we visited in October 2015.The stupa dates back to the 14th century and is one of the holiest of Buddhist sites in Nepal. There is a small fee payable to gain entry into the site and once inside you must walk clockwise.
Best sight. This is the sightseeing we enjoyed most in Kathmandu. This small Tibetan enclave is home to a wonderful white stupa. Vibrant spiritual life around, full of monasteries and also shops.
Amazing stupa!!. Really amazing, feeling peace when enter this stupa area been between crowd, I liked this stupa, i will try to visit again this stupa, if you are in kathmandu most visit once.
Nice place. I enjoyed this place despite the top being destroyed by the earthquake, there is a nice, relaxed atmosphere.

A very special place despite severe earthquake damage. Enjoyed walking around the stupa with many Tibetan and other worshippers, talking with monks, viewing prayer in a monastery, and shopping for souvenirs.

A WORLD FAMOUS MONUMENT NOW UNDER RENOVATION. I had heard so many good things about Boudhanath stupa before I went to KTM. Yes, Boudhanath Stupa is THE most popular tourist attraction at Kathmandu. Yes, it is centrally located at street level and visiting it is easier than many other touristic places. Yes, it has a lot of shops, hotels and restaurants all around to cater to endless stream of tourists.Each observation was 100% true. The attraction is very popular, not just amongst tourists but also amongst locals. You have hundreds and hundreds of devotees, monks and commons coming there to worship or offer prayers. You also have youngsters coming there just to "chill". The central attraction is a large earthen dome with some structures on top. Quite a bit of structure part was partly damaged during earthquake in April 2015. The local government and peoples' body of this area development committee is really doing monumental work of restoration. We saw a photo exhibition of the tremendous work that is being done, nice way of channelising peoples' energy and contribution to this work. Excellent.

Under reconstruction. The stupa and its surroundings is good for a half a day trip. There are nice rooftop restaurants with great view of the stupa from the top and lots of handicraft shops (cheaper than in Thamel). It's also one of the few monuments in Kathmandu valley that are being reconstructed after the earthquake (October 2015).

Impacted in earthquake. Worth visiting but due to the earthquake in April, some parts of the structure has been damaged. They are fixing it and there is a gallery booth that showing all the progress. Anyway, It's a great place!

Visiting the holiest Buddhist shrine of Nepal!. While visiting Kathmandu, the "Great Buddha Stupa" can never be missed! As the holiest Buddhist shrine of Nepal, it was appointed by Unesco, in 1979, as a World Heritage Site and is today a major destination for pilgrims from Nepal, Bhutan, Tibet, and many other countries. The first references to the "Great Buddha Stupa" date as far back as the 5th Century and it is believed that the relics of the Kashyapa Buddha (the Third Buddha) were enshrined at its dome! Under it, four pairs of eyes, one for each cardinal point, watch us: Lord Buddha sees everything. This Stupa, so full of meanings and magic, is dedicated to the "Buddhas of the Past, Present and Future", and is also known as the "Stupa of Enlightenment". A lot of history and faith! Monks of all ages, in their red tibetan purple robes are seen everywhere. Join them, take your time, turn the prayer wheels and walk slowly, clockwise, around the main Stupa as many times as you wish. Enjoy moments of silence, inner reflection and peace.I visited Kathmandu on February 2015, nearly two and a half months before the terrible earthquake that devastated Nepal on April 25, 2015. As far as I have read, the "Great Buddha Stupa" has suffered minor damages and is already under restoration. The Boudhanath Area is again opened to visitors and a fee of Rs 250,00 is charged upon entry. Restaurants, souvenir shops, temples (e.g. Ajima Temple) and monasteries (e.g. Guru Lhakhang Monastery) can be easily visited. Support Nepal's reconstruction by not postponing your plans! Enjoy!

Boudhanath is wonderful. I've stayed in Boudha several times but this last time, Oct. 15 just visited as I stayed in Thamel. Definitely visit as the atmosphere is so different and peaceful. Walk around the stupa, the top of which was damaged in the earthquake and is being repaired.

Peaceful & Beautiful. This Stupa is located in the Kathmandu region of Nepal. We booked for a day trip to all the monuments and temples of Kathmandu and this was 1 of them.The place is exquisite and peaceful, you can meet the Monks here and buy Budha preaching items here. The place is worth a visit as its one of the most sacred places in Kathmandu.
Beautiful. This place is really beautiful. Love the colourful prayer flags.We were here before the earthquake of 2015 though. I hope it wasn't badly damaged.

Interesting Local Population. The Stupa was damaged in the earthquake, but not destroyed. Work is being done to repair, and it does not, in the least, spoil the experience. It is lovely. Locals circle the site for religious reasons and the area is surrounded by shops.
Icon of Nepal . It's one of the iconic view of Kathmandu. It's very colourful and well known landscape of the world. Best for photography and share the experience of this old stupa

Amazing Experience. It is really an amazing experience joining hundreds of people in walking rotating ritual prayer around Boudhanath Stupa early in the morning. Afterwards, many shops offer a haven of colourful crafts.
Earthquake damage minimal. I thought that most of Kathmandu would be in tatters.But there is actually very little evidence of the earthquake in the city. So tourists should not hesitate to visit
Really cool!. Beautiful! And the views at night are amazing! A must see while in Nepal! I just hope it survived the earth quake!

Damaged but worth visiting. Boudhanath Stupa is severely damaged by the earthquake but the restoration work has already been started which is a relief.
The stupa is best viewed from the roof top restaurant nearby after a spiritual walk rotating the Prayer wheels around the Stupa.
One can also enjoy pigeon feeding and shopping for Prayer Flags and Good luck accessories in the area.

wounded by earthquake but extraordinary site. Even if hurt by the earthquake and it is in restoration phase, it's blessings seem intact. Life around the stupa is worth spending time there. Don't rush, hopefully spend a few days in Bouddha, walking it's small streets and doing Kora with the Buddhist community around the stupa at dawn and sunset, clockwise walking and praying every day.
Don't Miss. Well worth a visit - damaged in April 2015 earthquake but they are working on the restoration, don't forget to walk round it clockwise.

Tragic . I hadn't known that the Boudhanath stupa had been badly affected by the earthquake and was shocked to see that the top with the all-seeing eyes had been destroyed. Nevertheless it was good to see reconstruction had begun and that the businesses around the stupa continues. I went to see one of the nyingma temples around the stupa which had a good view of the stupa.Worth going to see.

See it from one of the rooftop cafes.. I visited at sunset. It's under construction because of the earthquake and the prayer flags are missing and the whole top part has been temporarily removed. There were still many people, locals and tourists walking round clockwise. We went to one of the rooftop cafes and then I was glad we had visited. We could see the mountains, the rooftops, it all looked very Nepalese and beautiful.
A World Heritage Sit. A wonderful location for a day visit. Immerse yourself in the peace and tranquility of this very special place
