Too many tourists. Too many tourists: As soon as they look at your "lack of tan" they try to screw you. Overpriced. Entrance fee is ridiculously high for the country.

nice tour for a day. Nicevto go there for day tour to see tibtain goods heritage site
It is very good for spending time recommended you
Damaged but still worth seeing. Unfortunately it's been badly damaged in the quake but the re-building work has already started and there's a nice vibe to the are.
nepal experience . one of the best places to see in kathmandu with a lot of history and buzz. impressive stupa. it makes you understand nepalese art and culture
Peace in the heart of chaos !. My favourite place in KTM sadly under post earthquake renovation at the movement . But still a spiritual uplifting enlightening experience .
Religious place.. The Stupa was a little far from the city itself. But was good. It is really a good place for pilgrims to travel to.

Super good vibe. This was one of my favorite stops in Kathmandu. Never a lack of people around, everyone was friendly; many praying; lots of monks around; and incense burning in big urns. So many marigolds placed in cups, part of the visual blessing experience. This was a wonderful place. For those who like to shop, there are shops around the edges of the plaza. We also found an artist studio, upstairs in on of the buildings. Highly recommend. They were getting ready for a celebration, and men were atop the stupa pouring colored wash down the big curved top. We were there in Feb 2014, but can only go back so far on the when did you visit button.

Still a must see sight. The current stupa dates back to the14th century and must have been breathtaking before the earthquake. It's grandeur is still there, but sadly the tower and spire are gone. Encircling the stupa are ancient (and not so ancient) four and five story building, housing everything from meditation clinics, religious artifacts, restaurants all the way through to souvenir shops. Prime location goes to the rooftop terrace restaurants, a great place to sit over a coffee and watch the Tibetan pilgrims walk clockwise around the stupa.
Still beautiful. Despite the earthquake damages and repairs, this is a beautiful stupa and must be seen. A walk around will leave you feeling energized.

what a thought provoking place. A lovely place to visit, great vibe and beautiful to see from a roof top cafe. Loads of shops offering fantastic variety of goodies and the area is home to 13 buddhist temples

Scientific restoration of the Stupa. This attraction also suffered significant damage during the earthquake on 25 April 2015. To see the effort going into restoring the Stupa and visit the monastery, is well worth the effort.

Peaceful Place. This is one of my favourite places in the world that I have been lucky to visit several times over the past 12 years. There is a peace and calm around the stupa that gets you hooked. Enjoy the stunning view over a cup of tea from one of the surrounding terraces or simply walk like the locals in prayers around the stupa. Best to visit in the early morning or late afternoon/evening during the high tourist season when it is less crowded. Or stay until the evening and light a butter lamp to the sound of the evening mantras. Particularly beautiful during festivals when the stupa is often illuminated in lights. There are also a number of lovely cafes around these days.
Boudhanath (Stupa) in my 1st day in Kathmandu. Boudhanath (Stupa) in my 1st day in Kathmandu, a good location to visit. Minor repairing are on going, shall be good soon !

Buddha is everywhere. This is an interesting site. It's a site worth seeing. It is more of a religious site and it abounds with shops and restaurants around it. However, I believe it was damaged during the last earthquake so check before you go.

Potentially very nice spot. The place is very impressive although under reconstruction. Lot's of coffee places, guest houses, etc.Also some very nice tamples open for visitors. If already in the area, go to Pashupatinath.
My fav place in KTM. Every time I visit KTM I always come here, I feel very spiritual n at peace when I m here among all the chaos

peace of mind. Boudhanath stupa is known as biggest and oldest stupa of lord Buddha.located middle of kathmandu offer seeing of monks and devotes different types sound of buddhist instrument and lots of prayer flags and lights.
Walk clockwise and enjoy . The top of the huge stupa is being taken down to be rebuilt following the april earthquake. It still is worth visiting. Find yourself a rooftop restaurant and relax.

Peace.... I had an extra day in Katmandu and decided to visit the Stupa. This place provides a good mix of spirituality, religion and culture. Being an Indian I have seen many stupas in India but this place gives a very different feeling. In the middle of all the chaos I could find peace.Structure wise there is nothing exceptional about the stupa but its the surrounding that makes it distinct. There are many shops playing mantras (usually Om Mani Padme hum) which gives a feeling of peace. A lot of Buddhist pray whole day and some function keeps on going. There are usually hundreds of pigeons flying around which is a delight for any photographer. The place looks even more beautiful at night and one can get a good view from roof top restaurants.

Beautiful Buddhist Stupa!. This is a truly amazing place. This Stupa is very sacred to Buddhists and Tibetans.The Stupa is much bigger in person than it appears. You can walk on its different levels.You are supposed to walk around it and turn the prayer wheelers. People go around many times.It is a main pilgrimage for Buddhist to try and make in their life. Buddhist walk from many places like Bhutan and Tibet to reach this Stupa. The Stupa suffered some damage during the earthquake but it is already being renovated. Boudhanath is awesome and beautiful.

Consumerism meets Buddhism!. A wonderful mix of shops and monasteries...all in a circular walk around the stupa. Shops selling malas (prayer beads), mandalas, and pashima shawls....and mini temples with huge prayer wheels. You will hear mantra chants (you can even buy the DVD!) from all corners. Really an experience not to be missed!

A fascinating place of great religious significance. A place that must definitely not be missed; awe-inspiring and peaceful as so many places of religious significance are; in this case Buddhist; monks wander around and study at local monasteries; the stupa complex is surrounded at ground level by smaller temples and shops and one can climb up to roof-top restaurants from where there are great views.Of course I was there pre-earthquake so am not sure of the degree of damage, but I'm sure it would be one of the first places to be repaired.

Just look at it. What else is there to say about how majestic and beautiful this place is? All photos you may have already seen here have no need to be doctored (and I'm confident that rebuilding efforts will restore the stupa to its former glory). However, photos cannot express enough the atmosphere of Boudhanath. It's a beautiful spiritual sanctum, tourist attraction, and Nepalese daily life all wrapped into one location. This is also a convenient place to get all the souvenirs you will need and grab a good meal.Visiting in the daytime will let you take in the color and sights of the location (try going to one of the rooftop cafes/restaurants for a great view of the stupa and the Himalayas). If you can, come back in evening times even after most of the shops have closed; it's a different, quiet experience that's also quite special.

Teeming with Life. I was in Boudha, as a pilgrim and academic researcher, in 2011 for a month, way before the earthquake. The stupa at Boudhanath and the life around it are a thing to behold. Joining in the kora, walking in meditation around the stupa morning or evening was a moving experience. The life surrounding the stupa is complex and simple at the same time. People from all strata--wealthy foreigners, local shop owners, artisans, pilgrims, Tibetan exiles, monastics, wily street kids, beggars, street dogs, and the occasional cat or monkey--mingle amongst well-behaved pigeons and the smoke and aroma of ever-burning incense and butter lamp offerings. Plenty of options for dining--from Nepali/Newari and Tibetan to Western cuisine--excellent for vegetarians! Duck into the shops showcasing Buddhist thangkas and allow the artists to tell you about their craft (I learned a lot and got to see some beautiful images of Mother Tara and Manjushri--which is what I was shopping for). Be prepared to haggle in most of the shops.
Amazing. for me one of the beautiest places in Kathmandu. Peaceful, spiritual and also Powerful. Wonderful view from the Roof Terrace Restaurant around the stupa

One of Kathmandu's main attractions. Fascinating Buddhist monument near Pashupatinath. One of the world's largest Buddhist shrines. Top was badly damaged in earthquake and is now under renovation. Many quaint shops and restaurants in the neighborhood. A fee is charged to visit this shrine, but can be avoided by entering through the back alleys.

Future Progress. It is sad to see the destruction from the earthquake. But it is nice to see the rebuild efforts that are taking place. The area is fun and has a lot of spirit about it. Very beautiful on a nice day!

Even with renovation it's an amazing place. This is a must see place in Kathmandu, very spiritual and some beautiful sights. Currently under renovation but this doesn't really affect the experience. Be sure to visit the surrounding temples also in the square.

Little Tibet in Nepal. Lovely getaway place from busy life. Boudha offers excellent Tibetan experience to your Nepal trip. It feels like a little Tibet surrounded by Tibetan Monastery, bookstores, thankas, dress, mandala and beautiful Tibetan people. The stupa is white and glazes with the sun. Plenty of options to have food, coffee and enjoy the late afternoon. Check out the alleys for surprise coffee shops and better bargain shops.
See it. It is a remarkable stupa, amazing view from above. sad to see what earthquake have done on some part of it.

Must visit -- spiritual, and recovering well. The top of the stupa is under reconstruction and should be finished in about 6 months. The Boudanath will add this episode onto its illustrious past. The work does not detract from the plaza around the temple, the spiritual feeling, the cleanliness, and the Tibetan feel. Have lunch at one of the rooftop cafes (Buf Mo-mo!) Please go -- show your support to great people!

Stunning. The most beautiful place in Kathmandu. We were here the day before the quake and hope it still retains the beauty it did before the earthquake occurred.
The presence of so many prayer flags finally made me succumb to my partner's pleading for our own at home. Just beautiful.

World's largest Stupa!. Such an amazing piece of history to go visit while in Kathmandu. Boudha is surrounded by lovely shops, artisans, and eateries allowing you to gaze into the Buddha Eyes and watch the people circulate around the stupa. It feels physically special to be near such a deeply spiritual and revered site.

Worth the money. Should be on every travellers sightseeing list. A shame how much it's been damaged during the earthquake but they're working on it. Can't see a lot since you're only allowed to walk around it due to construction works. But 250rupees fee seems fair.

Awe-inspiring. Unfortunately, the earthquakes have resulted in significant damage to the top of the Stupa. While this is now under under construction it is still awe-inspiring. Don't forget to have a look at the other Buddhist temples in the surrounding lanes.
Oasis of solitude. One of the last few areas of Tibetan culture left in the world and a must see when visiting Nepal. An oasis of solitude

A cultural gem. An awe-inspiring and beautiful relic of Buddhist culture. It is definitely worth a visit purely on it's architectural merits but most importantly to get an understanding of it's significance to the Nepalese people.

Love the construccions.. The building was under construcciont but stil madgestic, I just love the strcuture the design and the way to see the bulding, clock wise. it was very diferent to do it clock wise.

A destroyed temple after earthquake . I was very intrested to see this Buddha temple regard to personal attitude. I got ready to take picture from the Buddha's eyes espicially the third eye, which is represented of insight of Buddha. But unfortunately; earthquake destroyed the superior floor and main sculpture of temple.it is surprisingly that the local government try to repair it as soon as possible

Big Attraction. Boudhanath Stupa is a big tourist attraction. Presently, it's under renovations due to the April 2015 Earthquakes. It's set to be the second largest Buddhist stupa in Asia,when renovations are complete, though with the exception of Cambodia. However, I just learned that China had since constructed the tallest stupa about a few years ago. Not sure about the exact date. Here at Boudhanath, you get to mingle with Tibetan people, who are in the majority here. They occupy thousands of shops that sell commodities like Cashmere sweaters, incenses, Tibetan Thanka and the famous Tibetan rugs. Nearby is the Buddhist temple. You will definitely find many Americans here, who are either studying Buddhism or just hanging out. I was surprised when I met Joshua Fouse, from California, who serves as a secretary to Kyabgön Phakchok Rinpoche.
still shining :). one of the best place in kathmandu to see, shining big and tall, blessing to us. best place to spent a days. a must place to visit while in kathmandu.

Huge and Humongous !!! ❤ 💘 ❤. Absolutely Blissful !!!I went there on 25th August, after earthquake repair work under progress, The majestic stupa stands tall and handsome !!! I went around the stupa and sat in silence and found to be absolutely peaceful and feeling completely relaxed.A request to all the tourist , please come and visit Kathmandu , in fact the whole of Nepal is absolutely safe and has lots to offer for all types of tourist and enjoy the hospitality and stunning views with lots and lots of thrilling sports and trekking activities, please experience this experience for the experience sake.Thanks a lot for everything,Loving you so much,Peacefully yours.S M Bega Raaj.Happy travelling...❤ ❤...
Place of inspiration. Inspiration place, even after earthquake. Peace and quietness, mixture of characters and nationalities. Lots of good shops around.

Nirvana. Disregard of your religion,this place is a nirvana. Pilgrims chanting their prayers ,sweet fragrance of the incense they burn and the feel you get when you go around the stupa moving the prayer wheels. A must place to visit when u r in kathmandu.

Fascinating to visit while under repair. For those who have been to Boudha, Kathmandu, you will remember the magnificent golden spire and the Buddha eyes of the Boudha Stupa. The golden spire has now come down after the quakes and is being rebuilt but the whole stupa area and the white stupa dome is all there and really worth a visit when you are in Kathmandu. You will get a rare opportunity in centuries to see what sits behind the golden spire and eyes as the master craftsmen rebuild the spire by hand. In its long history, no one has ever seen what is behind the decorative cover. All the shops and restaurants in the stupa area are open and thousands of local people continue to walk around the stupa every morning and evening. The original Boudha Gate is still standing and the area gives tourists a very special taste of Buddhism in Nepal as it is surrounded by many large and small monasteries. Allow a good half day to take in all the sights.
Awe Inspiring. Awe inspiring, simply beautiful. The earthquake damage has not effected this site enough to change the experience.
Wonderful. My images are before the earthquake and what a wonderful place to walk round - TIP -always travel around the stupa in a clockwise direction
Buddha eyes :). Being repaired at the moment, it's still imperative to visit the place, and is one the most similar experience to the tibetan buddhism in Kathmandu :)

A living heritage. A must-visit in Kathmandu. The stupa is beautiful and is an icon of Kathmandu. The stupa complex itself is lively and colourful with a community living there.There is also a constant stream of worshipers and tourists to the stupa all day long. Besides smaller temples, there are souvenir shops, fruit vendors, restaurants and small hotels surrounding the stupa.
SERENITY .... the place that signifies serenity and peace. you will see a lot of people visit in the evening for prayers and lighting lights. also the area have pretty good Chinese restaurants.

Beautiful! Must visit. It is a beautiful surprise very unexpected as you walk through the bustling traffic and noise just a few metros away from it.A religious pilgrimage to nepal made by any buddhist is not complete without a stop at the Boudhanath stupa. Pilgrims and locals both can be seen circumambulating around it clockwise especially early mornings and evenings.Local curators have shops surrounding the Stupa with many a rooftop restaurants frolicking the buildings.If you are a fan of the szcheuan cuisine, try the white Zambala as local restaurant where the seating is very basic but the food top notch.La casita run by a spanish lady has a great view of the stupa if you climb up to its rooftop.Roadhouse cafe has one of the best wood fire pizza's in town, one of the many outlets it has in Ktm.Don't forget to eat Momos!
Wonderful. Amazing place large and the eyes follow you everywhere. Surrounded by great restaurants. Brilliant people watching place.
My favorite place to contemplate Nepal. My favorite place in Kathmandu -- early in the morning and around 6pm when the Nepalese and Tibetans come to pray. Incense, chanting, wonderful feel.
Must Visit. Crowded but the air has a sense of peace and serenity. View of Kathmandu valley is amazing from this place. lots of antique shop around.

A few little cracks..... The media painted a pretty bleak picture of the destruction caused by the two earthquakes in April and May 2015. But the damage was far less than portrayed, especially here at the Stupa.True, the top faces with Buddha's eyes looking in every direction was masked by scaffolding as workmen were busy repairing some damage to the tiles, but apart from a few fine cracks in the dome and little stupas surrounding the main one, there was much less damage than to be expected.And of course life around the stupa continues as normal. Buddhists from all around, Tibetans and foreign visitors walk around the stupa, turning prayer wheels and counting their beads. The little shops around the edge sell their beautiful handicrafts and the cafes and restaurants serve a wide variety of food. Heading out the back roads from the stupa, you find all sorts of local shops and restaurants, and little Tibetan cafes tucked down the alleyways. The atmosphere is tranquil and even if you don't have time for anywhere else, I'd recommend Boudha as a must visit place.

Awesome place. The Boudhanath Stupa cracked up a little during the earthquake and is being restored to its pristine glory.The main attraction is the surrounding area which is a shopping place for tourists. What attracts you there are like... The singing bowl shop which has hundreds of singing bowls stacked. Then there is the Thanka arts gallery which is a buddhist painting store. Paintings from Nepal, Japan and other countries feature here.You can also find exquisite and Traditional Nepalese clothing made of pure silk for girls and women.Beads, crystals, name it and you will find it.This is also a very good opportunity for different kinds of photography, be it people, artefacts, attractions and tradition of course.

One of the biggest Buddha temple in Nepal. You experience some of the religious activities around the stupa. Yet it surrounded by the souvenir shops and restaurant. Many buddhist pilgrims visited this place

Symbol of Nepal. Magnificent stupa, not so far away from downtown. Usually crowded, it turns into a real calmed place after 7 p.m. Restaurants and coffee places around are a little overpriced, but you will feel relaxed drinking your tea and having some snacks in a rooftop in front of the compassion eyes...
Central area closed for repairs, but still interesting. Key temple for Tibetan Buddhism with surrounding monasteries and smaller temples. Taxi from Thamel could be NPR 300 or lower

Great place. Amazing place. The stupa is beautiful, especially in the evening where hundreds of persons gather to pray. This place has an incredible advantage over all of Kathmandu: it's fully pedestrian. No pollution, traffic, noise, etc. And many nice restaurants and bars to eat and drink on rooftops with an amazing view over the stupa and surrounding plaza.

Cultural Magnificient. This is the cultural centre of the Tibetans in Kathmandu. The huge stupa and the surrounding area that any tourists should not miss. We visited temples, thangkas paiting, cafes... watched the monks and children walked by. The are is showing what Tibetan culture looks like.

Great little square!. Like everything about Kathmandu, the beauty of Boudhanath has less to do with the actual attraction but more to do with the area it's centered around. Worth going to. I was there in September 2015 and the main attraction was still destroyed from the earthquake but that doesn't take much away from the beauty of the place.
Beautiful Stupa. Spectacular Stupa in a beautiful square. There aren't the crowds of the Swayambhunath Temple and plenty of cafes to sit and relax while watching the local pilgrims.
A must see!. Visiting Stupa was a part of an organized day trip through ACE the Himalaya. It was worth the visit and very interesting.

One of the cultural highlights of Kathmandu!. Boudhanath is the largest Stupa in Nepal, and Buddha was born in Nepal. It is incredibly beautiful, however the top portion of the stupa was damaged in the April 2015 Earthquake and was under restoration in August, when I was there. On previous trips I have photographed the painted Buddha eyes on the top portion and the photographs have come out wonderful. Don't miss this stupa if you are in the Kathmandu Valley.

Brilliant. Boudhanath is a spectacular place to visit. The stupa itself is massive and very impressive. Although, the highlight for me was seeing all the Tibetans circling the temple with such spiritual devotion. It really needs to be seen to appreciate this. I visited in August after the earthquake, and the top of the stupa had scaffolding surrounding it, as it was being repaired. Access past the main walls was also restricted, but hopefully this will be changing soon, as repair work progresses.A taxi here from the Thamel area costs about 250rp.

Stouppa.... Making the time to look around here did not enhance my overall experience of Kathmandu. Probably not worth the effort unless you have plenty of time. Would much rather have spent that time wandering around the markets or at the Kaiser Cafe...
Awesome. We climbed on the roof of this beautiful stupa and basked in its beauty. It breaks our heart to see what the earthquake wrought.

One of the best and biggest stupas in Kathmandu Valley. Last time when visiting Kathmandu Valley I missed out on seeing this stupa due to a flight change, so I was eagerly looking forward to it this time. This large, white stupa is surrounded by shops (selling candles, souvenirs, food, tattoos etc.) as with it's entrance way. Unfortunately, on my visit repairs were being done on the top section and it was covered with bamboo scaffolding and tarps. However the remainder was in good condition, with many people (both locals and tourists) visiting the stupa. The lower portion of the stupa contains many sections of prayer wheels along with a few statues and gates to the inside (no entry allowed). Decorated around the stupa are also many statues and flag poles (with many flags). Missing are the many prayer flags that are strung from the top and attached to the flag poles. They are still attached to the poles and are likely to be strung up once repairs are finished.Overall, an excellent place to see during a day trip of other sides around the valley and highly recommended. Although my visit was only very good, that's solely due to the necessary repairs and no prayer flags flying, i'm sure at a later date once everything is complete it will be back to it's glorious self, an excellent sight to visit and see.
Kathmandu trip. A must see. I hope that the earthquake did not destroy it. I will be going back to see Kathmandu and plan to build a Habitat house next year.
Nice atmosphere. Once you enter the complex, you forget that you are in such a crazy city as Kathmandu. Peaceful atmosphere inside. Lots of shops selling candles, food etc. circumscribing the temple.

Boudhanath <stupa>peace pagoda. Boudhanath (Devanagari, Nepali: बौद्धनाथ) (also called Boudha, Bouddhanath or Baudhanath or the Khāsa Caitya) is a stupa in Kathmandu, Nepal. It is known as Khāsti in Nepal Bhasa, Jyarung Khashor in Tibetan language (Tibetan: བྱ་རུང་ཁ་ཤོར། Wylie: bya rung kha shor) or as Bauddha by speakers of Nepali.[2] Located about 11 km (6.8 mi) from the center and northeastern outskirts of Kathmandu, the stupa's massive mandala makes it one of the largest spherical stupas in Nepal.[3]The Buddhist stupa of Boudhanath dominates the skyline. The ancient Stupa is one of the largest in the world. The influx of large populations of refugees from Tibet has seen the construction of over 50 Tibetan Gompas (Monasteries) around Boudhanath. As of 1979, Boudhanath is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Along with Swayambhunath, it is one of the most popular tourist sites in the Kathmandu area.The Stupa is on the ancient trade route from Tibet which enters the Kathmandu Valley by the village of Sankhu in the northeast corner, passes by Boudnath Stupa to the ancient and smaller stupa of Cā-bahī (often called 'Little Boudnath'). It then turns directly south, heading over the Bagmati river to Patan - thus bypassing the main city of Kathmandu (which was a later foundation).[2] Tibetan merchants have rested and offered prayers here for many centuries. When refugees entered Nepal from Tibet in the 1950s, many decided to live around Boudhanath. The Stupa is said to entomb the remains of Kassapa Buddha.
Never Miss. First tour to this palace is my school trip. You should not miss this palace. Whenever I goto Kathmandu I never miss this.

Mooie stupa, en toch ook groot. After stories of other travelers i visited this place. That day there was some kind of festival, the place was full with people visiting the stupa. Great experiance to see and feel something like that.The stupa was looking great, especialy for the size of it. There are also a lot of shops around the stupa, I was looking for some typical Nepalese souvenirs and found more then expected for a fair price.
Boudha,Represent Nepal. Boudhanath,one of the most amazing symbol In Nepal.Very much attractive and eye appealing.The real antic construction.

You should not miss this place. When staying in Nepal do not miss this place. It is one of the quietest places in Kathmandu having atmosphere. Lot of restaurants nearby with great view on Buddhanath, lot of place where to buy mandalass.
The respectful place. The respectful and beautiful place. Lots of people came to do the respect. Around the Stupa was great, got many shop and things to watch.
This is the one. All the photos, postcards, snapshots in books... It's of this place. Big, bold, super white, not too crowded. And worthy of just sitting & staring.
Best Momo we ate here :). The oldest and the most beautiful stupa in Kathmandu, must see in your first visit! It's where Tibetan refugees live in Kathmandu

Earthquake damaged site. Alas, because of the earthquake, there is little to see here. The stupa itself is badly damaged and the spire is completely covered in scaffold and tarpaulin. You can walk all round the monument, but it's surrounded in a complete circle by souvenir shops, making the experience somewhat tawdry. Paying Rs250 effectively to shop for tacky nicknacks simply isn't worth it, especially as it's in a relatively inaccessible part of the city, way out to the east. Until the damage is reparied (if it can be) probably not worth the time or money.

Well worth a visit . The whole area around Boudhanath stupa is amazing. There is a great range of market stalls selling all kinds of memorabilia. The stupa itself is amazing to see but best visited at dawn or dusk for the full experience and as the Buddhist monks walk around the stupa chanting. Whilst there make sure you take lunch at the Garden Kitchen restaurant: delicious food and a great location.
Great excursion.. Great shopping here and great restaurants upstairs over looking the temple where you can have a drink and watch the madness of shoppers and tourists.
must see in KTM. Spiritual experience for some. Earthquake damaged however it is under scaffold now and will be repaired.

A must, not on weekends. Beautiful, calm, spacious square houses the stupa, lots of coffee shops, hotels and souvenir stands but nowhere near as stuffy as the thamel .its a breath of fresh air. make sure to check out the small alleys, full of little surprises

Home away from home. Each time I arrive to the area around the amazing stupa, Jarung Kashor, of Boiudhanath, it is as if coming back home in some way. The road/path around the stupa is paved and clean. All day long, but mainly in the evening and early morning there are crowds of people circumambulating the stupa. So there are plenty of opportunities for looking at people of different cultures doing their religious practices. Around the stupa are plenty of good cafés, restaurants and shops. Make sure you go inside and offer a butterlamp or more. Currently the stupa is being repaired after the eartquake - but the ambience around it is still the same - so this is no reason for not coming here.
nice place. i visit buddhanath stupa. it was very nice design and best place tibetan culture. it is worthful place to visit
A highlight of Kathmandy. There are many stupas in Nepal and Myanmar but this is one of the larger ones and it is surrounded by interesting structures.

A place of peace. A wonderfully peaceful place to stay in Khatmandu. We were lucky enough to be there twice, at the start and end of our stay in March/April 2015. The earthquake had hit the city on our return but Boudhnath felt scarcely touched. Although everyone was in a state of shock, circling the great stupa seemed to bring a sense of normality.

A Holy Place. Located at city of Kathmandu, this is one of the holiest places i've ever been. There lots of people from different countries mostly buddhists who visit here. Be sure to go around the stupa and meditate on Om Mani Padme Hum chants. At the front of the entrance of the stupa, you will see a buddhist temple (Guru Lhakhang Monastery). Go for a stop over and try to light an incensed candle. We went there inside. I was surprised that one of the monks (Brother Nawang) only asked our names and he started praying for us without asking our religion, donations or money. People inside were great and you can totally feel the genuineness of each and everyone.
Nice temple. Its must to see this temple in Nepal the taxi take 450-600 NPR There's many shops near the temple souvenirs & stuff like that So enjoy!!
Biggest stupa in the world!. I was told it's the biggest stupa in the world and it truly is stunning. Try one of the restaurants on the rooftops for an even better view.

Simple but Powerful Architecture.. Compared to Swayambhunath Temple, Boudhanath Stupa makes me feel more peaceful in mind. Nepalese walk around stupa in their normal life, and I try to walk like their way, it's magic I can really feel calm somehow. And it's also an comfortable experience that sitting on the rooftop cafe to see the whole stupa, I admire the architectural style, simple but powerful.

Even after the earthquake...... I spent time in Kathmandu after the 25 April earthquake that devastated the country. I found solace in the Boudnath Stoupa, amazing chanting from local monks and a resilience from the locals who are rebuilding the area. Lovely market square with souvenirs (they rely on this, be generous), and a few little tea houses. Honestly, I didn't feel safe in the tea houses because I was still there in the after-shocks but I"d be more than happy to return and give them business.

awesome view of ktm. I had been here before and I adore the awesome view seen from stupa of the valley. I like the structures here. lots of monkeys, so gotta be careful. overall nice... I came here again after the big earthquake and most of the building were damages and we're repairing so didn't get much to see around. I hope they repair it quick.

Buddhist pilgrims in Kathmandu. this sputa is a famous and very beautiful . one of the big monitory in Kathmandu must of the Buddhist religion people visit their every morning and evening , winch is a peaceful and romanticize please so that when you doing sightseeing in Kathmandu you do not miss to go their thanks

Feel the energy. I stayed in Boudha area for a few weeks during the chaotic time in Nepal with the earthquakes. I visited Boudhanath stupa many times as the accommodation I was at was nearby. Each morning at 6-7am the energy is amazing, take a walk with hundreds of local Tibetan as they walk around the stupa. The size of the structure is massive, something not to miss as it is one of the biggest stupa's I've seen. If you're looking for a more quiet place to walk around, than Boudha is for you.

Must visit site in Kathmandu. Despite the ongoing repairs to the stupa which means visitors can't wander on its different decks, the stupa is still well worth visiting. There is unmistakable atmosphere in the mornings and evenings as the most devout Buddhists, nuns and monks do their circumnambulations. A rather ungrateful man who wanted to chat about Buddhism in the hope of receiving at least $20 in alms, detracted from my experience. But this is samsara and part of the experience is learning to keep equanimity and show compassion to all beings! Perhaps I should be grateful for his reminder of that! Some of the cafes are closed as it's quiet in terms of tourist numbers and many shopkeepers seemed quite non plussed. However it's still well worth a visit to Boudanath.

worth visiting. if you come to nepal you shouldnt miss this place. i would suggest you to come around 3 o clock which i accidently found myself in a ritual that holly lama came out and walked in public. And after that all ather budist rituals begun which were quiet interesting. shops around are also nice. i suggest you to try all of them to have a lower price and compare.

Great Place for a Stroll. The Stupa and surrounding areas suffered from minimal damaging from the earthquake. The area is still a wonderful place to meander for an afternoon enjoying one of the many tea shop, restaurants or shops.
Very big.... Nice big Stupa and Nice place... it si apity to have so much business around, but the place is worth to go to visit...

A place must visit. Boudhanath Stupa, the world largest & holiest Tibetan Buddhist stupa. I have been visited here twice in year 2013 and 2015, the view from rooftop and bottom are very different. Try to spend sometimes here to relax and walk around the stupa. Enjoy the beautiful view from rooftop restaurant while having our lunch or high tea. You will love the place.

A holy place. One of the most impressing places I have ever visited. It is quite an experience to share this location with the pious Tibetans. Do a round together with them - in due respect- all around the Stupa during sunset. Maybe you feel like praying for the many Nepal people that suffered from the eartquake last April/May.

Damaged because of Earthquake. A must visit place for every traveller. Even though being centrally located, this place is absolute quiet. Surrounding shops are too good to explore.
Did not had chance to go and visit inside as it was damaged. However it was very amazing experience....
Stupa. Spend few hours walking around this place and enjoy watching the crowd, nice cafes with wifi and watch out for tourist guides.

Tallest Stupa Standing High !!!. Recently I visited this stupa. it was amazing. worlds tallest stupanit affected by earthquake of April 25. a place worth to visit in kathmandu. a very attractive Buddhist stupa.

Peaceful, Strong and Unshakable!. I had reached Kathmandu just a day before the earthquake struck on 25th April 15. Couple of days after sleeping on the streets, camps and getting our senses back, we decided to ventured around to see around. While most of the attractions were partly affected, Boudhanath Stupa stood strong and high as if it was just another day, there were only few patches of paints that has fallen. I came to know that it was slightly effected with second big EQ but there are already in process of completing the minute restoration work.The Boudhanath Stupa is an amazing place to be any time of the day, you could feel the positive vibe of the place as soon as you enter. There are many good restaurants, cafes and local joints to hand around too.Make sure you visit it when you are in Kathmandu.The Entry Fee is NPR150 (Foreign Nationals) and NPR 40 (SAARC Nationals)

Boudhnath Stupa of Buddhist heritage. It is a Buddha Stupa situated at the center of Kathmandu. Very beautiful place to be visited. The Stupa is surrounded by the shops selling mementos and other material of tourist interest. I am not aware of the present position after recent earth quake in Nepal.

Holding up after the quake...literally. I have visited the Great Stupa many times including a stay of three weeks when I circum-ambulated the Stupa daily. So it was with trepidation that I approached in June.It was a relief to see that it was mainly intact and the spire was still upright but under scaffolding. This meant there were no prayer flags flying from the spire which did detract from the atmosphere giving the whole place a less vibrant and joyous feel than usual. It was heartening to see monks, nuns and pilgrims worshipping as usual.The buildings around the Stupa seemed OK mostly and the cafes, restaurants and shops were open as usual. However, one of the monasteries on the Stupa circle was damaged and closed.I do not think it will be long before the repairs are complete and Boudhanath will be back to its best and worth a 5 dot review.
Amazing Place!. Very nice place with such a wonderful energy ! A place that all budhist must visit !Nepal is a beautiful country :)
same same but different. It was probably nicer before the earthquake, but if you have been to many stupas, this one just the same, but under reconstruction
The Circle Walk. Great Artichiteture and can easily access from Down toen Kathmandu Area. Once you are top the stup has to be carefull slipping off specially if it's rained else you can walk around.
Massive and very impressive if a bit crowded.. A good monument to see. Lots of Monks and music - the site is massive and different to other Stupas.
Bodh Temple. It is the temple of Bodha. It is on the height and one need to go through number of stairs to visit the same.

Guardian of Buddhist history in Nepal. Situated very near to the Thamel area, the stupa comes across as a surpise when managing through the narrow lanes of the approach. Once there, the serene environment hits you like a breeze scented by fresh flowers. The area is a mix of old and new with the Stupa standing proudly in the center. The area has a lot of small cafes which offer delectable fares at a very affordable price. The area around the stupa abounds with schools of traditional Buddhist paintings called Thangka. You can visit these if you have time and see the master craftsmen at work creating masterpieces.
Where Tibetans gather. One of my favourite attractions in Kathmandu. Remember to visit the many rooftop cafe or restaurant during sunset. The view from top is absolutely amazing!

Peace by Prayer and Shopping!. Numerous people walking around the Stupa while chanting in good faith. What you get is utter positivity and peace. BOUDHANATH STUPA. Boudhanath Stupa, 7 km east of the downtown Kathmandu. Nepal's most distinctive monuments. Simple, massive and powerful, rises above the number of buildings. The painted eyes gazing solemnly over the countryside. Stupas are essential to Buddhism as the cross is to Christianity, a tangible symbol of the Buddha's enlightened mind.With a diameter exceeding 100 meters and a wall-to-wall length roughly equaling a football field, Boudha is among the largest stupa in the world- certainly the biggest in Nepal. The monument rises 36 metres above the street. The form and the alternated squares and circles represents a three-dimensional mandala, which is comprised of abstract religious concepts. Every portion has symbolic significance: the base, dome, square harmika, spire, and pinnacle represent the five elements; the 13 tiers of the spire stand for the stages to enlightenment, while the umbrella atop is the symbol of royalty. Boudhanatha is both an eye of calm within capital's dusty pandemonium and a sanctuary of Tibetan Buddhist culture amid a nation dominated by Nepal Hindus. Throughout its narrow streets, you can see posters of smiling Dalai Lama, Tibetan folk-medicine stores, traditional artisans' workshops, and restaurants serving everything from yak-cheese to Everest brand beer.The painted, bow-shaped eyes of Boudhanath are variously described as mysterious, indifferent, compassioinate and knowing.

My fave place in KTM. Just go - its the most amazing place to visit. Find one of the rooftop restaurants around the edge and head up there overlooking the stupa, eat momo's and drink tongba. I head here every time I am in KTM
You have to visit here !. Buddhist Culture Amazing ! You will hear the Buddhist Bells and the scents of the Prayer Sticks ! Its a different world out there ! Om Mani Padme Hum :)

Boudhanath Stupa!!!. Walk Clockwise, I repeat, clockwise. If you follow Bhudha religion, you can have good satisfaction by going to Stupa and praying, while you are walking clockwise. If you want to stretch your muscles, you can have good walk either for 30 mins or an hour as you wish. Lots of shops and restaurants around Stupa. One of the most remarkable Buddhist sites in the world. I have a deep connection to this magical location. I practice Tibetan Buddhism and had been told of the beauty and power of this place but nothing prepared me. Before and after a two-week trek in Nepal I visit Boudhanath. I circumambulated the stupa with 100s of Nepalis, Tibetans, monks and nuns from all over the world. Boudhanath is the home to 50 temples. It is also a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Even if you are not a Buddhist I am sure you will feel the peace and certainly admire the beauty. There was only minor damage during the earthquake I am told, so please add it to your next journey. For the art appreciators, there are several art academies which make and sell beautiful traditional Buddhist art called thangkas.

One of the most fascinating world's spot. We were in the square in April, not that hot, but warm. The place is astonishing, emanating a sense of energy and spirituality. The Stupa is surrounded by thousands of local merchandise shops. You can buy all kind of typical clothes for a couple of Euros. The people is amiable and the fancy pray's flags give a hint of a Carnival atmosphere, for a western. Great place to visit.
Life Changing. Awesome place to see locals worshiping. One of the largest stupas in Nepal. There are lots of people walking around from the entire world.

Mezmerizing!. Regardless of where you stand, the eyes of Buddha will always be with you. Immerse in the sounds and smells of the shops, surrounding the stupa. Walk into one of the tankha studios and take one of these beautiful pieces of art with you.A truly stunning place.

It's great seeing the Buddhist pilgrims doing their rituals. I also really like finding a nice, quiet rooftop restaurant and sitting back with an Everest beer to relax and watch the world go by.A place I visit every time I'm in Nepal and I can't wait to visit again.
love it... Too bad that we cannot see the buddha eyes ( Recontruction/recovery)..however the i like the experience when we go to the roof of the temple and got blessing from the monk..

Enormous Stupa. This was an amazing place to visit. Many many monks and nun, as well as ordinary people, were circling the stupa, turning prayer wheels and chanting prayers as they went. The Stupa is circled by gift shops selling all sorts of souvenirs. It is then circled by Manasteries for the monks and nuns who come from all over the world to study and worship here. Well worth a visit. Well worth a visit. Unfortunately, the very top is closed to visitors post earthquake damage, but nevertheless still a great place to see. Dont forget to go into a tiny cellar at the side of the Stupa, and light a candle for a loved one. I was in Nepal for disaster relief work, but tourists are badly needed to help the economy. 17 and mezmorized. Came to Nepal in grade 12 with my Global perspectives class in highschool and this was one of the coolest places i have ever been. There was fun little shops that just kept going back until you had to almost crawl which was neat ( specifically a little bead and jewelry one). Favourite spot in Kathmandu. A must visit when you're travelling to Kathmandu. This is the place where you get a true whiff of the Nepali culture and experience firsthand how this beautiful mountain nation has managed to create a perfect mix of spirituality and tourism.It was the first stop in our daylong tour of the city's Stupas, temples and durbar squares. The moment you walk in, the "Om mani padme hum" music surrounds you and tells your brain that you've entered a sacred place that is a sanctuary inside a rather busy world outside its walls. Lots of shops all around the circle walkway (which i believe needs to be covered clockwise). Had a lovely early morning breeze during our visit, which made the experience even better.Plenty of helpful and friendly faces all around. You can feed pigeons which gather at a point halfway through the walk. You can climb the stairs of the stupa to get a more majestic view of the golden peak. Remember to buy a CD of the songs that play around the stupa, so you can relive the ambiance later in your living room. Boudhanath was definitely one of the favourites of our trip to Nepal

One of the most frequented Buddhist sanctuaries you must visit while in Nepal. The stupa of Boudhanath is the largest one of Nepal. It's one of the most sacred buddhist pilgrimage site. The white dome is believed to contain the relic of one of the past Buddhas "Kashyapa". The white color in Buddhism symbolizes "compassion". There are two eyes of Buddha in a square part just aver the dome symbolizing "wisdom" and "action" with a nose similar to a question mark in between, which actually is not a question mark, it's the number "1" in Nepalese, symbolizing "Unity". The upper part of the stupas has been destroyed by the quake of 25 april 2015 and is in renovation.This is a must visit place in Kathmandu valley if you ever go to Nepal. Surrounded of numerous buddhist monasteries, Boudhnath is one of the Buddhist sanctuaries where you can witness hundreds of pilgrims and monks turn around the stupa with a prayer wheel or chaplet all the day but it's more frequented in the morning and evening.The terrace restaurants around the stupa provide a chance to observe the grandiose and beauty of the stupa.

feelng happy. when i went to the u(stupaa).i was really happy.i was going to the stupa with my friends.we saw the view of kathmandu valley is really nice.we clicked the many photos in stupa.art of the stupa is really good.i impress the beautiful eyes of the budhdha.many shops are open for shopping.we bought the many beatyfull things like statue of the budhdha,locket,bangle,keyring etc.it is the most important visiting place of the kathmandu.

Tip: Go Early. A buzzing cacophony of monks, devotees, tourists and pigeons, this was one of my favourite places in Kathmandu. It's a lot to take in, though, and I'd recommend a couple of visits to fully appreciate this massive stupa. Another tip is to go early in the morning; 7am or earlier, to experience the locals' prayer rituals (later in the day it's a lot more touristy, and a lot less awe-inspiring). I've also heard that going in time for the evening prayers is amazing, but I didn't get a chance to. There are loads of monasteries around the stupa and I wish I'd taken the time to check them out (during our visit, however, it was too hot for our Scandinavian thermostats for us to do anything for more than an hour at a time). So, to sum up: Go Early and Take Your Time.

Beautiful . It's beautiful temple with stunning architecture. It's so peaceful to be at the Stupa and feels like time has slow down and you just want to sit and experience the peacefulness of this place. The view from the rooftop is stunning.

Revisiting Boudh. The Boudh Dome and Stupa always impresses with its sheer size and the beautiful eyes that watch you. A great place to pick up some unique and exotic curios, quite reasonably priced (after the customary bargaining). A delightful experience and a photographers delight. There is however a dire need to quickly complete the ongoing digging and repair work that seems to be going on forever. The stench near the entrance/stairs leading to the Boudh was unbearable and the standard of cleanliness for a monument like this was found to be wanting.

Must go here and let peace fill your heart. Must go here if you are in Kathmandu. This is a famous tibetan Stupa, you have probably see photos, or films of the place. Go and do the holw walk around the stupa and let peace fill your heart.

Absolutely Amazing!. The sheer size of the stupa in the centre of Kathmandu is absolutely amazing. The atmosphere around the stupa is great, although there are obviously a lot of tourists it's lovely to see locals moving round the stupa with various offerings. Aa very lovely, friendly place.

Gorgeous!. The biggest Stupa in the world? I am not religious, but surely appreciated the size and wonder of the place!

My Fave Place in Kathmandu. I have visited Nepal 4 times in the past 6 years.. And never missed to see Boudha in every single trip... This place gives me such peaceful feeling, with Buddhist religious music in ambience, monks everywhere, local people and foreigners walking around in circle with their prayers.. Boudhanath. The Stupa is on the ancient trade route from Tibet which enters the Kathmandu Valley by the village of Sankhu in the northeast corner. Nice place to be and get yourself clicked in traditional nepalese dress.

Stunning. Such a beautiful peaceful place to visit... The best place to sit and watch the world walk by...Boudha Stupa has many lovely rooftop cafes where you can sit and waste the day away watching the thousands of people who walk around the stupa all day long. My favourite place in Kathmandhu...
Beautiful Stupa. So beautifl to see all the prayer flags fyling...now we are praying for all those who still live there as they rebuild

Most of the small shops are opened and every night there are prayers. Hope the situation will recover soon.

A must-visit in Kathmandu. Very nice place, you must visit. It is surrounded by small shops and a few nice terraces where you can have a coffee or meals. I couldn't see inside as it was being rehabilitated due to the quake.

Lucky enough to see prior to the earthquake. The sheer size of the stupa is amazing, for those who love architecture this area in which the stupa is located is abundant in awesome architecture. om mani padme hum............. it was the most beautiful place in nepal,kathmandu.there is a beautiful restaurant also beside this stupa.its looks heavenly from that restaurant.i cant remember the name,but that was upstairs and made of wood.

A spiritual shopping paradise. If you are into shopping for Buddhist artefacts and prayer items, look no further than Boudha. Visit the many monasteries there or circumnambulate the Great Stupa, catch your breath and enjoy the view as you partake of the delightful local and western meals and beverages of the many good cafes, there's plenty to excite the eyes, ears and taste buds.However, it was dusty due to the renovations (tiling around the stupa) which prevented the turning of a portion of the prayer wheels around the Stupa. However, these should be completed by now (but don't don't what other damage was caused by the earthquakes of 25 April and 12 May).

Allways a must see in Kathmandu. Me and my staff spend many time here running video and photography. It´s a amazing place with some Budhist monastery inside. People are very friendly and sellers are not pushy or harass you. Also you can find good restaurants and Bar inside.

Stunning to view. Boudanatha StupaWe came as part of an organized trip with our trekking company, so our tickets to get in were included in that. It's pretty big stupa - no where near as large as Anuradhapura in Sri Lanka for instance, but pretty darned big.Walk around the exterior, turning the prayer wheels and taking a look at the various shops and restaurants that will allow you to contribute further to the Nepalese economy. Then go through the small gate, by the temple and walk around the terrace - this is much more spectacular, you'll walk under the prayer flags, and see the surround buildings from a different viewpoint. Be sure to take the information leaflet provided as you walk in for further information.
Awesome. Wonderfully spiritual atmosphere (even for a rampant atheist). Great Tibetan art and furniture shopping

Amazing site. You cant imagine that a historic site is nested within the confines of a mini fort city, from the main streets you would never know its there, once you pass through the entrance you see this fabulous huge stupa. we stayed in a guest house opposite so we could capture the after the tourists have left hours when all the locals and monks join in their daily exercise, wonder to witness

Put at the top of the list. You don't have to be religious to appreciate the Boudhanath. Even for just a quick visit, it doesn't take long to get lost in the feeling of the community surrounding the Stupa. The candles, the chance to join in the turning of prayer wheels, it is a place that engages every sense and that carries you away from the business of the city not far away. It is a place that sticks with you well beyond the visit and that should be a top of any list when coming to Kathmandu.

Serene Stupa. I walked down to this stupa from Hyatt. After negotiating the narrow lanes, I was amazed to see the awesome stupa standing majestically in the centre of a bazaar area. There was dense smoke rising from one corner where some sacred evening rituals were being carried out. I joined the locals as they queued to enter the premises. I followed them in reverentially moving with my hands the mystical cylinders having sacred encryptions. I circumambuled the stupa and spent a long time soaking in the serene atmosphere. I am happy to learn that this stupa has withstood the quakes. Worth visiting. The bazaar outside has lots of curio shops and restaurants.

Essential experience,. Spending some time just watching, looking and absorbing this site is an essential part of visiting Kathmandu. Walk around the base, and respectfully observe worshippers. I took about 20 photos,and a movie clip, as the flags in front of the stupa are just the ticket: colourful, active and look superb against the brilliant white of the stupa. One restaurant overlooks the area, with four tables and chairs perched right on the edge of a balcony, under umbrellas, so you can catch lunch as you catch the scene.

I wish i could give more than 5 stars. I was mystified by this site. I arrived early, so as to beat the crowds and basically was there with a few monks and a few other travellers. I really don't know how to explain it properly, but there is something very special here. The smells, the sounds of the chimes, the stillness and the reverent spirit all really touched my heart and soul. I highly recommended
excellent view. i have visited many places in kathmandu during my kathmandu visit. i found boudhanath stupa really nice and very clean. i like alot

Go do this. This is a must see. A mystical Tibetan monument which is well worth exploring. A quintessential Himalayan site, surrounded by plenty of shops selling knick knacks, as well as cafes.Hopefully, it is still standing after the quake

The essence of Kathmandu. We visited the Boudhanath one week before the recent earthquake and thank heavens it is unharmed. To join the faithful in circling the Stupa, even if not a Buddhist, is a highly spiritual experience. Somehow that circling seems like the essence of Nepalese culture. The first sight of the "all-seeing eye" from the main street, or any of the back streets seems bizarre but somehow makes sense after circling - and the shops and restaurants around it are amazing! We will be back.

Even after devastating earth quake, a quiet place to be. Luckily The Stupa did not suffer during the recent earth quakes. A great place to get initiated to Buddisme, inviting to meditate and reflect. If looking for gifts, stores here are advised over stores in the Thamel.

Huge Buddhist stupa. For somebody who has never visited a Buddhist stupa, I was totally charmed on seeing this one. It is huge and inspiring. Don't forget to take a walk around the Stupa, turning around the bells and chanting 'Om Mani Padme Hum'.
A must see. experience the feelings that evolve when you walk around it. It is phenomenally big and awe inspiring

Great place to visit. Boudhanath stupa is one of the biggest stupa in the world where you can feel peace and spiritual.Love to visit time by time. To all the traveler suggest to visit once in a lifetime.

world heritage. this heritage has it's own story behind.however it's one of the amazing thing that nepalese had made long time before.we are proud of being the part of it.i like this boudhanath stupa very much,because it has the meditative powers.every one should visit this place for the peace of the mind

Beautiful Stupa but that's it.. Boudha or Boudhanath Stupa is beautiful, it stands high and mighty, unaffected by the earthquake but that's all there is to it.It's a shoppin area more than a spiritual place. All around the stupa there are shops and some have very beautiful things but then it takes all the attention from the Stupa itself. There is a cafe called Mochiko Cafe and that's my best memory of Boudha. They serve excellent buff momos, and buff shapale (sort of a deep fried meat pie) ! And the hot chocolate is amazing! Apart from that, I love monasteries and Stupas but I like them quiet and peaceful.Also sometimes there are guards who take money from you to enter and sometimes there aren't, so be aware of that.

Happy Birthday Buddah. Though there was some places we could not go to because of the earthquake, it was amazing to see this stupa up close and personal. And the extra people gathered because it was Buddah's Birthday.

Huge Buddhist stupa. Nice place to visit. Just remember to go clockwise :) Walked here down the hill from crematory (took about 40min) and got back to city centre by taxi. There is a small entrance fee, about 2-5 euros as I remember.

Worth a visit if you're in the area. It's an important stupa, large and impressive, but I wouldn't make a trek all the way out there to see it. Someone told me it was "really beautiful" but I walked around it and clicked a few pictures, and 10 minutes later was on my way.
Very beautiful stupa. The space was nice and open, a true landmark of Nepal. I would definitely recommend getting a guide for your tour! There's lots of history in the architecture!
Simple beauty and peace. One of my favourite places to visit in Nepal, having visited several times. I always enjoy the beauty and relaxation I find here.
my favorite place in Nepal. Just love love love this peaceful stupa. Could spent hours there watching the world go by, watching the Tibetan worshipers in their beautiful traditional clothes !

Beautiful Stupa and square around it. Most beautiful stupa near Kathmandu. Surrounded by temples, artisan shops, small restaurants. You can find more than 20 Tibetan monasteries around Boudhanath. From the terrace of some of them, you can have a beautiful sight of the stupa. You can go in without problem. A lot of Tibetan people are seen walking around the stupa making the "kora", or a type of pilgrimage or meditation in the Tibetan Buddhist tradition. It is performed by circumbulating a temple, or any sacred site. So, you can see lots of people doing so, and thus it feels very authentic.
one of the biggest stuppas. a beautiful walk and above the monument with 3 temples around it. feel the smells and move the player cylinders to feel the buddist religion.

A humbling experience. A must see. I'm heartbroken to see the devastation from the earthquake a couple of weeks after we were there, hope it's survived relatively intact, a beautiful place which leaves you feeling at peace with the world.

Good Place to relax and see history. The serene and Colourful atmosphere, it was walking distance from the hotel, Unfortunately the stupa is damaged it was an excellent monument of history , we hope the world contributes to rebuilt the monument to its previous glory

Festival made it extra-special. While it was a cool building, what made it an excellent experience was the festival and people that accompanied it (I'm not sure on which days there is a festival, but we went on the first monday of the year). It felt very interactive, with prayer wheels that you can spin as you walk around the stupa, or smoke coming up from things that looked like pyres. We paid 300 NRS to get there from the Thamel area, not sure what the proper price is, but that seemed about right, don't pay significantly more than that.Visited May 2015

A must see. The pictures do not di it justice. quite a sight with sounds and after climbing the stairs at the top people are burning in ceremony intensions etc but it adds to the mystique and culture of the place. the shops are neat with singing bowls. quite a sight to see and not to be missed

Amazing Stupa in Boudha. Regret that i didn't review earlier after our visit 1 January 2015.This stupa and the surrounding area might not in the same condition as we saw several months ago, because of the devastating Gorkha earhquake.Located about 11 km from the center and northeastern outskirts of Kathmandu,and about 15 minutes by car to the east, via the Boudhanath Sadak.The stupa has a massive mandala makes it one of the largest spherical stupas in Nepal, and considered one of the biggest stupas in the world.The influx of large populations of refugees from Tibet has seen the construction of over 50 Tibetan Gompas (Monasteries) around Boudhanath. As of 1979, Boudhanath is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. We had our lunch at one rooftop restaurant whilst observing some kind of monk pilgrimage and ceremonies being held on the Boudhanath Stupa.This is one of the best historical site in Kathmandu , a visit is highly recommended.However , if there's damage to the stupa and its surrounding , because of the 25 April 2015 earhquake, the Nepal government could restore it to its original state.

Shayakon. A short taxi ride from Kathmandu. Early morning is the best time to visit. Lots of Tibetans here. Shops selling Tibetan religious objects and souvenirs but the price is higher than in other places.The stupa is very big. When you are here walk like a Tibetan, in a clockwise direction around it.

Circle of people, praying, lighting up candle. Visited nepal for a mission trip early may aftermath the quake that has took close to 8000 people life. Come upon boudhanath on the 7th May, and there's a circle of people gathering holding candle singing and praying for the safety and well being for the family of the quake victim, emotion build up, humanity and faith in people are restore at least to see so many foreigner and local gathering and helping to light up the candle praying together for the nation and the people itself. You will come back stronger and Better Nepal . Note : this place is totally undamaged so feel free to come anytime,in fact the best time to visit nepal for me personally is NOW when they are badly in need of us to Come and not only as a tourist but as a world people and friend or them . Cheers

A nice half day visit. This is a nice half say activity. After taking in the sights of the stupa grab a coffee or beer at one of the cafés. If you want to be sneaky and not pay just pop through one of the shops that boarder the stupa and exit through into the square surrounding it ;-)

wonderful. We loved Boudhanath Stupa, we spun all 94 prayer wheels, we have (had?) prayer flags with the names of loved ones blessed and hung, and we revelled in the reverance and joy so many others found, by being here. Sadly now damaged and i truly hope restored to formere wonder! We were there Aug 2013.

The eyes of lord Buddha are watching you.. Fantastic place to visit, I only hope it was not too badly damaged. We had a lovely lunch overlooking the stupa (which is one of the biggest in the world) and aftrwards walked around the structure taking lots of photos - it is really photogenic from whatever angle you take your shots. It is difficult not to take an interesting photo here.
Serene!. Right in the middle of a bustling village square stands the stupa. So simple yet so majestic. Seeing the monks on the rooftop in the midst of their prayers and rituals was a privilege!

Not a place to be alone--fabulous experience.. We visited with our guide on the last day of a festival in early April of 2015 and the crowds were wall to wall and wonderful to see and be a part of! All ages from babes in arms to the elderly were lined up to spin the prayer wheels as they wound around the stupa to the top and back. We are hoping it was not too badly damaged by the recent earthquake and wish all the best in their labors to cleanup and repair the area.

a good place to visit. This is an interesting place to visit it is a Buddhist temple that is very big. you walk around it and see all the religious stuff. after a while it is a bit boring though that said there is some good food shops there in the square.

Another one off the bucket list. I arrived in the middle of 6th annual praying festival of Nepal, so the area was filled with Buddhist devotees and monks, in crimson and orange robes, chanting prayers all day. It added the level of magic for me, as I was there, partly for spiritual reasons. I also visited the stupa once during the evening, it was beautiful.
Nice ambience. Boudhanath stupa is one of the best place to visit while one is here at Kathmandu, it has nice environment and beautiful surrounding

Extraordinary Site. One of the main religious sites in Kathmandu the stupa is extraordinary and well worth the visit. Not to easy to find, it's worth paying a few hundred rupees for a taxi-and having the driver wait for you. I didn't find it particularly peaceful and early in the morning very few of the shops were open-not necessarily a bad thing-but there were relatively few people: a plus. Do go inside!

Living devotion. This is more than a tourist attraction, it is a working temple. It makes you feel humble when you see all the devotees of all ages walk around the stupa.Stay strong Nepal & PrayforNepal.
Beautiful just before quake. We visited the day before the quake -- it was beautiful and inspiringThe history and symbolism, and religious significance made it a must see in Kathmandu

Peace n awesome. after a year,this beautiful place still in my mind clearly.i love this place so much.recall back,i with my frenz take local bus there.in view of language issue, we miss a stop but finally the bus driver vry helpful send us back to this place.when we step in and seeing these,touch my soul..i dunno how to describe...at the same time, on that day do have ceremony on this place,the chanting really make our mind peace.we almost spent a day here.after walk around stupa,we had our lunch here.beside the stupa,there had a lot of restaurant.we had a cup of coffee and rest there with this place..really peaceful...peace n simple about life come out from my mind...i miss this place.so much.
Heaven. One of the most wonderful nights of my life, walking around the stupa and hearing the Mantra of Avolkiteshvara playing.
Buddhist culture. little far from Thamel where i lived but, it is really nice place to visit in Kathmandu. Buddhist holy place where i feel peace when visited.
Buddhist centre. Most sacred spot to Buddhism in Nepal, together with Lumbini. Lots if monasteries around that one can freely visit. Good place for shopping too

Boudhanath Stupa market is great. A place to visit for buying different artifacts and iconography of Budddhism. The shops around the Stupa has a lot of products to buy that can decorate your home. A must visit. There is no parking and but you may take a taxi to visit the place should you not have a driver. Approach road is not well maintained though by the Kathmandu administration

Stupa Bodnath has everything. A wonderful place to watch people, see volonteers wash street dogs, take a cop of coffee on one of the roof-top-cafés, buy a lot of unnecessary souvenirs and take a walk round the stupa together with a lot of buddists.

Impressive Buddhist monument. The stupa is really impressive, with the colourful flags and watching eyes in its four sides. The devouted pilgrims circulating the Boudanath provides a different sight. The coffeshops nearby have good view of the stupa, and the variety is quite wide. A memorable visit indeed

perfect place. We have been there with our group of fren the stupa was awesome and great design. We enjoyed our short trip there. We can see lots of tourist and Buddhist monk around the place . Stupa was very clean but now I heard the Nepal earthquake damaged some of the small stupa I am very worried .

Most beautiful site in Nepal. Boudhnath Stupa is probably one of the most beautiful things I've seen in my life. Its majestic and dominates the city by its height. I suggest going there mid afternoon so you can enjoy the sunset and see the light changing on the stupa's face. We went up to a rooftop restaurant to enjoy the serene atmosphere. Try to stay until the night where monks light up candles and pray.

A must see. This is a fabulous place to visit. You get to see and experience both a culture and religious site. Being a world heritage site by UNESCO it didn't disappoint. The day I was there someone had donated money and they where repainting the stupa, which was incredible to witness.
peace. tourist visit to get the peace of mind. the area is mostly populated by Buddhist monks and people of Tibet migrated from Tibet from Chinese dynasty.
very amazing. I was in Bothna when it was a meeting of Buddhist, and there is a lot of people everywhereyou have no problem to approach them when they pray

Still standing - after the earth quake. Boudhanath stupa is one of the few survivors of the April 25 and 26, 2015 earth quakes. The area is also good for shopping Tibetan and Nepali crafts. While visiting the temple all shops and restaurants were closed and stayed closed for at least 5 days after.
Culture and Religion in One Site. We had a wonderful guide that gave us the entire history of this religious and historical site. It is well worth the visit.

Place of Peace. Hard to describe the energy that surrounds this beautiful space and the unity I felt with all mankind as I walked beside monks going about their daily business, tourists and locals alike. The magnificent sounds of bells, whirring prayer wheels, shuffling feet and muttered prayers, flood the senses. It's a place of peace and love that you can feel deep within your soul.

Fabulous place to see and hang out. After you walk around the Stupa, head to one of the roof top cafes for a meal or drink. It's a lovely place to spend the evening. One could even spend time in shops around the Stupa where you can buy allot of traditional art and gifts.

Wonderful place of peace and beauty. In light of the recent tragedy I wanted to share my wonderful experience and show the beauty of Nepal and its peoples...Fantastic experience. I was there when the Monks were chanting in their temple next to Stupa...so serene...went up to stupa and groups of Nepalese had to have their picture taken with me...a 5'7" blonde American...I was taller than any of them...some by almost a foot...be sure to go into the large prayer wheel area...and buy the charms from the Monks who guard the large prayer wheel...I bought a dozen charms, and my guide talked them into taking a picture with me...
peace and pleaseant. the stupa is near rushed market, inside there is a ticket fee and very peace, can sit there long in such peace. it was a gud place to visit. all around is cafe souvenir shop

Beautiful site with an amazing story!. We went to the Boudhanath Stupa as part of a day of sightseeing in Kathmandu. The stupa itself is so much bigger than we were expecting and we really enjoyed walking around and taking pictures from different angles. We had lunch in one of the restaurants located in the square around the stupa and were able to enjoy the views while relaxing as well. While there were a lot of people at the site, it never felt crazed or rushed - everyone took their time to appreciate the beauty and inspiring story behind the stupa.Like most sites in Nepal, there is an entrance fee, but it's well worth the price for an afternoon spent soaking up the culture!
Not to be missed. We went in evening it was crowed but very nice experience. Lot of shops are around selling tibetian artefacts.
Very old and beautiful. In and around stupa having a lucnh watching the same will be very nice. The history behind the Boudhstupa constructed there seems to be correct.

OMG! Amazingly heavenly. Went in and was amazed by the vibes and peacefulness. Very crowded but all was so calm. You have to buy tickets to go in.Ask someone how to go about the ritual and walk around the Stupa.People are very kind and helpful.

A must see World Heritage Site in Kathmandu.. About 10 kilometres from Thamel is the Boudhanath Stupa just one of the seven must see world heritage sites in and around Kathmandu. At 36 metres high, this three dimensional Mandala is the largest Stupa, and the centre of Tibetan Buddhist culture, in Nepal. There's a multitude of shops, restaurants, artisan workshops etc around the periphery of the Stupa, all under the central enlightened eyes of Buddha Although you can freely walk around, its best to negotiate a local guide so as to extract the most from your visit. The surrounding streets are also well worth a stroll.If you're into photography, history, religion, culture etc, you'll have a ball for the for your 250NPR entry fee.

Astonishing and magic spot. A gem for the 5 senses.. This place is full of magic where diverse energies and gents converge. A sacred place for Buddhists - yet for anyone looking for spiritual inspiration. You've got to experience it and go there if you plan to travel to Kathmandu.On the other hand there's a bunch of good restaurants and local shops at and around the square.If you are a tourist and you would like to visit the square in more than one occasion, there's a way of coming in no paying for the ticket every single time. Just go pass the big arch (the tourists' main entrance) and look for the next street on the left with lots of local shops and sellers. That one will take you right to the square.

Wonderfully Peaceful. In the madhouse of Kathmandu this is an oasis of calm and peace. The Stupa itself is very beautiful, bedecked with prayer flags and having delightful little triangular gardens within the outer walls. It is principally Tibetan, and there is a monastery overlooking the Stupa. Road around it is pedestrianised and peaceful, with some lovely shops and rooftop restaurants overlooking the Stupa. The airport is nearby and it is awesome to see the planes appearing on one side of the Stupa and apparently flying behind it as they take off.
Must visit in Kathmandu. Brilliant place and a short distance away from the Pashupathinath temple. Great place to watch people and culture.
Good to see it!!. It was very interesting to see it. one should not miss if he or she is in this country. Its a amazing place n whoever pass by will enjoy this.

Important stop in Kathmandu. Visiting this enormous stupa (the largest in the world) and the temples in its complex, and turning some of the prayer wheels, gives a good exposure to the Tibetan Buddhist culture that is one big component of Nepal. You will get more out of it if you have a guide. I wish we had had more time there.

Good place for visit. our group all are visit this stupa early morning this very good place for sightseeing near the many shop and restaurant we are buying many thing in this place this is the historical place

Worth a visit on a day tour of KTM. It was a nice place for us to stop and have lunch at a rooftop cafe. Around the stupa, which is similar to the one at the Swayambanath (monkey) temple are a number of shops and some great people watching. If you go to the monkey temple and are limited on time, you could skip this one and not feel bad. If you can't make it to the monkey temple, try this one out. The "eyes of the Buddha" are fascinating!
Tibetan Singing Bowls. Amazing place! Lots of things to see, and you must turn the prayer wheels at least once. Also great cafes all round with great views and photo opportunities

Interesting. It was interesting to watch the faithful walk around this very large Stupa. I thinkthat many Tibetans make this pilgrimage.There are many shops around it, selling Bhuddist trinkets and souvenirs.Worth a visit.
very peacefull place. we did kathmandu city tour along with other heritage place, this one is our favorite in all . A huge stupa with lots of flair and monks. a nice place to bilssout your mind :)
Fun. Good times, good new thing to discover. See it part of a tour to see the city and see more. Nice nice

Evening Sightseeing. If you are at Kathmandu, You Should Visit this Unique Stupa. You can Visit its 3 Tiers if you start your tour early in the Evening. Locals come to Pray here. Its a Crowded Place but well Maintained. Also has eating Joints and Wifi Lounges besides.

Impressive temple. This is a spectacular temple and you can walk all around it and get some great photos. Other than that it is mostly an area with lots of stalls and shops to buy all sorts of trinkets! There are temples with monks chanting which are also very interesting
Must see. loved the monks circumambulating and the rooftop restaurants. whats not to like? Lots of shops and butter lamps

majestic. Wide, traditional and majestic! Last time I visited that place, there are natives/tibetans doing full body prostrations repeatedly towards the big stupa..
