A must see in Kathmandu. I suggest that this is the best sight to visit in Kathmandu, particularly if you want to see something of the Tibetan community in Nepal. The entrance fee is 150 rupees but this is well worth it particularly if you are going to do some shopping and have a rooftop meal there. You are faced with a lot of options for the latter. I suggest that before deciding on a meal venue you go into the stupa and go to the top level and walk round the stupa. This way you get a much better perspective than choosing from shop level.

Definitely worth a visit. A great place to visit. Tibetan music in the background and a nice atmosphere. An interesting Tibetan Buddhist stupa. Lots of Tibetan oriented shops. Good restaurants surround it. I first visited it in 2001, and when I went back to Nepal this time with different friends, I urged that this was one of the best sites to see in Kathmandu. Definitely worth visiting.

One of the most beautiful Buddhist temples in the world. This is a must on your Kathmandu To Do list! Boudha is located in the heart of Buddhist Kathmandu and is a pilgrimage spot for Buddhists and tourists alike. The temple itself is breath-taking and the area is surrounded by many beautiful monasteries. Try to get there early or late to avoid crowds.

An amazing and vibrant religious and historical area. An amazing Stupa that you can climb onto and walk around. Situated in a large public square and surrounded by a large collection of shops, restaurants and activity. A beautifully colourful area and experience, must see.If you ask your taxi driver to take you to one of the side entrances, you can enter the area through the streets and alleys like the locals and avoid having to pay the relatively steep foreigner entrance change at the main street.

There is nowhere quite as nice as in here. I don't know what was it, but i would come there every evening and sit next to Boudhath. Best place in whole Kathmandu. There are monasteries, monks, spirituality - all that you need to love the place.

A BIG Stupa. This is the biggest Stupa in Kathmandu, and I think Nepal, and worth visiting for an hour. We went on a sunny and warm day, and with the sun shining down on that huge expanse of white-washed construction, sun glasses and cool clothes are a must! There are a number of temples around the area, and many cafes/restaurants with rooftop areas to relax and take in the view. One stupa visit in Kathmandu is definitely warranted, just pick which one suits your itinerary. And if you must turn each and every prayer wheel, add an extra 20 minutes...

Awesome. People offering prayers...in large congregation but yet so silent..I s did not enter the premises but enjoyed it architecture and the way it was built and surrounding by roof top cafes overlooking the place..

Most amazing place. Going around with small shops and temples around you can spend a half a day shopping for good paintings music CDs and lots of traditional items of Nepal. It is Devine serve traffic free place. A must visit.

Amazing must see. We have visited this site many times in the past few years. We have never had anyone ask us for money or to show us around. The entrance fee is minimal and worth paying. Whatever time you go you will see the faithful doing ' Kora' around the Stupa, but dusk is the busiest time. It is a wonderful peaceful atmosphere and there are a few temples which you can also visit. You can easily spend a whole day there and eat in the cafés and restaurants which sell both European and Nepalese foods. You can wander around the shops and stroll through the markets beyond the Stupa grounds, where you will happen across other temples. You may happen across a Llama or two who for a small donation will give you a blessing, or you can buy prayer flags which they will tie from the top of the Stupa. This is a good place to buy Tibetan goods such as Art or Mala's. I would thoroughly recommend taking your time and drinking in the energy of the place.
try and avoid major events. Unfortunately visited on New year's eve April 13th! Packed out yet great spot to see, have a coffee upstairs in a cafe for great views

Beautiful. Disliked the touristic atmosphere in the shops around the stupa.Loved the stupa, walking around.Be careful and do not let anyone try to "help" you and show you around the stupa- they expect money!

Lovely!. The stupa was a lovely opportunity to see some of the Tibetan monks and influence in the city. We went near dusk and it allowed for some really lovely photos. There is also a stunning pair of prayer wheels near by which I could not get enough of. Lovely spot, definitely worth a visit.

Day at the Stupa. This was ok. It was cool to see a Stupa for the first time it's the 2nd biggest Stupa in the world and the market around it was fun. I ate with friends on a rooftop restaurant a very good view, but also hot in the sun!
Amazing Place. It is a nice place holy for budhist people. The most amazing thing is the budhist prayer and the food collection. You will find many nationalities from Budhism praying there.

Nothing to see...waste of time and energy...Similar to swayambhunath temple. This place is similar to swayambhunath temple. It is not well maintained and clean. And there is nothing much to see in the stupa. One should visit during evening. Parking facilities are poor, far and unsafe bcoz of traffic mismanagement, it is even too risky to cross the road. And they will charge u twice - 1st in the entrance gate and another after u entered the temple.
Great Atmosphere. I was there during the evening when the believers were going about their rituals. I was able to stand on the Stupa which provided a great view of the action.

best place in Kathmandu. This is the best area to stay and to spend your mornings and evenings, circling the stupa. This place is magical and just wonderful. Only thing I don't like is that hotels and restaurants start to put out these ugly illuminated advertisments - that should be forbidden on a world heritage site. It gives such a strange look on evenings.

Great Views. Climbing to the top of the stupa and taking pictures. Afterwards my sister and I stopped by the Dew Drops Cafe and took in the views from the roof-top while enjoying masala tea. Great photo opportunities.
Merger of religions. The old structures are fusion of Hinduism and Buddhism. Mostly built using wood and intensive carving. Worth visiting to get feel of commonality of faiths.

Calm energy. This place is spectacular. Walking around the stupa with monks and the devote is an energizing experience. The entrance fee is minimal. The shops and resteraunts s are really good. A nice reprieve from Thamel.
A must see in Nepal. This place is bit crowded. Still its a must see place in Kathmandu, Nepal. Visit in the morning time or evening time to avoid hot sun.

Impressive and accessible. Great to see a historic site that welcomes all-comers and having a large number of good cafe/ restaurants with rooftop views of the entire square only adds to the enjoyment. Time your visit at a mealtime of tea/coffee time, walk the square, spin the prayer wheels and climb to a rooftop bar and enjoy the view.

Must see. A huge pagoda with a natural spiritual ambience.
Lots of crowds all day and a bustling market area.
Try to visit earlier in the day to avoid crowds.
Its Huge... One Of The Huge Stupa Located inside City Just Near Airport, Very Crowded, So No Peace But Its Soothing.
Best sighseeing. Peaceful placd in the middle of crowded Kathmandu. You can climb the steps of the stupa and sit watching the crowd of buddhist pilgrims passing by. Great

Spectacular ... just spectacular. It was very peaceful walking around this spectacular structure amidst the chaos of the noisy Kathmandu streets. If you have time to just visit one place in Kathmandu, make it this place at all costs.
Bodnath Stupa. HUGE!! Lots of sites, shops, a Mondala gallery, monastery, and restaurants surround it! Great to just sip tea and people watch for a while as well!
walking a lot. Stunning old city and it was also their new year. The Hindu cremation site was very moving, and our plane trip round Everest unforgetable

it's a huge stupa but stuck right in the center of a very busy urban environment. The sites biggest claim is that it is the largest and does not have that more to over. the smaller more intimate stupas in the old city were of more intreats to me.

My Favourite Place in Kathmandu.. Bouddhanath Stupa is by far my most favourite place in Kathmandu. Its a beautiful, calm and clean place to visit whether you are Buddhist like myself or just a tourist. The area is very well cared for and there are plenty of places to eat and drink within the Stupa area as well as a lot of stalls selling all the usual stuff. I cannot recommend this area enough, if your in Kathmandu you must vist this place.

2nd Biggest Stupa in the world. Loved the Stupa, it is the 2nd Biggest in the world. It does cost to enter, I think it was only a couple hundred rupees. The shops around the Stupa a much more expensive then Thamel. It is worthy of a visit, also link this in with the Pashipatinath Temple is only a short cab ride or a 20m walk away.
Good.. It is a good place to visit. Any guide will make you visit this place. As always, keep good time at your hand before visiting this place.

Good karma. The spire of the stupa is visible from a distance, but the structure itself is hidden from view by encircling buildings. You suddenly exit an arcade and are confronted with an imposing dome and the peaceful eyes of the Buddha. Slowly circumnavigate the dome , turning the prayer wheels as you go, and add some merit to your karma. Just inside and to the left of the gate is a huge prayer wheel housed in its own little shrine. There are several monasteries around the main stupa, which are worth a visit if you have time. There are many souvenir shops ( good shawls, handicrafts and thangkas), and café/restaurants for the hungry and thirsty

a very special place. It is hard to comprehend the enormity of this stupa - though sitting with a nice drink at one of the many rooftop restaurants helps appreciate it's size. Also it is worth trying some of the local eateries outside of the stupa complex, to enjoy Tibetan delights such as Thentuk and Tongba. While you can visit for a day, I'd recommend staying overnight close by. Then set the alarm and get up just before dawn to walk around the stupa. You will need to brave the crowds, but this will give you a true experience of the importance of the stupa to people (during the day the stupa is quieter, but primarily visited by tourists).
Must visit!. My girlfriend and I loved this place.. We even stayed at a nearby monastery to be near. There are lots of shops around and good eats too..
Must visit. Clean and loved walking around the Stupa. We went to a cafe and sat at a place overlooking the stupa. Had an awesome time. Loved observing the going-ons in and around the Stupa.

Sightseeing tour of Bouddhanath. Bouddhanath is the world’s largest stupa. It is a site of great reneration to the Buddhists. Bouddhanath is the center of Tibetan culture in Nepal. The 36-meter-high stupa of Bouddhanath is one of the largest stupas in South Asia. Bouddhanath Stupa was renovated by Licchavi rulers in the eighth century. The mandala design in Bouddhanath is a copy of the one in Gyangtse in Tibet. The stupa is located in the area of ancient trade route to Tibet where Tibetan merchants rested and offered prayers for many centuries. When refugees entered Nepal from Tibet in the 1950s, many decided to live around Bouddhanath. Hence, a complete township has developed around Bouddhanath. The stupa is said to entomb the remains of a Kasyap sage venerable both to Buddhists and Hindus. Smaller stupas are located at the base. Gompa monasteries, curio shops, and restaurants surround Bouddhanath.

A Must Visit When in Kathmandu. This is the largest stupa in Nepal (the largest outside of Tibet). The blinding white color and sheer size is awesome. The flapping/colorful prayer flags attached to the stupa are perfect. Go with a guide (someone who has vast knowledge of Tibetan Buddhism as well as the mythology/history behind this stupa) as the experience will be much richer.

Afternoon circumnavigation. You have to go here in the late afternoon and see all the people walking around the stupa, some prostrating themselves. You can get up on the first platform and walk around here too. Keep your entrance ticket as it can be used again if you return.There are loads of restaurants and shops in the area, and some temples to visit. This stupa is much revered by the Tibetan people many who live around this area. It is one of the largest in south east Asia, and the largest in Nepal.
The most peaceful place on earth. Walking around this temple, I felt an incredible sense of serenity. It was truly the highlight of my trip to Nepal.

Great Place to see Tibetan Monks. Entrancee Fee 150 Nepalie Rupees for foreigners, it is one of the best stupas in the city, you can see al the people walking clock wise around the stupa and tibetan monks praying all over.You can take a Blue mini van from Rath park toward to bonath,it will cost you 20 Rupees and will be fun to ride with the locals.

Losar in Nepal. Learn all you can about the Losar festival in Nepal. Indigenous peoples (Gurung, Tamang, etc.) have their own Losars (New Year). The Tibetan one is worth knowing about & is visible in Boudha. Beautiful ceremonies inside the monasteries.

Everyone is correct - you need to visit this amazing stupa. Really can't add too much over everyone else's comments. I am not really a "spiritual" person but it is just about impossible to not be moved and mystified by the beautiful symmetrical stupa and the numerous persons from all over who are walking around solemnly, many with obvious devotion. Important - walk CLOCKWISE around the stupa.
great mood. better visit it on the evenings, after 16:30, light very nice on the stupa and lot of people come to pray and walk around it.

Excellent world Heritage site. Had been in april 2014. Located in busy and crowded locality. Very little parking space. So had prepared for disappointment. But once inside it is beautiful with very religious anf pious atmosphere. Shopping malls with excellent goods. Multi cuisine restsurents and all. Spent 3 hours but could havr spent more. A must place to visit in kathmandu.
great place. It was nice to see real life of Nepali buddhist people and i am glad i have visited this stupa. will go there again!

beautiful views with relaxing energy. We walked here tonight -- pleasant walk through nice pathway of neighborhood. The stupa is stunning and huge-- beautiful. Quite peaceful, friendly energy. Cute shops, restaurants, hotels, etc., all around the stupa. Several restaurants have 2nd or 3rd level terraces to have a nice view of the stupa. Very relaxing!

the "trademark" of Kathmandu. It is very popular place for visitors and locals as well. You can see the Bodanath Stupa from far if you are to a high point. Especially afternoon local people go at Stupa to pray and make Kora(the clockwise round of Stupa). Stupa is Buddhist temple. Many shops around with good prices after hard bargains!! Nice to walk around and also nice cafe and restaurant on top of many buildings with nice views
The most important in kathmandu. This biggest stupa is must.So many magical moment that you can find (the pilgrim, tibetian refugee, local people, etc)The most important in kathmandu.Magic!
A must visit place. A trip to Khatmandu is not complete without walking the streets of Boudhanath and walk around the stupa. Will allow you to know better about Tibetan people and Budhism.

An oasis of serenity amidst the bustling city. Sacred Place surrounded with souvenir shops and restaurants.It is especially spectacular at night when adorned with butter lamps. Remember to walk around the stupa in a clockwise direction and also to spin the prayer wheels clockwise.

Always a must visit!. Been to Kathmandu 5 times in the last 6 years - been to the Stupa 5 times. Make sure to walk around the stupa 3 times clockwise - brings you good luck! Love the atmosphere, great shops, lovely people. Highly recommended as part of your journey!

What a Beautiful Place. This was my favorite place in Kathmandu. I loved going around (always clockwise!) the stupa, turning the prayer wheels, watching the people. There are nice shops all around, especially the Thanka school. There is a nice monastery in the back where you can see the monks do their daily thing.
Amazing!. Located in the north-east of Kathmandu Boudhanath stupa is the biggest Buddhist stupa in Nepal, perhaps in the world..an amazing representation of peace and harmony....

Peaceful. Always happy to be here!. I am always happy to be here. Praying Lord Budhha and walking around the temple gives u immense pleasure and gives peace to ur mind. Go anytime, the stupa is always peaceful.

You must visit this!. I love love love the Bodnath Stupa. The energy is incredible and it is simply beautiful. You can circumambulate the stupa with everyone or you can find a roof top restaurant and people watch while soaking up the energy. I stayed in the neighborhood around the stupa and am so glad I did!

"Magic to see this Stupa". I been Boudhanath stupa so many times .It is one of the most sacred places for Buddhists. It's Situated just 8 km to the east of downtown Kathmandu. You can take a taxi from your place and you may use local micro or bus as well. Boudhanath is one of the most imposing landmarks in Kathmandu It is the largest stupa in the Kathmandu Valley and is the center of Tibetan Buddhism. If you are in Kathmandu please do not forget to visit this monument Zone. It’s the Main visit destination in Kathmandu.
Beautiful. Magical here...there really is a profound energy in the temple! Beautiful to see. Great to come a while before sunset and here the chanting and watch the dosing evening ceremony!

Amazing vibe.Must see in KTM. Its a really holy and peaceful place, i just got that calm vibe. Take a few rounds around the stupa and ur wish may just come true. The onli thing i didnt like about this place are the shops around it, it changes the whole calm thing of the stupa.

Prayers at the Monastery. I spent an hour at the Boudhanath Monastery during their prayer time at around 9:30 am. I removed my shoes, went in and observed. I did take photos but tried to be unobtrusive. While the chanting and prayers were fascinating, the architecture was spectacular. GJS
Amazing. What a extravaganza on earth....the art of human civilization. A unique portray of religion and nature....

A center of Kathmandhu's Buddhist life. I stayed in Boudha for two weeks, visiting a friend who was studying Tibetan language and Buddhism. The point of the trip was to write, and I got most of my inspiration by sitting on the third floor of Ariya Cafe looking out the windows at the stupa. The site itself is impressively large and decorative. It especially makes a stunning outline against the sunset. More than the actual structure, though, I was intrigued by the life that goes on around it. Families walk khorra (circumambulate the stupa) before taking kids to school and after the work day is over, while some older Tibetans might walk all day, prayer beads in hand and a compassion chant under their breath. You can also catch monks, nuns, young couples, and people of every age and ancestry walking khorra (including tourists like me). Additionally, there are several nice shops along the khorra path; you can buy books, singing bowls, mandala paintings, or cheaper jewelry, clothes, and nick nacks. Boudhanath is a great way to experience a mix of Tibetan, Nepali, and Indian cultures in a place of deep Buddhist spirituality.

magic to see and my favourite place to live. I'm a frequent traveller to Kathmandu and no doubts Bouddhanath is the place many tourists are coming for: it is spectacular and thrilling for one visit, but it is also a comfortable, tranquil and peaceful place to live as well.I lived in Kathmandu in many places: in different Patan places and around Thamel. While Patan might be convenient for a group travel it is definitely uncomfortable for a single women because shops and restaurants are rather far away from hotels, streets are dark and lonely and it is rather boring. Thamel is crazy and only certain type of people would like to be touched, shouted and disturbed every minute. Could work for a day or two, but not more!Bouddhanath is almost perfect. I would enjoy walking around stupa even at midnight, restaurants are very close and small shops make it not even necessary to go outside. Moreover, here is peace and fresh air that you cannot find in Kathmandu at all! It is beautiful, i loved to go to the roof and to see sunrise over Bouddha and to see all the surrounding golden monasteries. there are many locals who live their life and perform daily prayers not really bothering to sell something and attack you.There are only two minor disadvantages: it might get rather difficult to get in and out from Bouddha due to traffic jams; and food in restaurants is not that advanced and might get boring especially for vegetarians after a while. Otherwise-definitely recommend. I was trying and experimenting a lot before i found my comfortable place to return when i go through Kathmandu and Bouddhanath is definitely that.

A must do. A place that should be visited when in the valley. It is a little away from the city centre but really besides the traffic, Kathmandu Valley(incliding Kathmandu, Patan and Bhaktapur) is not that large a place.

A Peacefull mind. Bouddhanath exist north east of Kathmandu city with perfect place and great environment. Once enter the gate is just peaceful and lively surrounding. Generally there is always Buddhist monks and nuns and lay people that follow Buddhism circulate the great Stupa. There over 2 dozens of great restaurants in the area with great food.
Its magestic. Its one of the greatest place to hang around in the valley. Being in one of the cafes around and you stay there for hours.

So cool!. This place is a pilgrimage site for Buddhists around the world. It's so awesome - looking up at it will give you chills. A must see while in Kathmandu for sure, don't miss it! At 6 PM the monks come out and do their prayers around it, go up to a rooftop cafe at one of the surrounding hotels and observe the ritual from there, it's SO COOL. Make sure not to stay too late there after it gets dark, the area gets dangerous at night.
Impressive!. Very interesting site to visit. Lots of people but i think its a must in kathmandou. You can easily spend 2 hours going around the site. Don't miss it.

A taste of Buddhism. although the Stupa exists in the middle of the chaos of Kathmandu, once you enter the stupa you can enjoy a peace of mind, watching the monks chanting or going around the stupa spinning their wheel prayers.Around the Stupa are many restaurants and shops, where you can buy some really nice Tibetan accessories, souvenirs and beautiful arts and crafts.

An impressive look at Nepal culture. 2,000 years old and with a top completed in the middle ages, the Boudhanath Stupa is a structure rich in history. Once again, having a local guide is worth having for checking this location out, as ours, Padme, provided a great explanation over the symbolism and history of the Stupa. I don't have much experience exploring Buddhist, Hindu, or Lamaism structures, so seeing all the prayer wheels ranging from two liter size to larger than a car standing on its bumper was a unique experience. The square is surrounded by many souvenir shops. My guide helped me pick out a handmade 800 gram singing bowl for 4000 rupees (about $40).

One of the most peaceful places in K-town!. Boudhanath is one of the must visit places in Kathmandu.Its peaceful environment with the enchanting sounds of the Buddhist mantras really makes one feel calm and relaxed.This heavenly place looks more spectacular in the evening surrounded by the lights.I always love visiting this amazing heritage :)
A day after Buddha's Birthday. We avoided the birthday itself - and had a very quiet day with very few people. It seemed a little sterile. Unfortunately we couldn't stay until evening.

amazing energy at the stupa. Great vibes. make sure you stay overnight in Bhouda as you get to watch the pilgrams at all hours of the day walk around the stupa. there is heaps of fantastic people watching to do from sunrise to sunset, meditation classes, Pranamya yoga is a fantastic yoga studio which is 2 minutes walk from the stupa. great food- for really really cheap yummy nepali food try the '3D restaurant' opposite the Mandala hotel, which is out the back of the alley from the green vegetarian cafe.i recommend taking a walk to Kopan monastry in the Kapan district. a great 30/40 min walk to check out other towns and have a great vista from the kopan hill.if you love GREAT COFFEE head for 2 places: however i forget their names! 1: i think its called the circle cafe. its a blue and white logo and the cafe is blue and white- amazing decor cool vibe and very new so support them! its just on the stupa circle coming from the main entrance on the right hand side. 2nd amazing coffee joint is a bright yellow painted hole in the wall type place directly opposite hotel PRK. huge variety of coffee and frappes and the lady is lovely.

Good place if you don't mind paying xtra if ur white. Nice place, be prepare to pay extra if you have light skin! Saarc countries like India and Pakistan citizens get in for cheaper, Nepalis for free and if you even slightly resemble a white person be prepared to pay extra. This white buddhist racist tax allows you to enjoy the place...This is the first area where I've seen them sell alcohol right near a temple...everywhere...then again Alcohol is sold all over Nepal... but near a heritage site? Seriously?

Beautiful stupa in a city. I recently visited Boudhanath stupa. It is one of the most sacred places for Buddhists. You can observe great ceremonial rituals, and a lot of people going around the Stupa in the clock wise direction. There are many restaurants with terraces with good view of the Stupa. You also get many shops where you can buy nice painting of Buddha, statue and other souvinear.

Could not take my eyes off it. What a breathtaking monument with such cultural significance! A must for anyone visiting Kathmandu. Be sure to also have lunch atop one of the rooftop restaurants for an even more incredible view of the stupa!

wonderful Heritage. Situated in north east o Thamel, it is 25 minutes drive by car. We rented car and spend our memorable 3 hrs at Budhanath. So many monasteries around an at evening Candle light Pooja is done by several monks. It was nice to see stupas, met monks and shop around it.
big stupa. Amazing big stupa, the sign of peace. Shops and restaurants and many monasterries are around . We love it.

Legendary site. If you are a Buddhist, this stupa is sacred and a sight to behold. For non-Buddhists, the site is a jumping off point to understand the complex mental concept that is both a stupa and a mandala. It is very interesting to hear and see, and I came away feeling that I have witnessed something very special and meaningful for many people in the world.

Biggest Stupa in Nepal with the most amount of shops surrounding it. This is worth the visit and only cost 200rps last year to get in but the entire stupa is surrounded by shops and restaurant's which gives the place a less religious feel. Lots of monks walking around and plenty of incense filling the air so you will get a real feel of Buddhist life. Make sure you head to rear of the stupa and up to one the monasteries there. Some days you can go in and one of them rents rooms if you fancy getting in to the monks way of life a little more.

Beautiful big stupa, great neighbourhood. The stupa is beautiful and definitely worth visiting. The ambience around the place is very atmospheric with shops playing relaxing music and selling handmade handicraft. In the area you can find lots of cheap places to stay or eat.

In the midst of the city but very melancholy. Very melancholy. In the midst of the city but gives you a very melancholy feeling. The best part is its location, stupa at the centre and the market surrounding it on its circumference. Worth a visit while at Kathmandu

a sight for sore eyes and bear in MIND,the eyes are the windows to the SOUL. The serenity of the surroundings The happiness shown on the NEPALESE(especially the children) although their worldly (material)possessions do not amount to much.

Visiting for Buddha Jayanti. Not sure why it's touted as the biggest stupa in Asia, Shwedagon in Yangon and Borobudur in Java are definiely bigger, probably even Wat Chedi Luang in Chiang Mai. Nevertheless, it's impressive, but from all the descriptions, I thought it would be huge. It's not. There are several rooftop restaurants around, which looked nice but I didn't try.I went there on the full moon day yesterday when the crowds celebrate Buddha's birthday. Which meant no ticket fees were collected, so that was nice. After many similar rituals in Thailand, I was expecting the crowds yes for sure, but I was disappointed that there was hardly any serene atmosphere. More like a mad dash around the stupa, and lots, LOTS of youngsters who were running around, yelling, some with alcohol on their breath, making an atmosphere that looked more like the aftermath of a winning football match. There were no monks or security or anyone trying to deal with them. There was no chanting, prayers, sermons, or people walking around in a meditative state. Having said all this, it was nice for taking photos well before sunset (I arrived at around 4 and left at 8:30), lots of people in traditional costumes, some monks, some schoolkids in processions carrying flags and statues of the Buddha, many young kids wanting a conversation in English. It was a nice atmosphere, and interesting place for people-watching, just not I was expecting for a holy day.

If you do only one thing in Kathmandu.... This is the essence of Kathmandu. Great for the spirit, stomach and eyes. We parked at the Hyatt and walked the back streets. Less crowds if you arrive before dusk while the shops are still open.
A must see in Kathmandu. A key site to visit in Kathmandu, with the huge stupa surrounded by a mini village of shops and cafes.
Unique experience. The structure is very unique. There are good sovenier shops around. Easily accessible by public transport.

must see. This impressive stupa must be / have seen woman. It was the most beautiful stupa in Nepal for us. Full festooned with prayer flags. Very colorful. A wonderful photo opportunity. The stupa is also visited by many pilgrims and is therefore not a pure tourist destination. You can see the variety of the population here. So do not miss. A must see in Kathmandu

Tibetan culture. The most famous stupa in Nepal and an ideal place to get a taste of Tibetan culture. It is 4km east of Kathmandu. You will recognise it from all the Nepal brochures which show its large white dome with eyes peering out just above. The gold pyramid above the eyes has 13 steps representing steps to enlightenment. Tourists can walk on the second level, and for even better views there are a number of rooftop cafés. A monastery on the eastern side called Tsamchen Gompa has a huge prayer wheel just inside the entrance. Shops surrounding the stupa specialise in Tibetan goodies such as singing bowls and mandala artwork. You will see a lot of monks in the dark maroon robes here also. Prayer flags and CD shops constantly playing the Buddhist chant of "Om Mani Padme Hum" will accompany you the entire time you are here..

Sorry Buddha's eyes. Sorry for being insensitive, and perhaps not fully appreciating its beauty. In general I was not impressed. The size it great and it is beautiful but it is poorly maintained I found it dirty and too many shops around it take way the meaning of Buddha’s eyes.
Peaceful. Good buddhist site with cozy restaurants with beautiful view of the stupa. Important UNESCO Heritage site, great for meditation and to relax!
Must see this iconic stupa, time travel!. Must see this iconic stupa, if you are in Kathmandu and not visited Boudhnath Stupa you have to go back to see it.
Beautiful place. Absolutely amazing place. Simply magical! I enjoyed every minute of my time there:) The energy of the place was incredible, I want to go back there as soon as I can!

Must do in Kathmandu!. This is definitely a MUST DO in Kathmandu! We even visited twice in the same trip, first time with a guide on arrival and the second time on the day before we departed the country. I like the meaning of the question-mark-type symbol that is actually the Nepali character for the number 1, some travel info interprets it as symbolising unity and the one way to reach enlightenment. Our guide also shared his interpretation too that this reminds us to be satisfied where we are at while exploring the future new possibilities in life. Very meaning. For these two visits, we also relaxed over a cup of coffee to enjoy the view at one of the rooftops coffee shops!

If you do one thing during your trip to Kathmandu, do this. We had limited time in Kathmandu, and chose to visit the Bodnath Stupa just before sunset. It was a lovely experience to walk round the Stupa. It is away from traffic, so despite the hustle and bustle of people, it is relatively relaxing. We then had dinner at a restaurant overlooking the Stupa. There are many to choose from. It was a lovely way to spend an evening.

The best Buddhist shrine in Kathmandu. Bodnath or Boudhanath is an excellent place to visit while you are in Kathmandu. This ancient buddhist stupa is one of the largest of it's kind in the world. There are many local Tibetan buddhists who live around the stupa and in the nearby monasteries. The people here are photo friendly and just generally friendly.Remember to walk clockwise around the stupa and there are some cafes around where you can get a rooftop view of the stupa and it's surroundings.It costs around 200 Nepalese Rupees to enter the stupa for foreigners ($2)
Peaceful !. its absolutely peaceful and serene , and amazing beautiful energy suroounds the place which makes you calm
It was our second visit. It's a nice and quite place in the center of the city. All around there are nice restaurants on the top where you can watch the Stupa
must see. The impressive size of the Stupa and the fervor of the faithful walking there make it a center of essential interest.

A lot cheaper. The stupa is great to visit for the day but the guest houses and restaurants just outside the stupa ring are a lot cheaper than Thamel and generally nicer place to stay. It is also closer to the airport.

Interesting and recommended. This place is well maintained and provides a great insight to the Buddhist religion. You circulate clockwise around the Stupa and the surrounding buildings offer an array of souvenirs and food. If you can find a guide it will make it more interesting to understand the history and etiquette. Make sure to go inside the Budhist temple which has some amazing art work. Overall this is one of the better maintained historical sites in Kathmandu.
Love it there. Very peaceful in the evening.. Love it there. Very peaceful in the evening. Also the good fact is it is so close to hotel Hyatt where I stayed.

Take your time, it's worth it. This area is great. Once you visit the temple and walk around it the correct way (don't be that guy...), there are also lots of little stalls and cafes and book shops around the area to stop at. Don't forget to look up - there are many buildings that have cafe's on the roof top, and the views are much better than the street level.
Poland like. Worth seeing, can get on the stupa which is not a common thing. Place of prayers.of many people. Small temple next to stupa where all plpl can enter.

Largest Stupa in Nepal. If you're short on time make this your preferred Stupa to visit. Swayambhunath is lovely too but more cramped and crowded - so it was harder there to get a sense of how impressive these stupas are. Easy to walk to - only a few steps up to the platform, clean, no-one tried to sell us anything as we walked round the Stupa (yippee). Area/shops around are Tibetan. Allow 30 mins.

The largest Tibetan Buddhist Stupa in Nepal. It is unique; Often when you see Kathmandu advertised, you see a picture of this great white stupa.There are thousands of prayer wheels which pilgrims are always whirling to send prayers to heaven. The largest prayer wheel I've ever seen is in the complex. It is about 12' high and you must make at least four pushes to get it to turn 360degrees.

Great attraction, DONT GET RIPPED OFF!. A must do for any visitor however...Aside from the stupa I want to mention a place selling 'cashmere' to watch out for. No idea about the name but they charge absurd rip off prices for 'cashmere'.If we say the entrance to the stupa is south (for ease of purpose) then the shop is located about north west on the circle.

Boudananth - a must see. a real wow "Kathmandu" feeling. A must see place as part of your KTM journey. The stupa is absolutely breathtaking in the sky - and only 15mins from Thamel. I had momos at a rooftop cafe overlooking the stupa and had an excellent day.

Definitely a must-visit. We entered Bodnath, and immediately saw throngs of pilgrims walking around the stupa in a clockwise direction. We couldn't help but be swept up with the crowds and join them in this religious procession of some sort. There was just so many things going on at Bodnath that you could really spend a nice late afternoon here observing what the religious are doing or to ponder your own take on religion. Some locals come here to hang out as well. We eventually settled for a meal at Roadhouse Cafe (yes they have a branch here) and enjoyed the Stupa from a higher vantage point.

Fantastic sight. A sight not to be missed in Kathmandu. Besides the main Stupa attraction, the whole area is a great place to shop. One should also enjoy a drink or meal on one of the rooftop bars/restaurants, particularly during sunset. Watch the hundreds of worshipers walk around the Stupa (clockwise of course). Then join them in their march, and soak yourself in atmosphere.
VIBRANT YET PEACEFUL. Apart from its sheer size and magnificence, this vast stupa is the epicentre of so much devotion - one can't help but be overwhelmed by it.

Breathtaking. It was a fortunate accident that we ended up reaching this place around sunset and the view was the most beautiful we could ever have and I doubt whether this place would have the same charm having visited any other time. The stupa and the whole prayer flags are a view to kill for among the backdrop of dropping sun and should not be missed at any cost. There are lots of shops and cafes around so you could easily grab a bite or shop for souvenir with your visit.
Well worth a visit!. Can't go to Kathmandu without seeing this.You can walk round the square and to enter the Stupa there is an entry fee of 150 Nepalese rupees.

Totally Atmospheric. Both of the big stupas in Kathmandu are wonderfully atmospheric. It is hard to decide which one is more so. Bodnath is a wonderful place to head in the early evening to watch the sunset. The stupa is surrounded by restaurants, cafes and hotels, many of which have rooftop seating. Find yourself a place that looks west and watch the sun set with a glass of wine in your hand - with prayer flags floating in the breeze and music drifting up from down below the atmosphere is fantastic. Then once dark has descended, head back down and do your three turns around the stupa, your path illuminated now by dozens of butter lamps. This world heritage site is not to be missed! ( If you want souvenirs there are also a number of very good shops surrounding the stupa)

A haven within the city. In a city that is dusty, hectic and rubbish everywhere it was nice to have a place that was managed and kept very clean. A great place to shop, and enjoy a drink or meal on one of the rooftop bars/restaurants.
Stupa. Wonderful iconic stupa. Surrounded by shops, vendors, restaurants and temples. Not to be missed. Walk around the stupa (clockwise of course) several times
Big amzing Buudhist Stupa. The biggest in South Asia stupa . Pleople every morning from 4.00 Am go round and round to Stupa which is amazing. We enjoyed a lot there.

Mystical and magical. It's hard not to be moved by Boudanath - being able to walk 360 degrees around the temple on the top of the stupa, gazing up at the prayer flags whipping in the wind, and surrounded by an unexpectedly spacious square hidden from the cramped outer street. Not to be missed.

Moving and interesting. A really chilled out place to hang out, shop, eat wander and soak up the atmosphere. I could have spent a day or more here just wandering in and out of places. Just a lovely place with a massive impressive Stupa in the middle of it.
wow. A must see on your Nepal trip a beautiful place of worship, just watch the world go by in one of the many rooftop restaurants.
Once in a lifetime. Everyone must walk around the Stupak once in a lifetime. The energy within the space is the accumulation of thousands walking in prayer over such a long span of time.
What a gem of a place!. The stupa is just wonderful, majestic and inspiring,with its crowd of people going around the dome for praying. Small shops with exquisite crafts dot the sorrounding area.

Magnificent Stupa. Grandin scale and solemn in appearance the centre of buddhist culture in Kathmandu.Surrounded by bustling markets and every souvenir you didn't want to see again, it still radiates a calm and intense feeling.

Very Interesting but get a guide and watch the hard sell!. We went with a small group from our hotel. The guide was knowledgeable and we loved learning about the associated customs. Without the guide, we wouldn't have known much at all. We soon discovered however, that the guides have their own favourite places where they took us to buy things. When we declined, it was tricky to stay in a harmonious group. Still well worth the visit, just take care and be aware.
Great architecture and Buddhist Stupa. The eyes painted on the Stupa gives a vert beautiful visual impression and the circle around the Stupa is decorated with Buddhist bells.

Bodnath Stupa. This grand Stupa is well worth a visit. It stands impressively behind and amidst the chaos of a Kathmandu street scene and provides a peaceful haven to experience this most holy Buddhist 'temple'.
Make sure you go. Great first thing in the morning - have a coffee and breakfast on the rooftop of Hello Cafe. Great views and very spiritual

Don't miss it!. Bodnath is not to be missed. On a tip from Lonely Planet, we went at sundown and experienced the stupa with local practitioners (not as many tourists) as they walked around the stupa and prayed. Very moving. We were too late to enjoy the shops and restaurants, but they would be worth investigating. Only downside is that it is on the outskirts of town and the traffic and crossing the street were a hassle.

Bodhnath Stupa. This was my 3rd visit to stupa.It always fascinating to visit it.The area around the stupa has not changed much.Only thing we could climb till the eye of the Stupa when we visited 1st time

Don't Miss This. After visiting the so-called "Monkey Temple" in Kathmandu, this place was a wonderful and serene break. As you walk around the circular promenade, you can find whatever you like: peace, shopping, food and interesting people to watch. Our family thought this was one of the best attractions in Kathmandu.Note: Be sure to visit the two monasteries around the base of the stupa. They are beautiful to see and do not cost extra (unless you choose to leave a donation). Also, don't miss the Thanka art schools if you wish to see art-in-action.
A wonderful spot to visit. The atmosphere here was brilliant. A mixture of the devout and the commercial as the people go about their daily business.

can miss. nothing special view but can just visit for watching stupa structure. place very crowded and out of the main area. very congested area and also lot of traffic. lot of restaurants around serving good snacks

Experience True Serenity. Take a break from Nepal's maze of unpaved winding streets with motorcycles weaving in and out and horns honking constantly. None of that here. The pace is slow. The Stupa is huge close up. Everything is clean and orderly - you'll forget where you are. The restaurants and shops around the outside were great. You'll experience seeing Tibetan monks, people chanting, candles & incense (no bodies- yuk) burning and prayer wheels, Handicrafts can be found all around the outer circle. I bought prayer flags & a poster for a teacher I know. Wish I bought a Thangka (a Nepalese art form exported to Tibet) while I was there. The Thangka and Singing Bowls are the must have handcrafts. The Stupa sparks a peaceful feeling that has to be experienced. When George from Seinfeld says "serenity now" this is where he'd want to be. You don't need to be a Buddhist to experience it.

essential visit. Nice vibe in this locality and a couple of temples and restaurants well worth a visit. Lots of interesting shops including sevaral in the streets off the circular promenade which you have to walk round clockwise - or else!
peaceful location. the place was very peaceful and nice. faced a heavy traffic to reach there, but once we arrived all the tension was gone. Its so beautiful stupa.

The Super Bodnath Stupa. One of the ultimate things to do in Kathmandu is take a visit to the Boudhanath Stupa. This stupa is located close to the airport, and not far from the best (and most expensive) hotel in town, the Hyatt Regency. It took me around 20 minutes in a taxi from Thamel to get here, and it cost around 500rps each way, which is an acceptable price so I didn’t even bother haggling! Boudhanath is a vintage UNESCO World Heritage Site and is the largest Buddhist place of worship in Nepal. It dominates the skyline of Kathmandu, although due to haze and pollution it may not always be visible from downtown.Entrance is 150RPS for everybody unless you are from India or Sri Lanka. I think the admission is worth the price, as it really is one of the main tourist sites not only in Kathmandu but also in Nepal overall. Around the outer perimeter of the stupa are little antique and handicraft shops as well as quaint cafés and bars, many of which have rooftop verandas with views down over the stupa. All of this adds to the vibe and atmosphere of the place and makes you realise that your admission price was for more than just taking photos of a big pair of eyes!One of the great things about the Boudhanath Stupa is the prayer flags that are draped all around it. I have seen many of these in Bhutan, but as this was my first trip to Nepal I was surprised to see them here, too. There are prayer wheels all around the stupa as well, and despite not being a Buddhist I nevertheless still enjoyed turning them with my hand as I walked past. It should be noted that you are supposed to walk in a clockwise direction around the stupa as a sign of respect.Of course, with this being Nepal, the area wouldn’t be complete with a little rubbish on the sidewalk and building work haphazardly being undertaken in the vicinity, but I always felt safe around here, and the workmen are usually very friendly and get out of your way when taking photos. I didn’t take any pictures of any of the many Buddhist monks around here, as I wasn’t sure if that was permitted or not, but they were all dressed in red robes, with orange scarves, and seemed to be hurriedly darting from one area of the stupa to another. It was a nice colourful change from the stark white of the stupa itself.You can ascend the Boudhanath Stupa up to the second or third levels, and again walk around clockwise, although there are no prayer wheels up here (there are more prayer flags though). You can get good views of the action down below and can actually have a better indication of your whereabouts as you are higher up. A word of warning, though, if you are scared of birds: there are hundreds of dirty pigeons around the Boudhanath Stupa. I guess in some countries these pigeons would have been forced to leave to make the place a little more hygienic for the monks and tourists, but I guess in this part of the world it’s just par for the course! I almost had a couple of pigeons fly into my face as I was walking around taking photos, but fortunately I survived!

Perfect to a relaxed walk. Surrounded by this special energy and vibration this place is perfect to at least, a day of walking, eating, local shopping and get in touch with the culture.I recommend to find a hotel/guest house there, takes you away from the noise and crazyness of Kathmandu, and you can always take a taxi for around U$3 to Thamel, the city center.

Good shops around. It is near Kathmandu and very surprisingly there are shops surrounding this temple. Did not go into the temple proper. Would recommend a guide to show the place so you learn more of this place in detail.

Get close and personal. I visited Bhouda by myself in the afternoon and it was quite crowded with tourists and pilgrims alike but nevertheless when I climbed to the stupa level, there were only 5 other people so I found it quite nice to absorb the atmosphere of the place.
Good structure but too crowded. Good structure and Maintained quite well. Worth one look. Not necessarily a major tourist spot. It is popular because of lack of other tourist things to do.

Not a must-see in Kathmandu. Maybe I had expected too much, so I was a little underwhelmed. Yes, it's a big awesome stupa. And it's great to see the devotion and the prayers and the rituals. Unlike many other religious places, you can get very close to the action, even imitate them, and take as many pics as you want. Getting up on the Stupa and walking around provides a good overview of the area and shops. Then you know which shops or restaurants do you want to visit. I went to a newly opened Circle Street Cafe which didn't have a great view of the Stupa but one of the best Nepali coffee, cleanest toilets, and the friendliest owners and staff I'd seen in KTM. The rooftop had a nice view of the street! All in all, a nice place to visit, but I won't call it a must-visit. Swomboth is probably a similar but nicer experience with the beautiful views of the city.

Must see in KTM. I could be wrong but there are more than 20 Buddhist Monasteries around this UNESCO heritage site. Lest people forget Buddha was born in Nepal. Tolerant Buddhist allow tourist free range in this their most holy stupa. Lots of cafés and restaurants around from Pizza to Tibetan. You haven't been to Kathmandu if you don't visit this holy site.
Wonderful!. Beautiful place to spend a few hours, the flags against the white - its just gorgeous. good place to people watch also. Very deserving of No.1 spot!

Buddhist center, certainly worth a visit. Truly authentic genuine, an own neighborhood center in Kathmandu. With the predominant five-tiered Stupa in the middle. Surrounded by tea shops, craft shops, mandala schools and much more. If you really would like to go into the stupa - check exact enough for opening hours - it's only open to the public approximately every 12 years.
Great. peacful, full of tibetan, nice people, graeat Stupa (and other buddhist temples)A MUST in Kathmandou

Interesting place. we visited around lunchtime but if you go later in the day you can attend one of the nearby monasteries in the afternoon usually around 3pm. The Stupa is the largest and there are no steps to climb like the others nearby so if you have difficulties this is good for you.

Peace prevails. Best place to observe monks in different coloured robes from all over the world and huge gathering of buddhists from all over the world. The largest tibetan community recites in this area.

A "must see" when in Kathmandu. This stupa is so integral to the city that it would be a shame not to visit. It is a huge stupa which dominates the surrounds. There are some interesting shops and restaurants. We particularly liked a demonstration and explanation of the thangka paintings upstairs in one of the shops.

A great place to visit. It is one of the most sacred places for Buddhists. You can observe great ceremonial rituals , and a lot of people going around the Stupa in the clock wise direction, it is not ok to go counter clock wise. Good coffee shops with terraces with good view of the Stupa. A lot of places to buy excellent souvenirs with years old traditions.

Allow time to look around. This place is awesome, and the Stupa is huge. We had lunch at a restaurant overlooking the Stupa. We explored the area including the two huge prayer wheels. We only had a couple of hours but could have spent more time here

Interesting!. The Bodnath Stupa is very interesting. First, before you enter there is a fee however; I can’t remember how much it cost exactly. The Bodnath Stupa has some interesting history and it is a huge stupa that you can walk around from below or from an upper level. We sat down at the stupa and read some history on this particular stupa. I would recommend as a good trip to escape Thamel and it isn’t far by taxi either. There are shops and restaurants around the stupa as well.

Don't miss this. If time is short in Kathmandu, this is the one place not to miss.The area is called "Little Tibet" as originally it was the area where exiles from Tibet set up many years ago. It was delightful: calm, peaceful and immaculately clean. All the people were charming, and it looked like a healthy, happy and thriving community. What a joy to think that the Tibetans have found a place outside their homeland where they can start afresh.There is lots to see; a small monastery; the kora; monks; views from the rooftop; climbing the stupa; and the general activity from this interesting community.And shops that support the local craftspeople.

Plenty of history and nice visit. I really enjoyed visiting the Bodnath Stupa. I love the spiritual side of Nepal and I visited this place with an included site seeing tour of Kathmandu. In my free time I went back and visited again. There is some interesting history with Tibet and there are lots of places to eat and shop in this area.
Interesting and good shopping. This is a very large temple with a large number of shops and restaurants surrounding the Stupa. Shopping was good and plenty of restaurants/bars for dining & drinking

Simply beautiful. During our trip we met an expat living in Kathmandu, and she said us to go there during the sunset, and of course we did it. Such a beautiful place, but with so many shops for tourist around the temple.

Tranquil and quiet place for the second largest stupa in the world. We visited this morning. It was very quiet. That may have been because it was a Saturday or the day before Nepalese New Years Eve. It was quiet and interesting. No beggars here. We ate lunch at the Buddha rooftop restaurant. Excellent cleanliness and food.
Boudanath. Full of atmosphere. We strolled around the temple with Tibetan worshipers in national costume praying and then Buddhist monks playing and chanting. It was awe inspiring.

Interesting introduction to local Buddhist culture - a real treat!!. The Bodnath Stupa is a wonderful cultural experience. I would suggest having a knowledgeable local or a guide to explain the variety of activities at the site. Buddhism go there to worship....some kneel and pray, others walk around the stupa, still other chant or meditate. There are two or three levels where one can walk, and one should walk clockwise with the flow of traffic. People are very friendly. Surrounding the stupa are many shops and restaurants. A good time to go is around the evening. The evening when I visited, people gathered around the monks and made monetary and material contributions. A real interesting experience....not to be missed!!
Very polished neighborhood. Here everything is very well cleaned and well maintained. The surrounding buildings emanates a healthy kind of charm.

Surreal. This is a very large stupa and the idea of Tibetans paying homage by walking around the Stupa 7 times was just surreal. If you are in Kathmandu, you need to invest the time to get here. This is one gigantic attraction. Be careful not to take too many pictures of the locals as some might ask for money.

Biggest stup a in the word. It was so amazing place in Kathmandu. Can be sassily reached with local taxis for 5 dollars from any part of tourist city. Its so much fun to be there at evening to see kora. Makes you feell like people are so kind, simple and all the world is a devotee of Buddhist religion. It was a huge mass of people. Huge white object with people doing kora. One most go here in you Nepal visit. Their entrance fee is so cheap compared to other sites in Nepal. I loved this place.

Stunning. What a place - the faith of the people is humbling. Beautiful. One night a week the stupa is lit by a garland of lights, and just sitting there, watching the people walking around the stupa and praying is one of the most amazing experiences.

Must see. It's an open mall, with the biggest stupa in the middle of. But, if you are in Nepal, you have to visit.If the Temple is open, pay a visit, it's a beautiful Temple with nice images, and a good vibration. If the monks are there ask for a blessing.There is good restaurants on roof tops of buildings and you can enjoy the view.Shops, shops, more shops.....The religious people have right hours to make theirs practices, and you can notice in their faces their faith!Round 3x clockwise in silence. Try to catch the feeling!

Five incredibles stars!!! Top one!!! Astonishing!!!. Absolutely THE BEST PLACE TO VISIT IN KATHMANDU!!! The place where tibetans go a pray. They have also schools of Tanka paintings. This incredible stupa is the most important buddhist place in Nepal. It's a simbol. Those eyes coonnect direct with your soul. Many people relax, pray o meditate. Is powerful!!! You have to give three circles around the stupa and you will be in Nirvana. The place is like a circle full of shops and three floor buildings around the big stupa. You have to pay an entance to get in.
crowded. could be world's biggest stupa,many pilgrimer around thi area. restaurant and souvenir shop are everywhere. entrance are crowded and packed. but its a place in kathmandu you must see.
First thing in Kathmandu. Put it on the top of your list for Kathmandu. A happening place and religiously colorful. It won't much time to impress you.

Iconic. This is a must see in Kathmandu. If you go at night you will see the stupa illuminated which creates a great atmosphere. There are several places to eat around the stupa and many places to buy trinkets. Buyer beware though, it's is a tourist location so prices for trinkets will be inflated. Final Verdict: A must see
Best Stupa.. It is the world largest stupa, must see. Buddhist chanting around, praying flags on the sky, monks, meditation around that stupa really make the time being in paradise.

Worth a visit. This stupa is enormous, and is surrounded by a wall of interesting shops selling all sorts of Tibetan clothes, brasswork, and other items. Watching the interesting mix of people here is fascinating.

Most impressive temple in Kathmandu. There is so much to witness and see! This temple is the most sacred Buddhist temple outside of Tibet. Monks and devotees walk around its periphery and spin the prayer wheels sending their prayers into the hemisphere. There are colorful shops where artisans sell their impressive handicrafts. Do not miss visiting this National Heritage Site!
Monk temple. Its a very beutyful place near in city & mostly for a monk there are many stupa also in side of boudha stupa n lots of market n resturant also help

Boudhanath Stupa in Nepal. Boudhanath Stupa or Bodnath Stupa is the largest stupa in Nepal and the holiest Tibetan Buddhist temple outside Tibet. It is the center of Tibetan culture in Kathmandu and rich in Buddhist symbolism. The stupa is located in the town of Boudha, on the eastern outskirts of Kathmandu. After the arrival of thousands of Tibetans following the 1959 Chinese invasion, the temple has become one of the most important centers of Tibetan Buddhism. Today it remains an important place of pilgrimage and meditation for Tibetan Buddhists and local Nepalis, as well a popular tourist site.

Must visit - charming, historic and peaceful. Before visiting the Bodnath after the Pashupatinath and Swayambhunath Temples, and what a delight it was! The former too are more religious, Pashupatinath being a sacred Hindu temple. Since we were not religious tourists, the Stupa felt like a great relaxing spot, after a long day of sight seeing. We reached Bodnath around 5pm, and it was just beautiful. The Stupa stands alone in the centre surrounded by a cosy circle of shops, cafes, hotels and eateries, largely Tibetan. The campus is clean and has a peaceful feel to it. We had some iced tea, walked around and enjoyed some evening photography in the setting sun. It was an hour well spent!

Pretty place to visit. A pretty place to visit and people watch and the stupa is huge. Worth a visit but for us only an hour max and we were happy to move on. It depends how much you are into the religion. If you are deeply spiritual you may decide to meditate here as lots of locals and foreigners do.

Breathtakingly Unique. Amazing is such a small word to convey how great this place is.Situated in a large square and drapped in Tibetan Prayer Flags it looks like those old King Kong movies where the beast is trapped down by chains, about to break lose at any time.This is a simply stunning monument and there are plenty of great photo opportunities.I would reccommend getting a drink in one of the rooftop bars to offer you a higher vantage point.

Holy Site. Its one of the holiest sites in Nepal, not so far from Katrhmandu.
Tibetan merchants have rested and offered prayers here for many centuries
Stay here it is cheaper and quiet. The area is a nicer place to stay than Thamel and near to the airport. If you want shopping then stay in Thamel.

A touch of Buddhism in Kathmandu. I took a group there for a visit. Everyone enjoyed this very much, and for anyone leading a tour, this is a must see. The great Stupa is walled in or encircled with mostly Tibetan shops, offering many types of Tibetan pieces.
Stupa View restaurant in Bodnath. Excellent service and smiles galore. Good food. Creative recipes and generous servings. We went up on the roof terrace - awesome view on the stupa!

Must see when visiting Kathmandu..... Historic and beautiful, though showing its age, it was going through some maintenance and is still a sight to see. The shops around it are very inexpensive and would recommend them rather than buying near shops by hotels which often prey on tourist. A small donation was given, and not pressured, and appreciated which made the visit feel that much more sincere. One of the places I highly recommend seeing in the area and entrance fee is minimal.
Nice place to see. The place is very nice holy and colorful ...you can have nice cup of cafe and enjoy the view of the place..must to visit ...

Spectacular!. Loved the atmosphere, activity, shops, views. Stopped in a temple and sat with the chanting monks- had a yellow thread tied around our wrists! Prayerflags and the all seeing eyes made great photos
A must do. A pitty of the many, many shops but one advise , ignore them and just go there and enjoy the most beautiful stupa of the world !!!
Go to this one. After you visit this stupa the rest make more sense. Beautiful. Relaxing. A must do cultural experience.
Very Peaceful. This is a very peaceful place, i spent 2 hours here just sitting. Do go here if you want to experience tranquility.

Worth a visit. Bodnath Stupa is in the middle of an enclosed square, surrounded by quaint little shops and restaurants, well worth spending an hour or so looking around. If time permits it is nice to visit one of the upstairs little restaurants and try some Nepalise food, whilst soaking in the views of the Stupa and also the surrounding countryside.

Huged, impressive!. This huge stupa sits in the middle of a square, the biggest in India, quite impressive and can walk around the outer borders, unable to go inside. Many rooftop restaurants to catch a cool view and great pictures. Looks modern, eyes painted on the top resemble those you may see in Egypt.

impressive. the sheer scale of the Stupa is mind blowing considering how they are made. the complex around the Stupa is wonderful as it is private and closed to cars and scooters so it is a very calm and quiet place within the city- The shops and restaurants are all facing the Stupa and offer good quality food and products- It is easy to spend a lot of time just walking around the Stupa feeling the calm.

Stunning!. You might get 'stupa burnout' in Nepal, but if you do pick one, this one is lovely. Have lunch at the Roadhouse cafe about 3/4 way round the outside - they do lovely wood-fired pizza - you can while the afternoon away up above the hubbub...

Good. it was a very nice place, loved the environment and the whole area , felt little crowdy, good place to shop... Buddhist locals, great place to observe people and have a cup of tea, many restaurants.
My all time Dream. This is a must see.. breath taking and so peaceful. I had dreamed of this since a child and my visit was all I had hoped it would be and more

Good place. A must visit place in Katmandu. You get to see all these Buddhist monks praying and the stupa is wonderful, it's Asia's largest Buddhist stupa . A good place to shop for Tibetan singing bowls and thangkas. Visit Tsering Art School Shop which is at walk-able distance from stupa. You can buy thangkas paintings from this place.

Nice experience. This world heritage listed site is worth a visit while your in Ktm. Because this is a Buddhist area it feels different to the other areas of Hindu majority. It's only 6k's from town centre and is worth the effort, especially in the mornings between about 6 and 9am and in the evenings when all the rituals are carried out in earnest. If you want contrast then it is only 30 min walk to Pashupatinath (a hindu area). Allow a good 3 to 4 hrs to do both.

A nice place to spend an afternoon. Bodnath Stupa is much bigger than I had expected it to be and with the weather being so nice my wife and I decided to take our time looking around and doing some window shopping in the stores that surround it. We had a lovely meal in a rooftop restaurant (name escapes me, sorry) and watched as large groups of people came to pay tribute to the stupa itself. It was a nice way to feel immersed in a culture that was not familiar to me. I would definitely recommend it to any travellers headed this way.
Very interesting. An experience to see how other cultures.. I noticed that all temples have very very very long steps to reach the temple... So not for the unfit!

The eyes of Buddha. I loved that it was so peaceful and calming. Surrounded by Ohm Mane Padhme Ohms everywhere, you cant help but relax. We got there a bit after midday and it was not packed at all. After circling the Stupa clockwise and seeing from the first level we then went for lunch and ate and drank while contemplating the mighty Bouddhanath Stupa. Nearby are the best place to guy real Thangkas and Prayer bowls. Trust me the bowls need to be bought from here, not Thamel. You will hear the difference.
Very spiritual. Well kept and very colourful ! Visit in the evening where you would be able to see all the devotees going around stupa.

Just very special............... This is my favourite of all the places I visited in Kathmandu. There is something very special about this enormous stupa. It's not just the knowledge that it is one of the most important Buddhist sites but rather the experience of being amongst genuine devotees who pray here (or in the many nearby monasteries) everyday. This is the main focus for Tibetan refugees in Kathmandu, and as you walk round (always clockwise), spin the prayer wheels, and try to take it all in, you are surrounded by Tibetans in their traditional dress, with prayer beads in their hands as they chant the mantras.In spite of the crowds Boudhanath always feels calm, and peaceful. On a practical level there are many good cafes and restaurants at rooftop height to sit and absorb the whole scene, with snow capped mountains in the far distance. Getting to and from Boudhanath is very easy by taxi from central Kathmandu and I recommend that you try to go independently if you can (not with a group) so that you can really take your time, and explore the whole area at your own pace.

Buddha Eyes. Walk around the complex, then, head off to one of the roof top restaurants to get your lunch and enjoy the view from there.I went on a weekday,so, it was relatively quiet.Many shops around the complex, you can get all kinds of souvenirs here. Try to visit one of the many art school there, they specialise in Tibetan art which they call Tangka.
Amazing!. Very peaceful and beautiful! There are also shops all around so there's more to see and the whole site is an incredible experience!

Great site. Due to its popularity in tourism, the buildings around the stupa have sadly been overrun with souvenir shops, hotels, and cafes. Still, the stupa itself remains an impressive peace of art, and serene in its own right, and the fee is much lower than other sites in Kathmandu, definitely worth walking around several times to appreciate.

Buddhist Shrine. Buddhanath stupa is one of the holiest Buddhist site of Kathmandu. It is on the north east skyline of Kathmandu. It is less than half an hour drive from central Kathmandu. Buddhanath stupa is one of the largest stupa of the world. This stupa is surrounded by different monasteries. It is believed that this stupa was built just immediately after the demise of the lord Buddha. It is single largest Chhyorten in the world. You can pray, walk around and visit different monasteries here. It is believed that thousands of Buddhas and heavenly Deities incarnated as Lamas in the Baudha stupa. It is said that because of the rays of Bouddhisattwa entered in the song from heaven and the holy sound of was heard in the sky. Due to being empowered by the Bodhisatwa this stupa is viewed with a great reverence.

Impressive. Despite having visited many stupas over the years, I was impressed by Bodnath Stupa. The sheer size of the stupa and all the activities and all the buildings/shops/temples surrounding makes it a very interesting place to visit. If it fits with your timing, consider having lunch in one of the restaurant next to it, it is a nice way of enjoying the view and the atmosphere.

Impressive and peaceful in the same time. The heritage of Tibetian people in Nepal and a worth to see monument for the others. I didn't want to leave. A peaceful place, with positive energy. A stupa surrounding from many temples and in the same time an important monument. Smells from the bunting sticks make the atmosphere so calm. Not only the Buddhists, but also the visitors feel like to pray. The place is like a small village, with restaurants, coffee shops and many small shops to buy interesting and cheap, good quality souvenirs. I enjoyed a lot my visit

Buddhist temples, exotic sights, sounds, smells. The Boudhanath area of Kathmandu has over 26 temples surrounding the largest stupa in the world. Pilgrims and visitors walk clockwise around the Kora, spinning prayer wheels, repeating mantras and observing the sights and sounds of this special area. Many restaurants with rooftop patios give one an amazing view of the stupa, temples and the Himalayas to the north. Always an interesting place to view Thangka paintings, singing bowls, prayer flags, mala's, incense, etc.

Spectacular!. This is one of the most beautiful and unique structures I have ever seen. Our group had the pleasure of writing our thoughts and prayers on primary colored flags and having a man bring the string of flags to fly at the top of the stupa. After walking aroung the stupa a few times and watching people doing their daily rituals, we were able to enjoy the area and its great shops and bargains. Not to be missed.

This is the most impressive, Tibetan Stupa, in Nepal. There is so much to see and witness around the Stupa - prayer wheels surround it; Buddhist monks praying and chanting and merchants with all manner of arts and crafts showing their beautiful artwork.
Kathmandu culture. Much better than the pictures. Also worth visiitng the Buddhist monastery and Thanka art school. Lots of interesting shops around the square

World Heritage Site…..awesome!. This Stupa is so powerful it's hard to describe. Circumambulate again and again with locals, pilgrims, and you'll see why. Never tired of it. Surrounding streets filled with shops better than Kat. of which it is a suburb. Dozens of monasteries that you can visit, 000's of monks here and there. Lots of Tibetans, very devoted to Buddhism. Safe and friendly, try Roof-Top Stupa restaurant for a fab. view and respite. Lit-up at night. Amazing sight.

Peaceful place..... and splendid sunset view!. Panoramic views of the Himalayan range, Fewa Lake and Pokhara city. The view of the still waters of the Fewa lake, the serene & beautiful Pokhara Valley with a backdrop of the snow-capped Annapurna range is beauty beyond compare. It’s a bit of a climb to get to the top of the Stupa but once you get there…. So worth it!!!

Visti to awesome stupa. It was simply awesome perfect place to meditate especially for Buddhists but people of all castes and creeds are well appreciated there. Calmness of mind is what I achieved there. Kathmandu itself is not a calm city. Oh, please remind me the traffic out there.
Nice monument. Its great place to be, but I could see new construction around it so much...would have been much better if the vicinity were untouched..

Beautiful!. The Bodnath Stupa is truly a beautiful site. A real peaceful surrounding only spoilt here and there by the odd person trying to sell themselves as a guide of the site. A must visit in Kathmandu

The icon of Kathmandu & worth the visit. Such a wonderful sight! Quite a peaceful spot in the midst of chaotic Kathmandu. Viewing the Stupa from a restaurant balcony, watching the carers throwing coloured liquid onto the stupa, is a memory I'll never forget. Enjoy a pleasant walk around the base viewing all of the stores and eateries as you go and also take the time to wander around the 'first level'. An iconic Kathmandu attraction worthy of visiting.

Peaceful in a busy world. Such a magnificent structure so close to a very busy, mad paced Kathmandu. When you walk through the gate the outside world disappeared. So peaceful, calm and meaningful. The small shops surrounding the stupa have all kinds of wares and the stall holders are friendly and not pushy.

Island of peace in busy Kathmandu. For me, definitely the best place in Kathmandu. Once you enter the square around stupa, all noise from busy Kathmandu streets disappears and suddenly you are at one of the rare places in Kathmandu without rush, noise etc. We loved it there, walked around stupa many times, had lunch in a rooftop restaurant (plus cafe few hours later - do not miss rooftop restaurants, they serve as excellent point of view to stupa and the whole square), in total we spent there a whole afternoon.Furthermore if you are interested in buying a piece of Thanka art (Mandala), pay a visit to some of few Thanka Art schools located around stupa. Not only they have good prices, but they will also show you around a painting school and explain you everything you want to know about drawing mandalas, etc. Definitelly better than to buy your mandala at some shabby place at Thamel.
loved it structure. I really loved the structure of the area, round area around the stupa, people chanting mantras and walking around the stupa, very peaceful environment and the well planned area..

Spiritually Inspiring. We saw it at sunset with the lighting of the candles around it shortly after dark from one of the roof top restaurants on the east side of the square. The sunset was spectacular and inspiring. Loved it!
Pretty. Worth seeing if you are in Katmandu. Loved the little stores around. Hated the masses of people and all the pigeons, but overall it was worth stopping and seeing.
Visit bodnath. Bodnath’s atmospheric environment is very peaceful, no traffic noise, no smoke and dusts and cool place rest your mind.

Zabojad Exploring Nepal Resham Firiri Tour 2014. Magic Energy and Peace while walking around the Bodnath Stupa. Zabojad has visited it twice in Spring 2012 and Winter 2014 with its Nepali Friends from Exploring Nepal, the same beautiful Feelings. A unique place to discover and feel while Exploring Nepal, to me it is Special as Cobra Bai the name I received from my Nepali brothers Sujan and Goks.Enjoying the Peace of this place is a must while in Kathmandu.

Amazing sight. The Bodnath Stupa was simply amazing - Thamel and Kathmandu are covered in temples and stupas everywhere you look, so I was expecting Bodnath to be more of the same, but it is really different. I'm not into the whole spritualism go find yourself in kathmadu thing as was only in town as I'd been working in Delhi and had a free weekend - but even so I was really taken by the atmosphere this place has. There is something very calming about the area around the stupa, it could be the relaxing chanting and singing, the smells of incence or something else, but wandering around the monasteries and soaking up the atmosphere here is something I can't get enough of.

very peaceful and spiritual. It is very peaceful and there is this vibe going on which feels very religious and so spiritual. it is very close to the main road but yet, the overall feeling was very calm and soothing inside the Stupa. This is also close to the Pashupatinath temple, which is another must visit.

The eye watches you. This Buddhist sputa which is about 7 km. from Kathmandu was built nearly 1500 years back. It has a large collection of Gompas. It is UNESCO world heritage site. The attraction is easy reached by taxi or local transport.

A great escape from Thamel. I love bodnath stupa, I stayed in the centre close to the stupa for my first three days to acclimatise to the culture shock which is Nepal. Outside of the quiet centre is the busy street filled with traffic and buses that you can dip in and out of. The monasteries are beautiful and the monks are welcoming. Meeting people on the pilgrimage here was just amazing. I can't wait to come back.

Amazing Bodnath Stupa. An impressive stupa and went there based on recommendation of trip advisor, A different cultural experience which is very unique what with the Buddist monks offering prayers, shops lined around the stupa and the restaurants boasting of a fantastic view of the stupa and offering different cuisines, Had a wonderful Nepalese meal in a cool ambience looking across at the stupa and the shops.Worth the experience.
Great Place. Great Stupa ..i really like it, I highly recommended this place for Traveler who want to visit nice place in Nepal.
