Try to come here at least once without a guide and allow yourself at least a night or two to stay here to understand that...
Very peaceful. Was a great experience to see all the pilgrimages and to be a part of a ceremony

Great place. Boudhanath Stupa is a must see place while you are in Kathmandu. The stupa surrounded with various shops and restaurant is a nice place to enjoy your time looking over the beautiful view. Peaceful, calm, beautiful, That is why I think it is under world heritage sites.

Favorite part of Kathmandu. A mostly Buddhist section, it is a quite peaceful, yet still busy section of Kathmandu. It does tend to shut down a bit early (compared to Thamel). The Stupa is a must see, and there are many great restaurants and shops in the area.

Must See!. The Stupa in Bhouda is a great place. It is surrounded by many shops and restaurants (make sure that you only walk clockwise around the Stupa). It is often crowded, with many monks, locals, ex pats and even a few tourists.

A nice cultural place with amazing views.. Our guide took us here in the afternoon. Its a very amazing and interesting place where you can just wonder round. The views of Kathamandu are stunning. There are some really nice vegetarian restaurants on the way up which are worth a visit. There are lots of people trying to sell you things, but you just have to ignore that. Definately worth a vist.

Nice place to visit. The stupa is quite impressive to see, with all its colors and watching Buddha eyes. I would also recommend visiting the beautiful monastery to see and listen to the monks chanting. It's a very peaceful moment that is worth living!

Ok place. Those who have visited the stupa in Borival, Mumbai (India), for them its a normal Stupa painted in white. I didn't find it that captivating. Rather the math next to Stupa was more beautiful and the deities of Buddha were superb in that.
Nice place. Good restaurants around there as well. There should be a guide with you to explain what's going on.

An unforgetable experience. We are not big on visiting churches, stupas, or other "religious" tourist attractions. However, visiting the Bodnath Stupa was an extraordinary experience. It is a beautiful structure, lined with nices shops, but the most impressive part was the peace and spirituality that we felt doing our visit. We visited the stupa as a member of a trekking group and several of us felt the same way. I would highly recommend a visit. The shopping is good but I recommend that you take the time to let the energy of the place touch you.
A symbol of Nepal. Culture, Believe, Peace,Trust, Love, Share Of mankind

A must see. My family and I lived near Boudha Stupa, it is wonderful. So authentic in every way. Best time to visit? 6 - 8 am for 'kora' walking around the stupa with locals and visiting devotee's. Anytime during the day for great shopping and lunch (be sure to walk side streets for even better deals) 4-6 pm for another round of walking 'meditation'. This site feels calm compared to the hectic streets of Nepal, a wonderful and spiritual oasis.

Peaceful. One feels a sense of peace as you circumnavigate the stupa... always clockwise. Like the shops. There is a Thankga shop & school where you can learn about the months long process to create the paintings. Don't like the few touts here and there, trying to sell things to tourists. They don't belong in such a serene, peaceful, religious, place!

More devotees than tourists. Well worth a visit, especially on a fine day to catch the light (an hour or so should suffice for many people). We would have liked to simply sit on a bench in the shade and look at the costumes of those buddhists doing the rounds, but there was only one of them and unfortunately the same eight locals were happily ensconced for the whole of the time we were there!

A must see. Everytime I go to Kathmandu I take my walk around the Stupa. Lots of praying Buddhists and some cute restaurants tucked in the alley ways. Watch out for the locals who try and sell to you or tell you about a loved one who is sick.....and might even offer you a white scarf in exchange for money.

Better than Swayambhunat. Although full of tourists (who have never read a guide book before which is clear from the way they dress = clearly against all rules recommended) it also gives a good insight in the religious life of Nepal. Impressing place!

Amazing Stupa Fell A Bless & Very Spiritual. BauddhaNath Stupa is So Spiritual Each Time I go Here i get My inner happiness & Blessed Fells Some thing New Will come Into My life Again i can not Say Enough About This Magical place So Warm Well maintained & The Prayers Waving Pray Flags & the Om Mane Padmein Huin Praying Wheels makes you Fell That Richness Of Buddhism The Surrounding is so Cheerful especially in the Evening Lights Love to Go back here again & Again Just too Good to Believe .

The world heritage site ~. Yeth! It was really the world heritage site with nice view from around the Stupa. I been there for 4th time when i were in Nepal and each time I went I enjoyed alots.Nepal without Boudhnath is not Nepal I speculation.Robert MD

An Inspirational Monument to Another Time. Walking around (and on) the Bodnath Stupa is a thought-provoking experience. The monument itself is beautiful to look at, well maintained and inspirational. Whilst not particularly religious myself, it is amazing to see people walking around and performing their acts of faith here. As stated in the title, the Stupa is linked to another time, a reflection of the past.The area itself is also enjoyable to walk around, surrounded by restaurants, cafes and little shops. Overall, a quiet way to spend an hour in a hectic city.There are crowds and a charge to enter but these do not detract from the actual Stupa.

relaxing. Major Buddhist temple, huge white stupa, simplistic. beautiful oasis in the middle of loud/chaotic traffic. very clean and well organized, almost looks like an italian piazza. Have coffee/lunch in a rooftop cafe to relax and watch.

Magnificent!. Sometimes you go to aplace that you have wanted to visit for years and you end up disappointed. And sometimes you go to a place that just blows your mind. The Boudha Stupa blew my mind. At least 1600 yrs old this holy site is a magnificent and humbling experience. The devout, the curious, monks, nuns, the old, the young, east meets west.Come with plenty of spare time to circumnabulate, people watch, poke around the shops, visit the shrines and spin the prayer wheels. Bring some small notes to give to the few beggars and make donations. Morning and evenings are best, and make sure you visit in the sun, the vibrancy of the gold and colours of the flags are simply stunning.A must see!

Wonderful. It is a lovely place with some very beautiful shops. The Street Vendors do not bother you as much as it is a Pilgrimage Site for Buddhists and is a world away from the rest of Nepal. Very Spiritual.
Overwhelming. A great architecture. Really worth visiting.But the surrounding was under renovation, it was all dust and dirt.

One of the most visited sights in Kathmandu, yet somehow it retains its peaceful, holy atmosphere. I had some doubts about going to Boudhanath because I thought it would be ruined by the tourist shops and hagglers that can't be avoided in Kathmandu's tourist sights. Somehow, the holiness of the site comes out completely unscathed from the tourist atmosphere. It felt very peaceful and I could not help but feel very spiritual being there, which I had not expected at all. In the inner courtyard, there is a place for quiet meditation and prostrations. I will always regret not having taken the time to spend a few hours of quiet reflection there... it's really worth going!

Overwhelming. Seeing this stupa was amazing. From the main street, we walked down a short sidewalk, at the end of which we could see the eyes painted on the stupa. Moving clockwise, we walked for a full rotation in the company of monks, local people, and other tourists. We then climbed some stairs to do another round of walking on the stupa. The Bodnath Stupa is huge; bright white, with numerous strings of prayer flags hanging from it. It has such power that I felt like I had to lean back in order to take it all in.

Amazing atmosphere. Just bring some hours of time to walk around, sit down somewhere where you can watch the colorful flags and the people and enjoy the incredibly peaceful atmosphere. An amazing place.
Beautifull. Really a world heritage site with nice restaurants around the Stupa.
Make peace around you. When my mind is tress at that time i use to go make fresh mind over there at bodnath stupa. I feel so nice and extra environment with lovely buddhist music.

beautiful. If you arrive befor noon or after 2 pm you can see the beautiful temple and see and hear the monks chanting. It's a pity that most tourist don't show any respect and talk loudly- but the monks don't mind it - or so it seems- they just continue chanting.A place you have to go!In the past this was the last place for the sherpa's and Tibetans to pray and ask for blessing and protection before crossing the Himalaya's!
Interesting Place. Huge and interesting place. The associated monasteries are worth a visit.
Beautiful. The stupa is well maintainel d, the temple is beautiful and they are very tolerant to tourist

The eyes are following you.... Well worth a visit. Set out in the eats of the city in a built up area. however, once you're inside the precincts of the stupa, it's a haven of tranquility in spite of the shops and restaurants that surround it. Even if the religious aspects of the stupa don't interest you too much its scale and and design are something to behold.

Top attraction with lots of restaurants, shops and monasteries nearby. Boudhanath is a top Kathmandu attraction with several adjacent restaurants, shops and monasteries. I would suggest arriving in late morning to visit the stupa and the shops around it, have lunch on a rooftop in one of the restaurants and then spend part of the afternoon exploring the nearby Tibetan Gompas (monasteries).

Boudhanath - a beautiful temple. Although there were many people there - the atmosphere was serene and tranquil. We were not hassled, there were no beggars (unlike the monkey temple), and it was altogether the nicest place that I visited in Kathnabdu.

An absolute must!. Go to Boudanath early in the morning, before the tourist crowds, and the many locals who go there swarm the place. In fact this goes for most places, including Swayambu and Baktapur or Patan. It is a very atmospheric place for photographs if you catch it early mornings and afternoons. The light on the huge gompa and the flags is just amazing!
The Stupa !!!. It was the 8th time that we were in Nepal and each time we must and will visit Bodnath.Nepal without Bodnath is not Nepal.

A Calmer Small-town Visit. This was a great way to see a small town and the temples it contains. The vendors were incesstant but charming! We had a great lunch in a restaurant overlooking the main square.

Someone's Watching. This was an incredible place to visit. It was clean and uncrowded. The stupa is amazing and it was fun to view it from different angles. There were many interesting shops, etc. surrounding the temple.
a must-see in ktm. a must-see in ktm, huge monument and nice area. Surrounded by nice temples too

Great place for a walk before dinner. One of the most memorable and iconic sites in Nepal. Super place to circulate around and then go for dinner in one of the roof top cafes. Often monks come here to pray and have services. Watch out for some rip off people - a guy who said he was 'the artist' that painted the momument asked me to put saffron in the holy bowls, then tried to get me to pay him 1000Ruppees for the privilege! I was obviously 'green' having just got off the plane. But said I didn't have any money on me and left. I had made the mistake of circulating anti-clockwise around a chamber within the monument, which probably caused this bad karma.
World Heritage Site. 'Nuff said, really. Just remember to walk around it clockwise, or you'll be fighting the traffic flow.

Little too commerical. It's a pity the Stupa is ringed by little shops aimed at tourists. It really detracts from the experience. However, the few Buddhist sites within the ring are well worth a visit.

A very sacred place. The best time to visit this site is early evening when most of tourists have gone and the place is lit by thousands of butter lamps. The rooftop cafe's are a great place to get views of the stupa while drinking masala tea.
Nice city. We took a guided tour of the city for 400 rupees. It cost 1100 rupees to enter the area. The tour took about 2 hours. It`s a nice city with lots of culture.

One of the oldest and Holiest Shrines in Nepal.. Its one of the prominent features in the Kathmandu Sight Seeing itenary. Though, it does not serve any visual treat as such, this place is more famous for it rich history. Its located on the ancient Silk Trade Route between Nepal and Tibet, and hosts lots of Tibetan Refugees as residents now.You would really need to appreciate its importance as a historical monument being enlisted as an Unescao World Heritage Site, than just go for beautiful surroundings.

Reasonable short trip. A reasonable place for a short visit but not a highlight. The best part of the trip for us was the shops selling hand painted religious works - with a number of places that you can see them being painted. The detail is incredible and you can appreciate the different standards as pupils progress over many years to masters.
good experience. Definitely a good cultural experience. This area has a large Tibetan/Tibetan Refugee population. People still practice Tibetan Buddhism at this stupa.
An icon of Nepal. I loved the atmosphere surrounding the place...at midday it was really hot but well worth the visit....
Excellent. Brilliant! Quiet traffic free area with lots to see around the stupa itself. Felt very safe

Great picture opportunities. Boudhanath Stoupa is a circular area which you can walk around and it has plenty of shops around the outside. The Stoupa is in the centre and the colours of all the flags are great photo opportunities.
One of the best Stoupa's in Kathmandu.

Interesting Cultural Site. We visited the Boudhanath Stupa after our visit, in the morning, to Pashupatinath Temple. Expect to pay Rs 300 for a taxi ride between the two sites. While Boudhanath Temple is certainly fascinating, I do not believe it deserves the current number 2 ranking on TripAdvisor. If you have visited Tibet you will be disappointed in this stupa, and by Kathmandu generally. We did, however, enjoy our walk around and on the stupa and managed to get some good photo's. Following a tiring morning we enjoyed lunch at one of the cafés overlooking the stupa – that is most enjoyable and well worth the effort. Also there are many tourist shops around the stupa selling items that you can obtain most places around Nepal. Overall it was worth the visit, and worth the Rs 150 (around USD 2) entry fee per person.(NOTE: There seems to be a duplication on TripAdvisor with respect to the same place – Boudhanath (currently ranked number 2 on TripAdvisor) is the same, as far as I can tell, as Bodnath Stupa (currently ranked 5 on TripAdvisor).

Large Buddist Stupa(Temple). This is the largest Buddist Stupa in Kathmandu and worth visiting whilst there. Interesting in it's own right, there isn't actually that much more to it than what you see. It is a solid structure, so there is nowhere to go inside it. You walk around, look at it and it is completely surrounded by shops selling TTT = typical tourist tat. There are two temples off to the side with some intersting features. One devoted to the Delhi Lama. Entrance fee is 200 Rupes.

An almost inside visit to tibet!. The Boudhnath stupa is an extremely enriching experience. The moment one enters, we feel the spirituality of buddhism. The lama's wandering in the premises and the preaching of the dalai lama playing on the cd's......A good guide is very important here without which the trip is meaningless.The only drawback here is that they have commercialised the area to sell souvenirs etc. Tibetan arts and goods was what this area was originally meant to sell but now its mostly the same overpriced souvenir shops that we see at the tourist attractions. Another thing is that the area has a controlled entrance but one can easily enter and depart from the bylanes of the stupa which has no entry/exit barriers. Entry fees are 200 for all foreigners except members of SAARC and 40 Nepali Rupees for SAARC country citizens.

My Favorite!. I loved Boudhanath. Try all the restaurants and buy all your presents to take home to your friends. Much of the sales goods are from Tibet. All I could say was "Did I tell you my favorite place on this vacation was Boudhanath?"CT from Pacific Palisades

The most impressive Stupa in Nepal. I went to the Stupa with my wife it is impressive to see from a distance, also to walk around it... its really something, so a must in case you want to visit Kathmandu, but in all honesty after making some pictures, unless you love moving from one touristic shop or small restaurant to the other, there isn't that much to see and you'll be out in less than an hour.That said It is one of the sights you should visit in Kathmandu, despite the fact that your out in less than an hour.
Don't step over the flags. Lots of prayer flags that hang low. They consider it disrespectful to step over them. Bargain and buy some then go to monastary and get them blessed by monk.

Lots of dogs here. Went to check the place out because it was so highly rates here ... and while the place was interesting to visit, I found it a little smelly (like most Nepal's religious sites) and there were just too many stray dogs roaming around for my peace of mind. Overall, the Stupa is beautiful, the locale has many shops for tourists, hotels and restaurants, nice Monastaries to check out and also from some points it looks like a quaint European village ... so very interesting ...!!!

Holy Stupa of Nepal. This is one of the most important and holiest Buddhist sites in Nepal. It is well worth a visit and is a good location for taking photographs. If you need to shop for local souvenirs, the shops inside the site would be a good start. They might be a bit more expensive than outside but these shops are usually more reliable. So if you are shopping for more expensive items it is a good idea to check here first. There are coffee shops around the Stupa and their roofs would provide you with a good view. WiFi is usually available in the bigger coffee shops too.One important thing, please always try to go around a stupa clockwise. Although this is only a Buddhism ritual but it is always a good idea to respect local tradition - plus you'll get good luck blessing doing so!

Great place to visit... Its a nice place to see and photo opportunity. You can find so many shops, hotels & restaurant (mostly with wifi internet) inside the surrounding area of the Stupa. Visit and explore all the temples inside. You can find several of them. A must to visit if your in Kathmandu.

Boudha Stupa in Kathmandu. Boudha, one of two major Buddhist enclaves in Kathmandu, is endlessly fascinating, with people of all ages circumnavigating the world-famous stupa in a clockwise fashion. Dawn and dusk are the busiest times with a constant river of human traffic in colorful clothes. Smiling amah-las (grannies) give candy to pouty children, Bells clang, monks chant, kids play soccer with a plastic bottle. These sounds drift in and out as you circle the stupa. The smell of incense fills the air, the prayer flags flap in the wind, the prayer wheels spin.This is a world class spot to people watch.

Tranquility Spa. Near Boudnath Stupa - about 100m up the narrow street to Tinchuli. Much cheaper here than the other spa's in town. Big wooden building - big airy wooden treatment rooms. Gentle music in background. Professional people giving the treatments. I had a Shiatso, 90mins, I think it was less than 1000 Nrps (£10). Found it on our last day - else would have used more!!

The most beautiful temple in Kathmandu!. This Buddhist temple is right in the city and a relatively small complex, but grande in scale. There are tons of prayer wheels at the base of the stupa. You'll smell incense burning everywhere. The stupa is surrounded by houses that contain shops on the bottom floor. There were few beggars and no monkeys.
